reviewText:
To be honest I really enjoyed the first couple of hours of gameplay.  The visuals, like usual, were quite nice, the game ran smoothly (for me) and it was overall quite pleasant.  Then I hit about 6 hours in and I unlocked the Lunar base and was pumped.  But it was just downhill from there.  I had hoped with the greatly simplified UI (if a bit perplexing at the start) that the tediousness of the last Anno would be fixed.  Wrongo.  If anything with multiple 'settlements' the micromanagement was intensified.  The supply chains, to me, are useless.  Produce something at colony X send it to colony Y and since colony Y doesn't pay for it I get a net loss.  So then to help offset the huge costs to start a lunar colony (and the artic to a lesser extent) I figured that if I shipped resources to the world market (or whatever its called) I could use that as a means to develop my colonies more.  NOPE!  Even selling resources on the world market cost me to sell it.  The only way I made a profit was to sell 1000+ units of the item.  Completely stupid and baseless (not to mention improbable).  Short of dumping a huge amount of time and effort to overdevelop my starting colony I couldn't make enough to make my lunar colony sustainable.  Which then made it impractical to send the resources I was producing back to Earth, which made my people mad, which made me less money which made me shut off more things.... just sprials.

Pros:
+The simplified UI does help in many regards (more on this later as this is a cusory pro)
+Introduction of a Military into the game was a nice touch, if not implemented all that well.
+Interesting factions, even if your relationship to them is fixed and therefore meaningless

Cons:
-While hardly known (at least recently) for telling a story, the campaign of the game is hollow and feels more like a checklist and less like a way for the game to get me involved.
-The factions are hollow are offer nothing to the game other than different people.  You can only buy items from them, but cannot sell.   You could lump them all into the group of 'Other' (with the remaining factions being us and them) and you wouldn't miss a thing.
-MIlitary integration feels like an afterthought and like you are hired as a contractor to help with someone elses problems rather than managing the military aspect directly.
-Missions are bland and often are 'go here, pick this up, bring it back, get resource, rinse and repeat'.
-Feels more like you took the previous game, reskinned it and made me pay for it again.
-No replay value (in my limited opinion)
-The UI while it looks pretty is just strange.  When tabbing between the different menus (population types for instance) I would expect to see only buildings unique to that population showing up.  IE:  The worker tab has worker buildings, the Exec tab has exec buildings, etc.  Nope.  When tabbing between the two (which when you first get the second tier population you spend time looking around to figure out how to start building the 'tier 2' (if you will) buildings as it is not explained) it seems the whole bottom row comes with it.  After the first couple of times you figure out that those buildings are common buildings but the level of detail in the menus are just nonexistent or just not explained (starting to see a trend?).
-Speaking of level of detail, playing as a CEO of a multi-planet corporation, one would think that details would be in abundance.  I like games Distant Worlds for instance where there is an immense level of detail always a click away.  If I want to know something I can find out but the game doesn't innudate me with detail otherwise.  Anno gives me little to no details on very important things.  Like on the lunar colony for instance, I built a maintenance center and my income dropped for 17K to 9K.  Uh, how?  If this building is going to cost me 8K to maintain a little heads up would be nice!  Sure I want to know how much resource this thing is going to cost me but without mula, resources (Which again cost more to sell than you get by selling them) are useless!
-A little more about factions:  The other companies are useless.  They are more like obstacles between me and new regions rather than a competing factor.  You could delete them from the game and miss nothing.
-This game fails to innovate in almost anyway.  It is standard now for games of this type and supposed caliber to improve on old systems and to experiment a bit.  We got the experimenting bit with adding new regions (which is done well, to be fair) but all the old systems are just reskinned.  Public opinion seems like an after thought (if you even pay attention to it), decisions (which are 'lets pick a company to vote for', more on this in a moment) are pretty much pointless, the global market is broken, I can't monopolize on having a fricken SPACE ELEVATOR!  Apparently space elevators are only for this global company/government (confused?  So am I) and security centers cost more to maintain (seriously?), etc etc.  Just poorly implemented systems that have the exact same failings as the previous Anno.
-Decisions.  I can't think of a reason why I would vote for these things.  They seem to give no real benefit (or it is so poorly implement [and not explained, period] and so transparent and ineffectual that if you don't vote then who cares!).  Plus I am voting for other companies.  First of all, why?  Why would I vote for another company?  I mean seriously!  Second of all, I am a major corporation, why am I not included?  Why are they included?  Why why why why.  Oh, and are votes a daily thing?  Weekly?  ummmmm, yeah, idk.  I just went back every once in a while and it was like 'and this was the outcome, vote again!'  Thanks but no thanks.  (I feel like there is a trend here)
-This game feels like everyone created their own systems and didn't talk to anyone else.  Just plain pointless.  SAVE YOUR MONEY

But all in all, I have little playtime so I would take that into account when reading this.  Maybe things change as you play more but, at 8.6 hours, I feel no reason to go back to the game other than to watch my little company spiral out of control.

Sarcasm fully intended.

reviewText:
Is it any good?
I really like it.  I realise that isn't exactly helpful, so to put this in some sort of context, many people aren't enjoying it for the same reasons I AM enjoying it.  As a background, I very much enjoyed Annos 2070, 1404 and the rather older 1602 and plowed hundreds of hours into these games.  I was rather worried that this new game would simply be a reskinned Anno 2070 but I'm happy to say it's not.  There are many fresh ideas that change it just enough to make it feel like a new and different game yet retaining the Anno feel.  The developers have removed some of the more menial micro-management tasks - contentiously, because many players are complaining about that now.

The graphics are as gorgeous as shown in the screenshots, and the three different areas of temperate land, the Arctic and the moon have been incredibly recreated.  One issue people are running into is performance; I have a 6-core i7 with a 6Gb nVidia Titan Black together with 16Gb memory and even at a basic 1080p resolution I've had to pull back the settings from 'ultra' - the first game I've ever had to reduce.  Ubisoft has recommended playing with a GTX 680 or higher to get the best out of the game and I can see why.  Use Steam's 2-hour refund window to see how it runs on your PC.


If you've never played an Anno game before...
Ubisoft has clearly worked hard to make the user interface much more friendly.  However, this game explains even less than the tutorial of Anno 2070 did!  For example: there are no on-screen prompts to help a newcomer in towing a vessel with their command ship (do you left-click, right-click or what?  Do you click your vessel first, or the ship you are meant to be towing,   and how do you know which vessel to tow?).  Us oldies will know that you highlight the mission, look for the orange dot on the map that appears and head for that.  Newcomers might flounder because a lot of very basic stuff has been left to players' memories of previous games.

Personally, I would recommend first dipping into the still gorgeous and highly enjoyable (and now cheap) Anno 1404 - simply because the detailed campaign teaches you how to play ALL the Annos pretty much.  If not, ask in the forums for opinions from other newcomers because most reviews seem to be written by experienced players.


If you've played previous Anno games...
Anno 2205 is getting a very mixed reception because there have been significant changes.  For the most part, I really like them, but many people don't, so I'll list the main changes in the hope it helps you decide whether you will like it or not:

1.  No random map seeds.  I can see why, because maps are fully 3D rendered with incredible dams, places for gargantuan bridges and it would be very difficult to generate these procedurally.  As a result, you basically have 9 fixed maps from which to choose.  It's not many, but more will be coming via DLC such as Tundra and Orbit.

2.  No multiple warehouses and transportation of goods.  Everything now must be connected by roads to your coastal warehouse, and the costs you incur are determined by how far goods must travel (you can place localised transport depots to reduce these).  Again, I REALLY love this change.  It's more realistic, and in Anno 2070 it was annoying having to pock-mark my maps with warehouses just to make all areas of the terrain buildable.  That's a thing of the past now!

3. No more town centres.  Nope - you don't have to build within a small, circular radius now.  This I think is a fantastic change.

4.  No more fields for farms etc.  I found fields cluttered my city designs in Anno 2070 so am not missing them particularly, but it's made some people unhappy.  Instead, your production factories now have modular add-ons to increase their output, reduce their energy consumption and such, and they bolt onto the building in the same style as Simcity 2013.

5.  No 'continuous map' mode.  This is a bit of a concern, but what seems to have happened is that the developers have this time merged the campaign into what IS actually a free-form world.  Imagine playing a continuous-map game as in Anno 2070, when up pops one of the (once separate) side missions right in your new world!  It's making people think there is JUST campaign mode when it's actually just a map that you can play how you like.

6. No multiplayer in this one.  I'm perfectly fine with that (I don't like multiplayer and Ubisoft claims that the multiplayer part of Anno 2070 was only played by the tiniest percentage of users).  If you enjoyed Anno 2070's multiplayer, this is something that might be of concern to you.

7. Combat has been moved to its own map.  This is so that nuisance enemies don't bother people who really just want to build relaxing worlds.  However, you really need to partake in some of the battles in order to win resources you can use in your own map.  People have criticised the combat but, beyond it being in its own map which I don't mind too much, the combat seems to be quite an improvement on Anno 2070's combat, but it is still very basic (as it always was in Anno games).


In summary...
Anno 2205 has been received well with 81% on meta-critic at the time of writing, but many Steam reviewers are panning it for some significant changes to the Anno formula (the biggest are listed above) so existing Anno gamers will need to decide for themselves, using Steam's 2-hour refund window.  I love it personally.  In my opinion, most of what was annoying has been removed, to be replaced with better features.  I am a bit concerned about the map limitation (no random-seeded maps any longer) and performance is a tad hefty, but there have been no bugs and it is a gorgeous game - incredible to look at and enjoyable to play.

reviewText:
Whilst I generally do not say anything about the game when I find something that I personally think is lacking, though this I have to admit I did not expect.

If someone is only interested in the campaign, then by all means, this title is just for you.

But for those that enjoy sharing experiences with friends or to have countless hours fooling about against AI, well then it's all down hill. Whilst the somewhat simplified gamestyle is a bit of a thorn, cannot complain too much as it makes the game more new player friendly. Though even so it would have been nice to have more complexity and not keep it as linear. SimCity 2000 is more complex than this title is at the moment.

But the little bit of text compiled into simple things that I personally feel ruin the game experience for me are:

No Multiplayer

No Sandbox/Skirmish/Any other mode but Campaign

Simplistic mechanics

Perhaps in the future if more content is released the opinion might change, but as for the time of release, greatly disappointed.

reviewText:
In a nutshell: Microsoft Office Excel 2205, AKA Spreadsheet Simulator

If you're a fan of the Anno franchise like I am, I'd say skip over this entry, or if you can't resist the temptation, buy it when it gets a price cut and is on sale.
The way the game is handled is RADICALLY different from any other Anno game so far. Strategy is not a thing in this game, you can just throw down buildings randomly and happily chuck along. Your citizens need food? Place a rice farm in an spot and they're instantly supplied. Are they thirsty? Find a coastal slot and throw down a water bottle whatever. It's simple and it's unappealing, half of the time I'm just waiting for numbers to go up.

Oh right, there's combat too, I guess.
See, the game is split into sectors"

reviewText: This game was a huge disappointment. If you think everything about previous Anno games is difficult and just too complicated then this game is probably for you. Everything has been simplified and a good deal of your building locations have already been pre allocated for you. There are no side missions, there is one game mode, continuous, and there are very few costomizable options. There are 3 maps for each location, Temperate (Earth), Arctic (Earth), and Lunar (Moon). There are no longer different factions to play as, just different types of people for each location. The people icons that appear when you click on a residence or a trading warehouse is no longer a decent size tucked away off to the side of the screen. It is now a big cartoony ♥♥♥ face in the middle of your screen, and the voices are just horrible it makes you want to mute them all. The game looks beautiful overall, (unless you zoom in real close, then it just looks cartoony) but is extremely lacking in substance. The game has an overall consistency of a play to win mobile or tablet app. 1/10 (Because it looks pretty.) This game is not worth $60, let alone the $80 for the season pass included. If your curious just wait until it goes on sale for $5 or $10, because thats whats its worth. Waiting for the game to save the money is worth it. Your not missing out on anything.

reviewText:
From chess to 3-in-a-row...that's how this game feels when you have played previous Anno games before Anno 2205.
Almost everything like trade, diplomacy, managing time, managing building space,...has been simplified, even oversimplified. Unlike previous Anno games, you can get things done with a few mouseclicks and be done with it for the remainder of the game.
From making a mistake to completely ingnoring certain aspects, nothing will punish you in the game.
This game brings the hope and need for DLC's blowing new life into it, much to fast. A way to sell as much DLC as possible right after release? I don't know...but very cheap if intended.

Does this game have the right to exist? Offcourse.
Does this game have the right to wear the Anno title and a €60/€80 pricetag? No, definitely not...

reviewText:
I got Anno 2070 a few years ago and absolutely loved it! I wracked up a lot of playtime with this beautiful looking game.
I don't really play single player missions in games, but this was alright in comparisson to a lot of games on the market.

Continuous play and multiplayer are what makes this game great, the freedom to span a map with your colony to grow your mighty city into a thriving metropolis.....

Oh wait, this is Anno 2205?I bought this game luckily last time it went on offer.. Do not buy it unless its on offer, if you really MUST buy it, and I cannot think of a reason why anyone who doesn't have it by now should get it.

The great things that Anno 2070 and Anno 1404 had in them, such as continuous play, multiplayer, oh and freedom,  ARE GONE

Don't get me wrong, its a beautiful game, it really is! But the entire game is a campaign designed to make you feel like you have freedom, but you don't. You don't have a warehouses that fill up when you over produce a good, making expansion extraordinarily tedious, you have to balance resources without even an inkling into what you are doing wrong in some stages.
It is literally quest, mission, quest, mission, quest, mission. The endless cycle like a TF2 map!


Other reviews saying that UPLAY is the issue, they are wrong. Just google a work around for loading UPLAY up (Program Files- Right click the launcher and open it in administrator mode)
UPLAY isn't the issue for this game. The Game itself is ♥♥♥♥ing awful.

reviewText: Game is still pretty much an Anno game, with city building and resource management aspects of the game intact. There are three main zones (temperate, arctic and lunar) which corresponds to Ecos, Tycoon and Tech factions in Anno 2070. Gameplay is tweaked and streamlined such that resource management is straight forward plop-and-forget, unlike previous Anno where placement is more critical and planning is required. Trading is also streamlined but in hindsight regressed, with trading featured only between sectors (world). Within sectors, there is no need to move goods around islands as they are all interlinked.\n\nHowever, at initial launch, the game lacks replayability and excitement that comes from random maps (almost all previous Annos), items (Anno 2070), exploration in that adds depth to the game. Maps are fixed (9 variants) and lack variety, and missions are very similar in nature with the same scripts across multiple play-through, unlike GTA or even other modern games where the scripts are varied. In particular, items are also totally stripped out, and there are no longer things that make your world unique such as ship equipment, ark upgrades, island-specific upgrades that makes the game exciting.

reviewText:
This version is getting a lot of flak for daring to finally change Anno's mechanics. If you are looking for a strict yet-another-Anno-with-same-mechanics, this is not for you.

However, ironically this is hands down the best Anno experience for me. Streamlining the logistics (Anno hasn't really never been able to give much tools for that) works perfectly for me, and now it's a strict production and space optimization simulation.

Perfect. Consider this a spin-off of the original series, and it's easier to objectively consider the game's overall value.

The price is a bit steep, but damn it's beatiful to look at; the terrain is incredibly detailed or at least manages to convey a really good impression of detail. UI is also so much better than the clusterfudge of previous Anno 2070. Also, combat is now done in their completely isolated missions, and works for me; it has always been the least interesting part of the series.

reviewText:
I've been playing the Anno series for a while now and feel compelled to leave a review about this one. The biggest complaint about this game is that they simplified the game mechanics. While that is true I still found the game to be pretty enjoyable when it works.

This game crashes a lot for me and I have a pretty standard setup (other than Windows 10 I guess). I still get framerate drops down to 30-40 fps on Ultra running a 980Ti at 1080p.

My biggest complaint is that there is no way to manually save the game. The auto-saves seem inconsistent at best but I have lost hours of progress on this game due to frequent crashes and lack of a manual save. I can't even believe this is a thing. I just can't even imagine why the devs wouldn't include a manual save feature.

reviewText:
General Honest openion on this game:

First i would like to mention that this is the first anno series i played so i pretty much didn't know what to expect.

Pros:

1)Graphics are great, looks very sci-fi and fresh compared to other city building games(Animations are great specially cars in the street and factory workers moving around)
2)Nice economy concept on how goods are consumed and produced.

Cons: (The bad, what is really going on .... and what really went wrong).

1)Firstly; the game objective is building 3 colonies in 3 different world regions (mainly the temperate zone, Polar Zone and Lunar base the Moon) and gets addicting until u finish your first two or one colony. Honestly the game gets really boring after 15 hours of game play mainly because as far from what i see there are limited things to build and u really get the whole picure of the game within 4 to 5 hours of game play, so there is really no future suprise element that enhances the game play.

2)Combat: The combat system is nice but i wish if the developers made it bit real time. Combat in this game is just basically 4 to 6 ships and controling them to the enemy base with their units and nothing else. so basically you don't invade a city and you don't destory it so the entire combat thing is just on a different isolated map from where you actually build your city.

3)Building the Ciy: What is really sad about this game is that everything u want to build is kinda bit forced on you, For example the bridge & Dam you see in the images are kinda invisible in the game or destoried  (the dam that is) and you just right click and it builds them once you supplied the materials. so basicaly if u want to build the bridge else where u can't as you must choose with the AI tells you in the recommended locations same thing goes for many structures in the game.

Conclusion:

If your looking for a game that will give you 100 hours of game play addiction, this is not for you and it will simply just waste your money. The only maps you will enjoy building is the temperate zone or green zone but the Ice zone (polar maps) and lunar base gets really boring due to restrictions such as heat field & enegry shield when building houses.

reviewText:
Never played Anno before so this was my first one.

I found the graphics and themery to be quite beautiful.

The game has massive flaws in construction managing - especially when it comes to modules which are often awkwardly shaped and in most cases larger than the original structure - while providing the exact same thing the base building did (A Rice farm and it's module will both produce the same amoung of rice despite the module being nearly twice the size.)

The economy for trading is BAD.  It is impossile to profit, even using the world market is barely enough to draw in a profit.  The taxes on trades can go well up to 10,000 after a couple of units and eat up all your profits instantly unless you're in the game of super massive overproduction (which is impossible to achieve because mass producing things just raises your needs more and more.) - This system is further insulting when you have to pay extortion level logistics between YOUR OWN colonies.

I played the campaign on easy and finished the game story" with 3 maps
date: however I was unable to continue my career as I was constantly in the financial negative and unable to help myself as the other 6 maps were locked behind whopping 2 million credit costs.  To make matters worst everytime I built a profitable thing to sell (Example: A.I.) it's needs would interfere and I would have to supplement them.  This leads to an endless circle of somebody - somewhere missing resources
recommended: and no profit being made - energy expendature constantly increasing and leaving me with an overall feeling of dissatisfaction.  It was like playing on a teeter totter except at the end the other kid gets off and you're stuck on the bottom with no way up.\n\nMaps are small and awkward
hoursPlayed: and most space is not viable for building
voteText:
of course the module sizes contribute to this and eat up atleast 60-70% of your map.

The Naval combat was shallow and boring and had no depth whatsoever - and no purpose as it did not affect your development - in fact I wasted credits upgrading ships when I could have ignored this aspect alltogether.

30 hours or so on the game I wonder why.  Why did I waste my time on this?  I don't feel victorious
helpfulPercent: I feel I failed at a game dedicated to "balancing" which just gets frustrating at the end.\n\nReally would not recommend this game to anybody - if it wasn't pretty I wouldn't have even stayed for as long as I did.  2/10 game at best

reviewText:
One of the biggest dissapointments in game history... I've been waiting for this game for years, and what have they brought? an empty game with merely 15 hours of gameplay, and no replay value at all; no map generator, it's always the same 5 boring maps over and over... with the exact same tutorial - campaing...

No computer players with cities, instead a secondary and totally boring minigame with a few boats to blow up the enemies in the exact 2 repeating maps over and over.

Trading is boring, you no longer have to think about building ships and stablishing trading routes, you simply clik here and there and the resources are transferred automatically.

This game is basically a oversimplified version of the older Anno's, it's so simplified it looses all the fun and strategy the saga had in older tittles...

Go buy Anno 2070, or Anno 1404 if you want a good game with houndreds of hours of gameplay.

The game is not a good Anno-series follow-up as it's too restricted to be one (e.g. just one mode of gameplay with fixed maps). Probably was pushed as a fundsraiser by Ubisoft...

Please use my money to make it better Ubisoft, not to sniff that line of cocaine at your desk.

reviewText:
!!!READ THE ENTIRE REVIEW TO SEE WHY I'M NOT RECOMMENDING THIS!!!
2015-11-04: Last edit before I finish the campaign and give the game a score

I've played all of the Anno games before, and I have hundreds of hours on them. I have played on the hardest difficulty from when I started this game up for the first time.



Anno 2205 differs alot from the other Anno games and many of the mechanics are more streamlined and dumbed down. Infinite resources, no random maps, no multiplayer, no AI to battle on the maps where you build your cities and no warehouses or town halls.

The Anno feel is still here though, managing your supplies and juggling betwen regions instead of islands and send materials back and forth betwen your different cities. Trading is now instant and you don't need boats to do it, instead it will cost X ammount of cash to maintain each trading route.

For anyone new to the Anno series this is probably the best game to start on, and for the veterans it is still a polished and bug free game. Just keep in mind that alot has been changed, so that it wont come as a surprise.

Difficulty is really easy, even though I'm playing on the hardest difficulty. Generating resources and income is as basic as it get's in a city sim and I've had no problems getting the resource I need. Planning your cities ahead isn't that big of a deal any more since you can freely move buildings around and since you have no warehouses, building a logic road system isn't an issue any more.

They've changed how the industrial buildings work by adding the ability to upgrade them with modules which costs resources you cannot obtain other then by doing missions. This does add a sense of missions actually being worthwile. But I have so far not ran out of said resource and I always have a surplus of them.

Battles are now confined to areas where there are no city building. You will get a fleet and a mission on a map that you need to complete to get the rewards, which consists of rare resources to upgrade your factories. You can upgrade said fleet if you have the cash and experience needed, and it feels like a nice edition. This does mean that there will be no combat where you build your cities though, so no defense what so ever is needed in your cities or on your trade routes.

You will spend most of your time on three areas; Temperate, artic and the moon, each being more expensive to build on and each having it's own resources that all of your cities will consume. Going between them isn't an issue for me, but if you don't have a good computer the loading time is probably really laggy and long.



All in all it's a polished city builder with some really basic trading elements. And it would be a great game if the price was lower. Considering all of the things they removed from previous games, like multiplayer, I can't see how the price is acceptable. As I keep playing I just get this feeling that an DLC will be released sooner rather then later that will add a bunch of the stuff that feels like it's missing now, and we the players shouldn't accept this buisness model.



TL;DR
Get the game on a sale, there are more content rich city sims out there that are alot cheaper then this one. This feels like a set-up for DLCs,

For anyone still intrested in how the game mechanics works, here is a video of the first 30 minutes of gameplay:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HEf4avR_tLk&feature=youtu.be

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game.  Even with all the great games that came out within a month of this one; Legacy of the Void, Fallout 4, and SW Battlefront this was the game I was most looking forward too because when all other games start to get tedious and the story starts to feel stale, you could always jump back into an Anno game, start from scratch and get 20+ hours out of a single development.  Anno 2070 was a gold standard, it provided the right balance between city-building, combat between competing factions, and random objective / crises situations that could be resolved or ignored depending on how you wanted to play the game.\n\nAfter a single 26 hour playthrough of Anno 2205 I can sadly say that this game diverges an astonishing amount from the incredible Anno gameplay style players have known and loved.  There is absolutely no challenge beyond resource balancing that occurs throughout the game.  After putting +250 hours into Anno 2070, I can say with a great deal of sadness that I wont be putting more than 30 into 2205, because there's simply no point in replaying.  Even on harder difficulties its just a matter of expanding and expanding resource production...no challenge, no replayability, the first and only playthrough most players will experience also starts to feel tedious after 10 hours.

reviewText:
Loved the lunar and artic settings which combined for a great global style game. Graphics were good and overall seemed a decent upgrade on the Anno series. The addition of heat zones in the artic region was also a new twist that I enjoyed creatively solving (just like the lunar shields). Modules to expand existing buildings were also cool, much better than blindly making a carbon copy new building each time. Increasing immersion was the parallel running of all the zones since it simulates how it would really work. Finally, auto game save/sync worked flawlessly for me.

However I feel there is also a lot wrong with this game.

1. I liked the AI as the enemy in Anno 2070 as I feel it helped build and round out the story. In 2205 the terrorists (wow original) are forgettable, literally ignorable, and seem to break the story immersion more than than help it.

2. There are a ton of zones but pretty much all are useless. Sure I bought them all from competitors but I never needed more than my original three zone plus one temperate zone in order to max everything out. Also the zone swap load time is an annoyance, entirely too long even on a SSD and high end computer.

3. Transport routes are ridiculous as well. Easy to set up but having to set up a new route for every little thing was a HUGE pain. Especially when my route list got to the point it required scrolling (again that was only 4 zones, not even half the ones possible). I much preferred the 2070 method where you could mix and match on a single transport. Making this far more absurd is that you get 'magic' transport size in 2205 anyway where the amount you can transport automatically increases and you just pay more credits. With that being the case why limit one transport to one item?

4. Building modules while an awesome thing were also problematic in that they only fit 'right' in about half the building types. Some of them would fit like perfect puzzles in a couple different ways while others were so far out in left field I wondered if maybe they had one designer on the core building and another on just the modules.

5. Uplay required and Uplay sucks. Ok it has improved but who uses it because they want to?

6. DLC also sucks.

All in all it was an OK game but far more negatives than positives in my opinion. If you loved 2070 you will like this game even if you might not love it. Worth buying ONLY on a significant Steam sale.

reviewText:
I like Anno 2205, but Anno 2070 was better.

The current version of the game has little to no replay value at the moment, and people like me whop played the previous game are not a very big fan of the new supply chain system. Yes it is cool that you can/have to have supply lines linking the 3 different area types in the game, and contary to popular belief you CAN stockpile goods. The problem is that the stock pile of consumer goods is almost non-existant compared to Anno 2070 and the amount of supplies in storage is not displayed.

The game is really pretty, but not very well optimized and tends to start dropping FPS after an hour or two in game. The combat is limited to 2 missions that you repeat to get rare resources.

But what really bugs me is HOW THE HELL DID TERRORISTS FROM THE MOON GET SUCH AN ENOURMOUS WET NAVY DOWN TO EARTH WITH NO ONE NOTICING!?

As with every other game I've given a remotely positive review of: get it on sale if you want it at all.

reviewText:
I'm a great fan of the Anno series, but my recommendation is as follows:

Do not buy at this time.  Wait for a significant discount.

Pros
Graphics are, as always, extremely beautiful

Cons (in order of impact from my perspective)
*  (Added later)  My new worst con is that the epilepsy warning lasts literally 30 seconds and you can't escape out of it.  You have to wait every time!!!
*  The change in battle mechanics is just too much for me.  Having a dedicated zone with no risk in your home sectors is no fun.
*  There is no sandbox game capability - it's all campaign only.
*  You can't trade energy from map to map, so I have +1000 energy in one map because it's special project is actually energy generation, and am starved in the next, but can't utilize my surplus.  (Edit:  You end up being able to very deep in the advancement chain)
*  Islands are in no way 5 times larger as was stated - they might be larger, but the buildable space is actually pretty small.
*  Zoom capability - you can't zoom out much and I feel too close to the map.
* Control-Number assignment doesn't work.  You can't assign 1 to your command ship which is actually quite disrupting.
* Other comments have mentioned the change in logistics, storage etc, and I actually prefer the old way.  Everything seems too dumbed down to me and it potentially removes game play hours.  I can see myself getting bored much more quickly since it already seems like a simplified (and disappointing) grind.

My hope is these things will be addressed in patches or free updates, but for now, I'd wait if I were you.

reviewText:
Wait for the 1st patch before you buy it if you believe a $70us game should be bug free.

Slow to start, as complexity increases I enjoyed it more - then the bugs: game breaking bugs that can't be fixed by loading a savegame (feature doesn't exist). At 1st I failed to see how a franchise at this level could in good conscience release such a product.

You know who is to blame though: us. We need to stop pre-purchasing these AAA games. I, for one, will no longer be doing it. These AAA developers are getting fat while they laugh and count our money and sit back while we debug their rushed out crap. |f I worked for blue byte - I'd be embarrased.

Regarding the gameplay: It's unfortunate but the rather than moving towards a City Builder RTS (which aside from the earlier Anno titles there are none other in the game market) the developer decided on the easier and less bold route - City Builder with a pseudo RTS minigame. I guess there is no need to stand alone in this market when you have a following - people will buy enough units apon pre-release and then on release day to cover initial development.

I was excited about getting to build monumental cites and then having the satisfaction of fighting to keep them. No longer, your creations are all strangely safe from the outside world in the future :)

There is no doubt that the visuals are top quality. So, if you like eye-candy and enjoy the build houses with roads, build industry to satisify, expand, repeat until no new exciting buildings are available cycle then buy the game. Indeed, if you are interested in placing esthetically pleasing things on the map with no other real challenges then the game is for you.

reviewText:
It is a very good game, interesting, fun to play and very rewarding. There are a few things that I don't completely like. In specific, it seems a simplified version of Anno 2070. In 2070, you need to set up productions on different islands building ships to trade and send stuff from one Island to another, organizing the route and so on, it is very detailed and
it requires a lot of planning and care to organize it. In 2205, most of the things are automated, and this detract, in my opinion, from the fun.

In 2070, if you don't satisfy the needs of your population up to a percentage, they simply move out and you lose the revenue. Here it doesn't seems so or it doesn't seems to have much negative effects.

The combat missions are... meh... Ok, they are not required, but still... they feel a bit like an addendum that was thrown in to spice up the game.

The Tundra was a bit of a letdown, mostly because I got in after finishing everything else, with almost 5 million in the bank and a positive balance. So I basically steamrolled over everything.

The Tundra, in my opinion, would have been nice just after the Arctic, because it adds a lot of complexity. The population is divided in 2 groups: there are the ecologist" that are equivalent to the Arctic's Preserver
date: and the Researchers that are the scientist. Also the population's needs are mostly the same. The trick is that they require canned food

reviewText: Huge fan of Anno 2070, so I was very excited about this game. Unfortunatly it's a massive disappointment. The strength of Anno was its ability to allow for great depth in gameplay that stemmed from enjoyable micromanagement, complex industries and resource management of scarce materials that forced the player to think strategicly. That central aspect of the game which fans loved has been ripped out and turned it into a bland balance sheet system that makes the game painfully simple. I do like the new enviroments and I was really hoping going to space would have been similar to going underwater in 2070, seamless and engaging, yet another disappointment. The game has been gutted of complexity, made simple and inviting to an audiance that normally wouldnt appreciate Anno, I felt the new direction was just a sell out, all at the expense of fans of the past games. This isnt a game you can sink 100's of hours into, after 5 I was bored and dont care to pick it up again. Big waste of money, its a horrible value

reviewText:
It's fun to play, and I don't regret buying it, but in comparison to previous Anno titles it's extremely simplified and misses a huge amount of content.

It all looks very pretty, but I don't see any replayability value in it.

I guess a good thing, and I don't believe I'm saying this, is that the FUPlay launcher seems to actually function now, even though you have to start it before starting the actual game from Steam. But it seems to behave now at least, whereas the old launcher could only be update on my machine in safe mode on a reboot...

To people wanting an Anno game? Get 2070 or one of the even earlier titles. For people loving Anno? Get this on sale. As it is, I wouldn't recommend it, even though I'm having fun playing it.

reviewText:
Dont waste your money. Besides the beautiful graphics, there is nothing really comparative to the previous Anno Titles. Its become a game for casual players who dont want to spend time with management. Its very easy to redo an island layout without restarting to maximize your income/resources.

The biggest hit for me, that I really wish I had now checked for, was the Skirmish/Multiplayer portion of the game. It has none.

I didnt know Anno had a new release coming out and the second I saw it hit steam I purchased it without hesitation. I was sad to see that they didnt follow the Anno 2070 model that had a Single Player Campaign that was more of a Global Event Single Player play that allowed new options for Multiplayer sessions.

The combat was not how I expected. I was thinking I would be able to play a MP game and build ships as I did and have exciting battles. Sadly this was not the case. While ship battles are fun... in singleplayer only it is pointless and only acts as a way to aquire resources that you cant get anywhere else other then quests.

All and all... If you are looking for a single player game to play a few hours a day and looks really good.. Go for it. ... but if you were hoping to play with friends.. dont bother.

reviewText: My friend and I were super hyped for this game. This excitement stemmed from playing Anno 2070 multiplayer. So I bought it day one and was quickly dissapointed. Anno 2205 is so lackluster for me because building was not entertaining, The battles were too frequent, and the lack of multiplayer. The building is too simple, You place a building down connect it to any road and now the whole sector has the resources. One thing i really enjoyed about 2070 was finding optimal ways to place different buildings, or maiking sure you have enough depots to manage transportation based on physical units. In this game, you build this building that helps transportation by placing it on the island. To improve efficientcy of these buildings , you plop upgrades  connecting to the building based on materials that as far as I know, you cannot produce.  That brings me to the next issue, The fights. At first they were really fun with the missile barrage recking havack, The cool EMP, and the support submarines. However, Each mission drags on forever if you want to get all the materials and do the AI missions. This would not be so bad if the AI didn't constantly ask for your help every 3 seconds. In the 4 hours i played this game, I spent the majority of the time fighting Moon rebel jerkface. The battles become boring really fast despite multiple maps because of how they drag on and on. Finally, the Lack of multiplayer was the final nail in the coffin. My friend and I bought the game solely for playing together. We were playing singleplayer because there really isn't a main menu when he asked me how we played multiplayer. I didn't know because the Popular user tags are Strategy, City Builder, Simulation, and Futuristic. Yes, it does say Single-player next to ubisoft DRM warning, but I missed it. Sue me. Anyways, My friend and I quickly got refunds because we would not deal with this dissapointing experience without multiplayer.

reviewText:
After spending the majority of the weekend with Anno 2205 and playing through the main campaign, I can say that what's here is a promising framework to be built upon.  If you're going into it expecting a sequel to 2070, you're going to be disappointed due to the number of things left out or streamlined in such a way as to lower the barrier of entry.

While I initially liked the logistics trucks concept, after 5 minutes of going back to 2070 this afternoon, I realized that it was far too simplified.  As were the mechanics of always knowing exactly whether supply was trending upward or down or knowing that an island had finite (read: specific) resources, forcing expansion to grow.

The combat missions have potential but are tedious and overly simplified.  Plus there only seems to be a couple of maps for the two conflict zones.

Some of these things can be improved upon through DLC but they should be included from the start.  Continuous play as well as careful resource management is the bedrock of this series.  2205 doesn't live up to that legacy at this point.

The software itself is buggy (it has crashed a couple of times) and is a serious resource hog.  In late game, my machine slowed to a crawl so be advised if you're running on slightly older hardware.

There's potential here but I would definitely wait for some patches and/or a sale.

reviewText:
I waited to pick this one up until it went on sale, due to the mixed reviews, and wish I hadn't - I am really liking the game so far. It is different in a lot of ways from previous ANNO titles , but overall I think they have done a good job updating the series.

I especially love being able to move buildings (watch out some can be ridiculously expensive to relocate!), and the various addons that you can customize for them. Game looks amazing, and being able to now jump between your different settlements is another welcome addition.

I definitely have not found the game to be too easy, I've only recently reached around lvl 12 and started the moon base and it is already challenging keeping all of my sectors in balance while bringing in enough income to fund the steps needed for the main progression!

The side quests can be a bit generic and repetitive, but do offer a good way to supplement your income or get those last few rare resources you need. A lot of players did not like that all combat was moved to a separate part of the game, but I don't mind so much. Having these 2 parts separate lets you concentrate fully on one or the other without having to stop in the middle of what you were doing to address whatever event/crisis pops up. Just make sure you have a positive income flow before starting the combat missions - your settlements still run in real time while youre fighting!

If you like strategy, city building, or any of the previous ANNO titles, give this one a try - you can always refund if you hate it, right?

reviewText:
The majority may dislike this game, especially the Anno purists, but I've found myself enjoying it.  2070 was the gold standard for me and though 2205 is a vast departure from that design it isn't as bad as many claim it to be.  I agree that the game is a little too simplistic and could be fleshed out in a few ways to offer more depth.  There are what I would consider to be some missed opportunities.  But when I combine the good and the bad, I still come away wanting to recommend it.  If I were to assign a percentage, I'd say 60% of me likes it while 40% of me is left scratching my head over some of the shallow design decisions.

Here are a few positive bullet points...

- The game is beautiful.  Even on my GTX 760, the game runs very well.
- Setting up the balance of goods and trade routes is actually pretty enjoyable.  That being said, this is pretty much the centerpiece of the game.  This is all you need to do, but that task has a lot of sub-tasks.
- As simplistic as the game is, I can't seem to get enough of it.  That may change and I often question the replayability, but so far I'm having a good time.
- While I am not blown away by the storylines in each sector, I do enjoy the overarching questline to achieve something.  This also adds to the balance difficulty as I'm expanding.  If I need to increase a specific commodity (it's usually something really expensive to produce), I've had to be pretty careful in that venture as to not begin hemorrhaging cash.  I lost my first game as I was powering through the content and quests.  Before I knew it, I was in the red and couldn't figure out where things went wrong.  2205 will surprise you if you aren't careful.
- As you upgrade your buildings, the challenge to meet the needs of the new demographic presents itself prominently.  This is where you can really screw yourself over if you aren't careful.

Here are my reservations about the game...

- The mini-quests in each area are a waste of time.  Once you've done about 5-6 of the variations, it's a repetitive and mundane task to do the quests unless you need the reward.
- There is a distinct lack of depth on the resource side.  You create specific resources in specific regions.  No pre-req required, just jump right in.  For me, I missed the challenge of obtaining the correct fertility and building an island around the production of that resource.
- Also on the resource side, when you build the buildings, the resources are immediately available. There's no delay to allow production to ramp up and give you the feeling that there are some logistical challenges in opening a new factory/farm etc...small detail, but it was strange at first.
- Combat is separate from your region builds.  I'm not sure I understand this design decision, to be honest...If it weren't for the pestering of the NPCs to do my combat missions or the fact that I'd end up low on a rare resource, I'd probably never do them. When I do complete the missions, it's not a very robust system.  I hold down my + key a lot to speed things up and even if I lose a few ships, completing it on Expert difficulty isn't insurmountable.

It's not a BAD game by any means.
Did it fall short?  Most certainly.  The side quests and combat are questionable.
Will you still enjoy it?  I believe you will if you give it a chance. Start building up your moon colonies and you'll see what I mean.

UPDATE:  I'm still playing this game.  I really feel that anyone passing on this game will be missing out.  What's amusing is that I think I make the majority of my rare" materials from the Anno 2205 Asteroid Miner smartphone game.  I haven't had to do a military mission since I posted this review.  One day
date: you'll buy his game and agree with me.  Whether it's now or when it's on sale for 5 dollars in 3 years..\nI'm very much looking forward to Wildwater Bay!"

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews, but I spent countless hours both playing and watching streams of Anno 2070 and wanted to give my first impressions. I found this game to be simplified, but not in a way that was unpleasant. For example, there is a new window which tells you how much you are consuming and producing of each good; this makes it so much easier to balance production chains. Additionally, the move tool is awesome given that I like to rebuild things.

Overall, based on my 4 hours in the campaign, I would recommend this, especially if you are on the fence because it is published by Ubisoft. BlueByte did an excellent job with this game and I am enjoying it so far. It's both simpl er and more complex than 2070 (haven't played the other games, so can't comment on that). Running one city is pretty easy, but moving up the chain and expanding to having multiple cities is a more interesting thing. Definitely worth a look at least and I am excited to see what else they do in the future.

Things that are different:
1) Multiple theaters" in the form of Temperate

Then I moved my existing farms and factories to something that both worked and was visually pleasing without a massive loss of resources. Coupled with a central storage of goods in each theater

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=urge6q5hfUk

It's not your father's Anno 2205... and that will ♥♥♥♥ a lot of people off.  Taken away from the serious is a lot of the user unfriendly elements.  Gone are the days of using tables, calculators and chains.  The game is now built in such a way that it will show you exactly how much you need to balance everything off.  It's just a matter of doing it yourself.

Gone are the days of hitting Tier 3 only for all of the AI players to immediately declare war and usurp you with giant barrages of ships.  Now all of the fighting is done on separate combat maps that require little to no investment from your colonies.

Instead you get a game that feels kind of flat by comparison.  But it is also a very very different game than the rest.

You will have three different types of zones (regular, arctic, and moon) in which each place will have resources that the other needs.  Added to the game is a new resource of workers that means you need to maintain actual populations in order to work in buildings.  These buildings will produce all of the resources you need.

There is no more building ships in the game.  Instead you have to choose between three crafts for each trade route of increasing size and organize your routes from here.

Also gone from the game are items and the ARK.  This is a very large hit on the game.  However it also makes the game balance more likable.  Without requiring to have 30% speed on all transport ships they will just have that 30% from the start.

The game has simply become one of managing various resources, populations and needs.  It's not a terrible game, but it is most certainly a very different game that will scare away any of the faithful who enjoyed the Anno series.

It is most certainly not Anno and probably should have not been named as such.

reviewText:
For the average gamer who likes city builders?  Its not worth the price, wait for it to go on sale.

For the Anno fan?  If your bored and have expendable income, buy it.  If not, wait.  Your call.  Heres the facts.

- No multiplayer.  No continous mode.  The campaign is very similar to continous mode except a plot you don't care about is forced upon you.

- No military.  A HORRIBLE mini game exsists in its place with many of the ships recycled from 2070.

- New storage system.  Building materials work like always.  Consumer goods work like electricty in 2070.  Its not bad.  I like it except...

- Some building materials cannot be mined/crafted.  They are only available by a) cash b) mind-numbing quests c) horrible military mini game.  THIS is the worst part of the game.  Essentially think of any previous anno games farming system.  You set the farm and then you set the fields.  In Anno 2205 you are forced to jerk off NPCs before you can set your fields.

reviewText:
TL:DR: An over simplified game designed for millenials to satisfy their need for pampering and false achievements. Seasoned gamers STAY AWAY. Check the last part for after 30+ play review.

As a seasoned Anno player I must say this game feels like a massive disappointment, the whole depth and substance of the game has been taken away. It's now a childrens playtime game, no real resource management, no real challenge, not even an interesting story line. It's just massive amounts of great graphics and that's it, nothing more.

It is so obvious this is another game made for not-so intelligent yet massively pampered and lousy millenial kids, you do trivial stuff and you get levels bonuses praises and crap, while there's not a real game going on, this game can be played after a real game as you let your mind to ease and eat dinner in front of the screen. It's that easy and crappy. THEY KILLED ANNO. Skip this one.

Let me summarize:

PROS:
+ Easy interface
+ Great graphics

CONS:
- No real strategy
- Not much of a resource management
- No real challenge
- No storyline

----------------------------------
At this point I tried to give the game a second chance since I gave so much money to this damn game and forced myself into its system, turns out they actually put some sort of resource management scheme, in the old games you'd manage the resources in between the islands of a single map, in this game you have to do it in between maps which means you have to wait for loadings and transition effects each time you visit a map location, they space bit is nice but not detailed, the other corporations dont even challenge you, the graphics engine is not optimized to you get damn frame rate falls, what else is out there ? What a bummer.

reviewText:
25+ hours in building massive cities and hit the 6 digit negative somehow
The new anno is fun to play and more streamlined into a resource management game. They got rid of some of the original concepts which was really good and replaced it with new ones. The game however lacks a bit more substance to it as if this is just a base game for things to come. With hopefully dlc or expansion to fix it up and create more depth to the game it is unfortunate that the core version did not offer much much more. I do however recommend it as worth being played.
Some may love this game, and some hardcore veterans of 2070 looking for more depth and  the same game will most likely hate it. It has its good point but also letdowns. Hold off on it a bit for the dlcs to kick in unfortunately.

Pros+ The graphics in this is aesthetically pleasing. Great to watch the people and the day and night cycle (Which is optional and can be turned on bottom right)
+ Sleak, clean interface that is easy to learn and use
+ Music never fails to impress in the anno series
+ Open ended campaign system so that you can build and do whatever else you like
+ Modular buildings, easy to build/move buildings, combat in seperate zone, and strategized resource locations for some factories (can be a hit or miss for some)
+ High density building content can prove a challenge you think its easy till you try to upgrade everything
+ Multiple ways to earn rare resources t (Trading, mission/quests, and combat)
+ Build and manage cities in 3 different areas at the same time or focus on one, from temperate climate, artic, and lunar. Still your choice on what you want to focus on
+ Alot of new features that fixes hectic hassles I had in 2070, The ability to move buildings is one so that I don't take down an entire area to build statues.
+ Each areas of the world requires different strategy for settlement placement i.e placing near factories to stay warm in the artics, having to build under shield generators on moon to avoid space debris
+ Hopeful for additional content and release for the game to make it much better than it is which is a base game atm


Cons - They took out alot of the management system from the original that added depth to the game
- Not as much depth and content as I expected after reaching end game, only thing to do is build high density and balance it out to work which is the challenge will be fun for a while. There needs to be more challenges
- The combat system is arcadey and feels like it was just thrown in for the sake of it. I am glad however that it is optional
- The rare resources are not so rare at all, there are 3 ways to earn them and it is really easy. too easy for rare
- Needs more map randomization to add replayability
- Multiplayer is gone unfortunately, but sometimes that is a good thing.
- Needs more content

Review Video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3safqsJjFaA&feature=youtu.be

reviewText:
Not a huge Anno fan, but I did enjoy 2070.  I wasn't the best at it either, failing many cities but I still kept coming back for the challenge, and to try new things out and go with different themes.  This installment, however, seems devoid of any challenge and variety at all.  Maps are pre-determined and don't change, but they are very prety, especially the arctic and moon.  There's only one 'faction', your own.  You can slightly customize it by naming it and picking a logo, but it will always look the same in the game world.

Combat is pretty stale too, as it is shoehorned in with battle arenas that are forced with each stage of your space program.  Take your fleet, navigate the given arena, kill ships, and loot things in the water to call in artillary or EMP.  I miss having all the factions present on the map and having to defend my settlements when the time came.  That aspect is no longer present.  On top of it, it all feels incredibly linear as to your settlement's direction.  There's no harbor design, many buildings go where the slot on the map is, and goods and storage are so streamlined the game basically plays itself.

The game is fun, but very very stale in the complexity department and I feel I won't return for a new game after one is completed, because the experience will largely be the same events in the same order.  I want to enjoy this game, and the theme is amazing, and it's gorgeous to look at, but there's no substance here, not for $60 at least.  Wait till it gets cheaper, or maybe changes with patches or DLC.

reviewText: Anno 2205 is definitely different from the previous entries in the series. Whereas 2070 was essentially 1404 but with different assets and a few new mechanics, 2205 makes some big and bold changes - but most are for the better. If all you want is another 1404 or 2070 you might not be happy with 2205.\n\nPerhaps the biggest and best change is the removal of combat (save for self-contained generic missions) from the building and management sections. Instead, combat has been compartmentalized and moved to separate maps that you complete for upgrade materials. It's not a perfect system, as the combat has little depth and isn't very strategic, but it can be a nice change of pace and lets you build capital while being somewhat productive. Not just the combat is removed, there is no competition from AI players. There's no urgency to settle islands to avoid being locked out from resources as once you settle in a region, it's yours
date:
including any and all islands (though you don't get access to them all right away). Wether this detracts from the experience varies from player to player. Personally I prefer the relaxing building simulator, but some might miss the competition.

Gone are a lot of tedious and needlessly time-consuming mechanics from the old games, where you sat around and waited for resources to tick in and population to rise so you could ascend dwellings. Instead, you get instant access to any information you need regarding production and consumption, letting you focus on what the games have always been about: efficiency. There is always something you can do to improve revenue flow, citizen numbers or space usage.

It might sound like the game has been simplified, but in reality it has just been streamlined and sped up. It's still plenty complicated once you unlock and get far enough in the different types of regions, and making big sweeping changes require careful planning and preparation to avoid plummeting production and income.

The game isn't without flaws, of course. While there is a lot to do in the game, there isn't that much replay value. Once you've completed" the game
recommended: that's it. Unless you wanna start again on a higher difficulty or with a more efficient building/expansion plan
hoursPlayed: there is little else for you to see.\n\nI'm still not done with the game and I believe I have gotten plenty more than my money's worth from it
voteText: but I don't believe I will be playing it for years like I did with 1404. Still
helpfulPercent: well worth the purchase."

reviewText:
First of all, make sure the reviews you base your decision to purchase on are from people that have played the game for more than a few hours, the game ramps up drastically in difficulty after a few hours and again after a few more. Also, for the true Anno experience, you should be playing on Expert, which will erase your save if you have a negative balance for more than 30 minutes. I found the other modes much too easy and restarted twice.

The game is gorgeous, I have an older machine with an i7 850, GeForce 550Ti and 8 gigs of RAM and I am able to play on Medium settings and get around 20 FPS. It's not buttery-smooth at 60 FPS or anything but it's definitely passable on a very old machine. The graphics are nothing short of stunning.

The game appears to be 'dumbed down' at the outset, but wht you'll actually find are quality of life improvements. All items are stored in one central location, you can tell how much or little you have of something, and what the balance is of that item in that sector with a simple mousever. No more monitoring individual storehouses to make sure you're not over or under distrbuting goods. You won't have to micromanage shipping routes, either- it's all been streamlined.

The addition of the World Market allows you to buy and sell resources to the rest of the Anno community. I challenged myself to not use it but eventually there are items that (for now, anyway) just make more sense to import.

Combat is completely optional, as is the associated app- but they do make the main missions a lot easier.

My main advice is to take your time, grow slow- and enjoy!

After reading the many negative reviews from people who played it for less than an hour -- some were even from people who played for 30 minutes -- then reading the reasons for the negativity, I just want to warn you guys about the accuracy of some of the claims. I already know a lot of the bad reviews would solely be over the fact that you have to use uplay. Lo and behold, I got it right.

--First, I want to say, give the game about 5 hours of gameplay. That's about how long it takes to really feel the game as a whole and see what it can bring and if you like what it's bringing--

I'm going to talk about the game first. When I just started, I felt like the game was a bit fast" in terms of progression and I was breezing through it. I wasn't forced to micromanage right away like the older annos. Now am I saying that the game is easy like the others claim it to be? No

hoursPlayed: I think they designed it this way so that you can reach the point of the game where you now have to be aware of your resources and if leveling up your people into higher tier shiny buildings can cause you to not have adequate resources for your regions/cities. It pretty much wants you to get to the meat of the game fast. But once you get to that point

reviewText:
Anno 1404 was a magical game. The setting was perfect for me. I love history, and that game scratched every itch I had. Everything made sense: Of course your pioneers needed fish. Of course they needed meat, coffee, wine and tools. The production chains made sense, I understood them. You need cows to produce meat. You need iron and wood to produce tools.

That is why Anno 2070 did not manage to suck me into it. That is one of the reasons Anno 2205 fails. Do you need nano ceramics and cobalt to produce construct-o-bots? I have no idea.

What I truly loved about the previous Anno games was this:

If you had joined a game after 20 hours, everything would seem like complete chaos. Fleets of ships going in all directions carrying tons of different goods to a dozen islands. But for the player, every little thing made sense. Because they had built everything from scratch. Every boat, every building, everything. That was the real beauty of it. The best learning curve I have ever witnessed in a game.

It was challenging. You had to keep trying getting the perfect balance in your production chains. You had the option to taxate the population and selling surplus goods. You had to fight for the best islands.

Now, they have stripped most of it out. Every warehouse is in prebuilt locations. The ships are just generated, making no sense. You cannot set taxes, you dont need to fix production chains as they tell you exactly what you need to do, and you cannot sell goods! So what do you do when you are low on cash? Its quite simple, actually: You just leave the game with a positive income, and let time take care of it.

That was the point when I realised how poor this game was: When I could leave the game on for several hours, and when I opened it again, the ONLY thing that had happened was a big bank account. In Anno 1404, that would have been a suicide. Pirates would attack. Other players would steal the best islands, they would invade you. The production chain was guaranteed to be a little off-balance, so after some hours your citizens would have left your town. Because they would run out of bread, meat and books. And I understood them. I would leave too.

Would I leave due to a lack of neuro implants? I dont know. Probably not.

This is not strategy, its barely administration. Bring back the excellent gameplay of 1404, and make a Anno 1800 or 720bc. Until then, I will keep beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of Leif Jorgensen.

PS: If you havent played Anno 1404, do it. Its the pinnacle of the series in my opinion, and it has aged quite well.

reviewText:
Excellent update to the Anno series.  Streamlines a few systems, namely trade between sectors, logistics within sector, and how combat is handled, but that doesn't mean they are simple or dumbed down.  The ability to move structures around is a nice addition, you don't have to wory about screwing yourself with a poor layout early on since you can just rearrange it later.  The temperate, space, and arctic/tundra ecosystem all play uniquely and emphasize different aspects of the game.

You're got to give it 10 or so hours before you really hit the complexity that Anno is known for.  Each of the first three initial sectors is like a big tutorial for the game and once you complete all three (the Lunar Licensing Program in-game), you are turned loose to go around and complete the other sector projects.  This is where the free-form style of game that feels more like traditional Anno begins.  I imagine a lot of the negative reviews that complain about lack of complexity or short length either never got this far, or were simply expecting some other than what they got.

It took me about 45 hours to complete all of the sector projects (including the Tundra dlc), which is the meat of the game.  This game definietly continues what Anno 2070 started, so if you didn't like 2070, you probably won't like this.

There is currently no multiplayer, which may or may not bother you.

Like any game, this has some bumps, but that wouldn't stop me from whole-heartedly recommending it!

reviewText:
Would I recommend the game? Depends on whom I'm talking to. I'm assuming you're reading this as someone who has played the game a lot, because you're a fan reading your trillionth Steam review to try and work out if you'll like the game. I can 100% assure you that I enjoy this game to a very very mild degree. It's not much of a step up beyond what was already happening in the Anno series, so for someone new, it might be a fun little game. For someone familiar with the series, it might be a bit disappointing. That said, I've played a bunch of the old Anno games, and I haven't found myself moving on from it yet.

Some mildly interesting things to affect your mild decision to mildly purchase this game:

1) It provides a colony-to-colony transfer system that meant I had to manage the different resources from each of the biomes in a cross-planet trade network, which was simple, yet delicate.
2) If you were like me, and you really want to like this game, chances are you'll enjoy it, provided you don't feel like it's a big expense.
3) You don't get to your moon base for a while, so don't expect it to be there at the start
4) the various in-colony optional missions are kind of boring and arduous. Just a bunch of fetch quests to justify a plane or boat model on the map.
5) the military campaign missions are also kind of boring, but in a different way. It's just bland to wander around the map with your full armada of ships and either be at an adequate level, and thus just breeze past most things, or to be insufficient, in which case your units will atrophy away before you can finish the level. That said, if they were difficult, I probably wouldn't bother playing them, as they're not that important for the main game.

reviewText:
update for Tundra:
-changed recommended to thumbs down.

I wasted money 2 times on steam (60€ each). First was Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II. Second was definitely ANNO 2205.

Abandon SHIP!

old review:
CANT PLACE TREES!  MY METROPOLIS IS RUINED!!!
(spent thousands of hours on ANNO series since 1602)

IMPRESSIONS AFTER 20 HOURS

First off, Uplay works fine.

Secondly, game needs content. ALOT of content. And a patch. ALOT of patches. Interface update specifically,new production buildings, more employee levels for lunar and arctic bases. Some kind of random element to maps. More sectors. Fix for the memory leak. Overhaul of the arbitrary quests system. (rare materials are practically worthless bcoz military missions yield u half a stack -> always capped). Again, the interface!, it's been so dumbed down you practically dont get any info at all! Feels like a console game at times. Voice acting for major characters is disastrous, overall sound and ambience is top notch. No more scientific research? That used to be fun! Theres no incentive to continue playing after completing main objectives. I don't feel pressured or challenged anymore. I can just sit on my millions and look at the scenery. No-one is competing against me.

Game deserves 7/10 rating as of now. has GREAT potential though, and i'm under the impression it was designed with numerous expansions in mind. SO KEEP THEM ROLLING.

Still think its worth 60€ for an ANNOholic. Otherwise, wait for a sale or google a better deal. And/or wait for them expansions.

AFTER 50 HOURS

OCD is stronk with this one. Pretty much nothing else. Boring. All the same. No content, no challenge. Persistent annoying quests, crappy voice acting and bugs. Well. It certainly feels more like a beta version than a game we were supposed to sink thousands of hours" in. If youre a lil hardcore ure pretty much done in 20h with EVERYTHING game has to offer
date: literally. No replay value whatsoever. (you can rush thru the game in 3h btw
recommended:
including 30 module HQ)


TL;DR: Honorable failure. Nice try. Decent "beta". Now give us the real deal please!"

reviewText:
UPDATED REVIEW.

Recommendation: YES, but at a lower price due to replayability concerns.
(Changed from NO from previous DAY ONE review)

First of all, thanks to all the commenters... You've really amazing people. ;)

Anyway, short form: Not quite the Anno you know. A lot of the core aspects are present: resource and production chain management, income balancing through satisfying population needs, laying out roads and your city, and the complexity of not having all resources at one location. Caveat is that the scale of the game has become a bit grander that it takes time to manage your chains because instead of managing different islands you now manage different maps you have to jump in and out of. The maps are limited in selection, and without multiplayer replayability is pretty low.

Is this an Anno game? Yes, in it's own way.

Long form...

The story is also you guide to winning" the game and also your basic tutorial. Playing the game for the first time
date: you will be thankful how the story progresses and asks you to do tasks sequentially based on what kind of resource chain should go up next. If you already know what you're doing
recommended: you can safely ignore the story content and it will actually automatically progress as you build your chains on your own. One quirk is that you may get intrrupted by the story as it automatically progresses along with you.\n\nResource collection and production chains remains pretty much the same
hoursPlayed: except you no longer directly deal with invetory counts. Yes

column20: instead of maybe a a ship that can be filled in with goods of different kinds for a cheaper transport. Oh

column34: and the Crisis map. The first three are your build your city and production chain maps

reviewText:
Anno 2205 presents a radical departure from the previous games, and it will probably displease a LOT of Anno fans. I myself was a little disappointed by how streamlined the game is at first, but I kept playing and the new puzzle aspect that the game flaunts grew on me. This game does NOT replace Anno 2070, just like Anno 2070 did not replace Anno 1404, and I firmly believe that all 3 games can coexist perfectly fine.
Other than that: didn't notice any particular bugs, the optimisation needs work, the military missions are cute but frankly, no multiplayer sucks and no sandbox really sucks.

I'll recommend this game and I'll give it a 7/10 speaking as an Anno games fan, and 8/10 as a simulation games fan.

Looking forward to the updates, DLC and expansions to turn this good game into a great game.
voteText: 23 of 48 people (48%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
So, a quick recap:

- No Multiplayer.
- No factions.
- No trade.
- No customizable map mode.
- No storage (it's a resource flow now).
- No non-renewable resources.
- No placeable sub-systems (as in farms and such).

Basically, this game is as much Anno as Inquisition is a Dragon Age game.

Even if this is your first Anno game (they've clearly tried to reach a broader audience), I can't really see how this can compel you.

Whoever made the decisions to remove - yes, remove, because I'm pretty sure they recycled - the aforementioned missing features: congratulations! You killed it! Honestly, all you had to do was KEEP the old code, tweak a few mechanics, add two or three new features, and that's it. I mean, that's exactly what your publishers do with the Assassin's Creed franchise, and it seems to work.

Edit: Forgot to mention there's no trade.

NO MULTIPLAYER
NO CONTINUES PLAY
COMPAIGN ONLY
