reviewText:
I'm writing two versions for the review - if you are new to Anno, keep reading, if you are not new to it, scroll down a little. Or read them all, whichever you prefer.

If you are new to the Anno seriesAnno games are more of a tycoon game; an economy simulator rather than a city builder. So if you are expecting a city builder to kill your time with, Anno isn't for you, and I recommend checking Cities: Skylines instead. But if you are still reading, that means you are interested and I'll do my best to help you decide.

There is no multiplayer. However, that shouldn't be a deciding factor for your purchase, not for this game at least. Multiplayer has never been a strong point of the series. Anno 2070 features co-op in addition to competetive mode, maybe 5% of my total playtime is in co-op multiplayer. However I gave up on it as you cannot speed the game up in multiplayer. The bread and butter of any Anno game is continuous play; which is intertwined to the base campaign now, and I like it quite a lot.

Game focuses around building a population, and supplying them with their needs. As they get satisfied, you'll have an opportunity to upgrade their residences, which opens new building options, and unlocks new production chains. Production chains get very complex as you progress, and requires several buildings to keep the efficiency at 100%. You have a nice little panel which tells you exactly how much you are producing and consuming (or sending/trading).

There are 3 types of environment; lush, arctic, and lunar. Lush is maybe the easiest, with no additional mechanics. Arctic and lunar has different mechanics. Arctic for example, residences can only be built around a heat source - your production buildings so to speak. This makes Arctic map different from Lush, a lot. Every environment has their own set of buildings, and in order to proceed in the game, you'll have to transfer resources between your regions. It's very easy to set those routes up though. You'll swap between these regions, and play every map at the same time so to speak. credit income from one map affects you globally - only resources are localized.

There are 9 maps as far as I can tell, and you start on one lush, then grab an arctic, and then grab a lunar region. You can purchase the other regions though. Every one of them looks gorgeous, and I didn't really miss a random map generator - because as I've said before, bread and butter of Anno games is continuous play, and when you start a game, you'll keep playing it. Being able to also play on 8 different maps - that's even more butter for the bread so to speak.

Aside from the resources, there are 4 things that you need to manage; power, workforce, logistics, and credit balance. At first it may seem easy to do so, however as your city grows, the distance to your warehouse increases, and production buildings will have higher logistics requirement. Soon, you'll have to build transport depots to increase your logistics capability; however these depots require power and maintenance of them is rather high. After a while you may find yourself in situations where you are trying to get a balance between power, logistics and maintenance. Aside from these, there are special, rare materials which you get by doing mini-missions and combat missions.

Mini-missions are non-mandatory, optional stuff that you can do in order to get more of the rare materials. Combat is on separate maps, so you don't have to worry about them if that's not your thing. However, I found myself quite enjoying the combat maps from time to time. You have a separate military ranking, and as you gain levels, your fleets gets bigger & better. Each map has one primary goal, and up to three secondary goals, and you get a lot of power-ups & pick-ups on your way to deal with the threats in the mission. Your rewards are rare materials which you require in order to upgrade your buildings - and these upgrades are very powerful.

Graphics are very nice, however I feel that the game could use more optimization. I also feel that there may be a memory leak, as after 2+ hours of playtime, the framerate starts going down. I have an average PC, and usually sit around 40-60 FPS on medium settings, but it starts dipping down after a while. Music is as always, very good. Relaxing, soothing. The UI could use some help though - I'm not sure if I can - but being able to pin some stuff on the screen would eliminate a few mouse clicks.

Overall, I highly recommend this game if you like economy simulators / tycoon games, with a little touch of city building. If you are interested, but would like to wait for a sale, it is understandable, it's not a cheap game afterall, You may want to check Anno 2070 meanwhile, however this game has big differences to Anno 2070, just keep that in mind. Have a nice day!

If you are NOT new to the Anno seriesI see a lot of reviews, comments, and discussions saying that this game is dumbed-down, and is easy. I beg the differ. All the changes I've seen are primarily aimed to please the people who enjoy continuous play a lot. I'm someone who plays Anno just because of the continuous play, and I'll take Anno 2070 as a base while trying to explain the changes.

No multiplayer - I believe it was the most underused feature of Anno 2070, and that's why they got rid of it. Anno has never been a good RTS either. It was the right decision in my opinion. I tried to play it, but I gave up on it as you cannot increase the game speed in multiplayer (naturally) - and at most 5% of my playtime is in multiplayer.

No storages/warehouses - To me, primary aim of these two buildings was to provide logistics drones to your facilities. Now, we have something called Logistics, and it makes the game harder actually. There is a building that increases your logistics capacity, but it doesn't come cheap. And as the distance to your warehouse / depot increases, the logistics maintenance also increases, so you cannot just put cheap storages everywhere to cover the map and then build as you like. There are no aerial drones to make your job easy either.

No random maps - I am STILL playing the very same map that I've started months ago in my continous play in Anno 2070. To be honest, looking at the same thing for a rather long while gets a bit boring. In 2205, the main campaign is actually a beefed up continuous play, and you can swap between your maps with a short loading time. You can establish routes between your regions - as opposed to establishing routes between your islands, to develop them even further. What I'm trying to say is, now at least I get to look at 3 (9) different maps, the main difference is that we all will be looking at the same maps. But personally I'm fine with it, since they are hand-crafted, they are gorgeous to look at.

Infinite resources - Well, Anno 2070 also had infinite resources. You either researched or traded special warehouse modules, and applied those on an island to regain some resources. It was tiresome in continuous play, checking every trader, doing research, etc... and doing this for every island that you owned, and every resource that you needed... Now it's infinite, and I'm glad they've changed it. It was one of the most irritating aspects of previous Anno titles.

No factions - No, there are factions. It's not what we had before though. As the game has 3 different environments, you also get to play 3 different factions in essence. Arctic for example, you can only build residences with access to a head source - a production building so to speak. That alone makes arctic play out differently than what you've got used to before. Not to mention that every faction" has different production lines.

What do you enjoy the most
date: in an Anno game? Continuous play? Then this is the game for you. All of  the changes are to make continuous play even more enjoyable. I can keep going and explain more but character li"

reviewText:
I feel like a minority when giving a positive review, I think other people are being to irrational on the gameplay experience. It doesn't play like the previous annos but for me thats not a bad thing, I like what they have done here, it's refreshing.

The pros:
-Amazing aesthetically, the graphics are really nice, the character models/animations and even voice acting is much more improved.

-Regions of settlements - this is really refreshing and nice to build up and start fresh with new visual styles, new conditions depending on the climate in that area and trading depedancies between regions really give them personality (Artic region costs a bomb but is essential for other regions to develop).

-The campaign flows much better, in previous annos you would have mission that you would load in and out of to complete objectives, this anno feels much more seemless, a persistant long term goal that lasts throughout the game.

-The combat - in previous annos it never felt like a core pillar of the game, while still being completely optional this one it treats it as a seperate experience, which does infact remove from the risk of getting your hard built settlement blown up (I kinda liked that in the old ones), but it does mean that they got to focus on the combat elements in a completely fresh way that actually makes it more engaging. You have a ships that you can unlock via leveling up your corp level (through population and other bits and bobs), you earn experience via doing the combat missions and this experience can level up your boats, each boat has a key role to play which brings quite a bit of interesting strategy to the table, on top of that you now have abilities which you can use to call in reinforcements, nuke, stun, repair, shield and send out a wave to push the enemy back. Overall this is much better than previous annos as you won't need to wait until the 20 hour+ mark before you have any fun with the military side of things.

-Modules on factories are quite refreshing, allowing you to customise your settlements focus, it means I don't have to keep spamming tea farms down and finding much more real estate for additional buildings, if you are negative in a particular resource, find the building and simply place a production module to tip you over the edge back into positive readings.

The cons:
-No multiplayer, I think people have expressed this enough already that this was a weird design choice when the previous annos where so popular for it (It increased the longevity of the game considerably).

-Not enough information is easily exposed, in previous annos you had how much of each resource displayed in your depots, in this one you simply have a positive of negative number and as long as you keep it at 0 or above, then everything is gravy.

-Everything feels a bit too simple in regards to raw RTS traits, they have removed the hard numbers in areas and streamlined it so you know exactly what to do and when, although this isn't really a con, compared to old anno games it can make it feel 'dumbed down' saying that I kind of prefer it in someways as it means I can focus on getting that space elevator up and progress with a lot more flow.

-Slots, this one is mentioned a lot by other reviewers but my opinion of them is quite indiferent, in anno 2070 you had slots for mines, slots for river modules and slots for dams, in this one they have extended it to bridges (Which are large), to your depot that settles on new island and to structures that would work similar to fishing ports... I don't really get how this makes for a negative experience other than restricting customisation in regards to building (Which doesn't account for much with these few structures).

Overall, maybe give it some time and see what blue byte does with future patches/DLC, if you are looking for a traditional anno game then this may disappoint you, but if you are looking for a casual city builder with combat elements to distract you then this one will keep you entertained for 30hours +

reviewText:
+ The game itself is very beautiful. Run on a single GTX 980 full ultra, with a average between 45-60 fps, depends on the density.

+ The musics also are nice.

Sadly that's the only great points.

- What's the point to playing a game without multiplayer (or even coop) and all the long you are assisted by a guide. There is no difficulty. I felt like i was playing the last SimCity in solo mode.

- The maps are smaller than in Anno 2070 because there's no underwater. Instead, we have the moon and the arctic zone in a separately map. By the way, they told there will be no loadings. You must click two times on a map. First time to load the map, and second time to enter the map.

- The story is useless for a game like that.

- No diplomatie.

- Without the manual save, we can't go back. So if you are not sure by testing some projects for your city and you want to go back, that's impossible.


Because of this simplicity, there's no motivation and no initiative during the whole game. I can't recommend you this game for that prize...

reviewText:
Gonna slap a solid 4.5 out of 5 stars on this. Overall its a fun and streamlined experience for the series, the modular buildings are great, as is the large interconnected system of zones you can build on. I like the new take on how the continuous game will carry on after the main campaign is over.

I am a fan of the combat changes, and the fact that they are optional! Graphics are top notch, the 3 zones (temperate, arctic, moon) you can build in are all unique in their own ways, and mix up the game play. Also its wonderful to be able to move buildings around and fix the accidental misplacement of something.

Some people do miss multiplayer, I am not one who ever bothered, but I can understand why people are upset over it being removed. I hope for more scenarios and a map creator in the future.

reviewText:
TL:DR:
First of all, I recommend this game, but barely. I personally give it 5/10 points, if you don't love building games and anno specifically, just drop it. Or read the review below and make your own score based on that.

This is, because I enjoyed it more than Anno 2070. Still, earlier games (starting with 1602 even) are all better in my opinion.
The game HAS some good potential and is fairly enjoyable on the first biome. Even the tacked on combat is fairly ok the first few tries. (but not on the long run)
The combat gets VERY repetetive on the limited maps and objective types. You just don't really have any fun after you beat all maps at least once or twice, than it gets tedious. It is fully optional though, so just let us leave that be.
In the game you have quests. Some are ok (like in Anno 2070, time wasters), but in most cases you have to repeat same stuff all over again - tow ships, tow drones, find some ridiculously small items on the map and click it (outrage!) or meet economic criteria - which would be fine, but NO - you have to wait from 5 to 15 minutes for it to complete (can do other tasks in the meantime though).

Than you have progressively unlocked biomes - Arctic and Lunar. Those are not really fun. All they do, is provide slightly different economy type and make it more difficult by having to build around factories (heat radius) or shields (anti-meteor shield on the Moon). All you get from that is different visual style and rarer resources, that you have to export to other biomes. And they never generate income (at least on normall or higher) - so the whole point is to build up/buy more temperate region biomes and use them as cash cows, so you can afford loosing hudred of thousands on arctic/lunar biomes. That makes them very unrewarding and as less you can build there, the better for you in general.
Eventually you will unlock energy transfer from the moon and ability to build HQ on your starting map (game goals).
For some weird reason, you have a money cap, dependent on your corporate level (so you can't generate cash in advance and one mistake can destroy your cashflow, no matter how high it would be).

So why the hell do I even recommend this game!? Becaue I spent some hours on it and don't really regret that. I liked some aspects of it, while I hated others, but I enjoyed it more than Anno 2070 at least. Keep in mind that many people disagree and like previous game better. It shares one thing with it's predecessor - it is too expensive for what it is.

Also, optimization is bad. I play on everything maxed, on GeForce 970 and i7 6700K, 16gb DDR4 3000mhz ram, and I get about 30-60 fps in normall play (mostly at 40-ish), and in combat when the flyby starts it can tank to 15 fps for a while. Not so much in normall play, but still.

With all that, game looks stunning, temperate biome building was pretty fun, other biomes frustrate a bit, but at least look different.
There is Voting mechanism (council) but it makes little sense to me.

Combat is used to get extra rare materials (there are 4 types). Those can not be mined, can only be acquired through missions, combat, small amounts when you level up your corporate lvl and you can also send them by using a companion app (a minigame, where you connect 3 or more diamonds).

As for the minigame, it is optional and it gives some easy missions at start, but later it promotes heavily the use of premium currency. You have to be REALLY lucky to be able to beat later levels without spending ridiculous ammounts of cash (which in turn make every puzzle increadibly easy). I do not review the companion app itself, but it is an insult. Exist not just to promote and make the core game more fun, but to look for whales that will throw cash at it to progress. One of the thousands of unethical freemium games out there, that you should avoid like cancer.

reviewText: I ran through the game in just under 14 hrs. At least to the point that I got to build the corporate office.  The tutor said at that point that I could stay and continue building. reviewText: This is a well designed game. Very balanced and easy to pick up. The atmostphere is stunning : graphics and music. As in the previous title, this Anno does a great job in taking you through competitive market systems and complex, but not straining, assembly lines and trade routes. Some of the ideas for future products are creative and humoristic. The only downside is that it is rather finite. Once you've reached the top, there is not much else to do. The competitors' dialogues should also change more drastically as you progress but that's a minor detail. However, given they have already released a Season Pass" for a future expansion
date: it is more probable that Ubisoft will be adding features to make it more "replayable"/"continuous" in the near future than not. Regardless
recommended: I would still recommend this game in its current state. 7/10"

reviewText:
compared to the older games in this series its not as intensive in trade but its still there in other ways the maps are fixed into regions the main lush green regions that have their own unique challanges and unlockables. the space regions with the huge crators and constant threat of falling astroids and the new Tundra region(was given to us as a preorder bonus) which now gives us a frozen island chain region option all three work together to get your main city to its highest potential thruogh multi layer trade(now even includes power)

overall still a beautiful Anno addition that lacks in random seed generation but makes up for it in varation of map styles
would recomend it to anyone looking for a fun management game that gives hours of fun

Also, optimization is bad. I play on everything maxed, on GeForce 970 and i7 6700K, 16gb DDR4 3000mhz ram, and I get about 30-60 fps in normall play (mostly at 40-ish), and in combat when the flyby starts it can tank to 15 fps for a while. Not so much in normall play, but still.

With all that, game looks stunning, temperate biome building was pretty fun, other biomes frustrate a bit, but at least look different.
There is Voting mechanism (council) but it makes little sense to me.

Combat is used to get extra rare materials (there are 4 types). Those can not be mined, can only be acquired through missions, combat, small amounts when you level up your corporate lvl and you can also send them by using a companion app (a minigame, where you connect 3 or more diamonds).

As for the minigame, it is optional and it gives some easy missions at start, but later it promotes heavily the use of premium currency. You have to be REALLY lucky to be able to beat later levels without spending ridiculous ammounts of cash (which in turn make every puzzle increadibly easy). I do not review the companion app itself, but it is an insult. Exist not just to promote and make the core game more fun, but to look for whales that will throw cash at it to progress. One of the thousands of unethical freemium games out there, that you should avoid like cancer.

reviewText:
Anno 2205 is like many recent 'city builder' games that have come out over the last few years.  Promising much, but delivering an experience that is ultimately quite shallow.

There is little background to the 'story', other than the - now almost mandatory - spiel about climate change and something about needing to build a space elevator, which apparently requires you to build a sprawling suburb where the denizens can get enough reality tv and fruit juice to reproduce...

To spice things up a bit you get to (after completing your island adventure) do the same thing in the arctic and then.. on the moon.. wow.

The voice acting is terrible, cut scenes are choppy (even on a top end machine) and after a few hours of playing the game feels like it has little to challenge you, other than making sure you balance resource X with demand Y.

There are some rather uninteresting RTS elements which never really challenge you.

Ultimately, I played this for a few hours and just became bored with it.

It is indeed a very pretty game, but a shallow experience.

For me the best city builder is still Civilisation V.

I give Anno2205 about a 5 out of ten, passable but with little if any replay value.

reviewText:
This is a review from an old player form Anno 2070, the judgement is heavily based on the previous game.

Pros:
- Simplified Production: Now everything is descripted in production rate, so we don't have to look up the wiki to find out the optimal ratio of resource/production.

- No threat around your city: As for the time I was playing, there are no enemies popping up near your territory. While some may consider this as a bad thing, I'm the kind of player that always make peace with everyone on the map anyway.

- Good tool and UI: Building moving and mass building by click-and-drag are long awaited feature. UI is simple, friendly, and clean.

Cons:
- Too few game mode: Only one career mode is available for now, though it contains all this game is to offer.

- Lack of vehicle customization: You can upgrade your ships, but not like in previous games when you can apply different items and modules to them. No research to enhance them either.

- Trading Route inefficiency: Now you can only send one ware at a time and pay hefty toll for it. I really like the trading mechanism back then, which you can prepare your own ship and freely trading around. Though managing route is one of the main chanllenge in this game.

Conclusion:
This is a bold move for a long lived series like Anno. They planted a lot of new mechanism to this game while some concept may still in its infant I think, but I look forward to the future of them. Blue Byte is always one of my most respected teams, and I trust them can make another peak of this series.

TL:DR

Recommended: A great game for newcomers and STG lovers with much detail, but not so similar to the old Anno. Consider it as a new game, not a remake.

reviewText: Fun city builder. This would be a good  “starter” game if you are interested in this type of game. reviewText:
I am truly shocked at how petty people can be. It is not fair that people review this game against some preconceived idea of what they think the game should be. It's even worse since they knew what the game would be before release as it was well publicized.

The game in it's own right is amazing.

Unlike the previous Anno's in this one resources are now flow resource, instead of gathering in a warehouse. I think this is a great change as you have so much more control. Resource gathering is fine for games with a micro scale where you manage a small city but do it in great detail. In this game you manage multiple cities on a macro scale, so flow resource makes more sense.

A lot of people are complaining about multiplayer. I don't think that is fair as this game is intended to be played over many days/weeks. It will take a while to build up large cities. How will that work with multiplayer? It's a city builder so multiplayer doesn't make sense.

A lot of detail exists in this game. People giving negative reviews seem to overlook the effort the developers put in, not fair.

Some people are saying they played 20 hours and have done everything there is to be done. To those people I send my condolences. Once you get your city big enough things start to get very complicated. It becomes an incredible balancing act between production, supply and income. Your trade network can get very complicated.

I've seen many complaints about the game not having random maps. But lets be honest, the previous anno's didn't really  have random maps, it was the same islands over and over again, they were just slightly in a different position every time. You can't have random maps and meaningful maps at the same time. This game has meaningful maps, and they are so large that it really doesn't matter. Even more the amount of time you will spend in a single game, random maps also becomes irrelevant. The maps have so much detail and is incredibly beautiful, they deserve praise.

The game does have sandbox mode, the campaign is the sandbox. the first few missions is just to get you started on your sandbox experience.

People complain about the naval battles, but these are entirely optional and are only for rewards, that you can get in other ways. This is a city builder not a RTS. The battles are fine for the type of game.

I only have two complaints about this game:

The world market needs work as it is a bit unbalanced. But since you can completely ignore it in your game and still be very successful, it's not that big of a complaint.

There seems to be a bit of a memory leak if you play for a long time, that slows down the game. Restarting the game solves the problem though.

reviewText:
I feel this game gets alot of Flak thats not really deserved.  I've played the original ANNOs and loved the previous one a good bit, but I still have to say that while this is not the ANNO that the others were, it still has a charm of its own.   Its still an ANNO game without being the overly complex time sink that the other ANNOs could be, meaning that it has been simplified down so you know just what your people need and how to make it with out having to guess that I need x Production building for x amount of production building to get me out of a hole.  To me this game makes it easier with knowing what you need and how much is being produced with out comprimsing the difficulty of the game itself to much.  I've noticed alot of people (Not All before some of you put on your Comic Book Guy braid and jump on your BBS) who complain the most about the game proabbly havn't played it long enough, or played it on extreamly easy to find that it can get hairy at times when your trying to expand and find yourself with 30 minutes to drag yourself out of a 5k hole while trasporting 5 bioenhancer units to your headquarters for a whopping 3k just to try and pull yourself out of that hole.  There's deapth to the game, its just not right there right away.

While I am happy that I don't have to worry about Combat on the mainbuilding side, I never really enjoyed trying to balance the needs of the citizenry while trying to maintain a fleet just because Boris was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ I was sucking up to much oil instead of buying it from him, the way the combat is placed in the game is kinda meh.   The Difficulty for the combat is difficult to scale, on easy its way to easy, on medium it can get pretty hairy unless your going back after you're pretty much maxed out, and the Hard mode can just be rediculous.

People complain about the lack of a Mulitplayer, but honestly now adays those same people complain that Solitair wasn't Multiplayer.  The game holds its own with out having to worry about trying to find a 'match' and then hope you can keep someone around for the hours it takes to build a successful Corporation.  With the way combat is managed in the game Mulitplayer would either be a Multi Day affair with one person you'd have to schedual with, or a series of short RTS Ship combat that, and lets face it, in the end would either be boosted by a paywall or would get full of hacks that would ruin it.

I would still recommend this game to those that enjoy Management games that have alittle bit of story included, and while there are fewer maps in the game, the build area is larger letting you create that city you want much easier.  I might say that if you are still on the fence about the game, watch some videos of the game, and wait for a sale if your concerned about the price tag.

Another Up for the game is that we will be getting some DLC soonish, I am looking forward to the Tundra area moreso then the spacestation building DLC, but still can't wait to see just what these will add to the game and the story being told.

reviewText:
Review: Anno 2205

PROFILE OF REVIEWER:
I have played hundreds of hours of this games predecessors: Anno 1404 (Dawn of Discovery), and Anno 2070.

POSITIVE:
(+) Excellent art assets. This game is beautiful and runs very well.
(+) Gameplay has been streamlined. Trade is no longer a mess and is sent between sectors, rather than islands.
(+) Map design is very good. Sector projects add a much needed end goal.
(+) Building radii have been done away with in favor of a much more interesting supply system.
(+) The UI has been given a much needed facelift. It provides much more meaningful information and ensures a much better experience in handling production and supply chain management.
(+) Being able to move and adjust buildings AFTER you've placed them is a huge improvement.
(+) Sound design and soundtrack are both improved.

NEGATIVE:
(-) Combat is restrictive and relegated to zones that exist outside of your economic empire. You will never feel threatened.
(-) The variety of buildings you can construct in each environment is fairly limited.
(-) The lack of a map generator, skirmish mode, and competitive AI rips a lot of replay value from the game. (DLC?)
(-) The lack of disasters and ecological consequences strips a large element of surprise/challenge from the game.

CONCLUSION: 8.5/10
All things considered, this is a very strong entry into a long line of complex city-building games. Many veteran players may dislike the streamlining of the gameplay and feel like a lot of the challenges have been stripped out, but they will find different challenges coming into play in the late game. If you liked Anno games beforehand, but felt the complexity was a bit burdensome, you will love Anno 2205. Likewise, if this is your first entry into the series or even city-building games in general, you will find a lot to appreciate.

reviewText:
ANNO 2205 is a different beast from it's predecessor. Most notable among gameplay improvements is a virtual stockpile of goods; the game focuses on this mechanic of creating positive balances, and most other changes to core gameplay have been made around this one significant improvement over the last ANNO game. Skilled players will be able to balance their production at +0 and then focus on other maps, shutting out their competition and claming the free world for their own.

The graphics are really nice. Major improvement. Some of the buildings are re-used from the last game though, minus points for that.

Certain aspects of the game have been removed, but it's overall improved. For example, I can't find any sort of multiplayer in this game, but the online play for 2070 was clunky at best and perhaps it's worst feature. With the removal of a military presence and splitting the game out over different sector-maps, multiplayer is unlikely to return. Good riddance.

Speaking of the military aspects of the game, they have been shunted into side missions. In these side missions, you control a small (what do you call 7 vessels? A platoon? squad?) of  sea ships with different but well-balanced and amusing weapons in order to claim the mission's main objective and collect 'rare resources' vital to improving your settlements. If you aren't building modules: you really should be. Modules are really what was missing in 2070: the ability to upgrade production buildings and streamline chains in bulk rather than building 10 or 20 individual factories.

Annoyances? When you have to switch between maps, there is a small load time. However, as much as the developer has tried to segregate maps from each other, there is still some resource bleed. I can feel my game becoming sluggish the longer I play with 10+ trade routes and a civilization on all of the maps. The region maps are pretty samey, If I'm not paying attention I can accidentally spend up to 10 minutes on the wrong sector. Really wish they had put a little more effort into making the maps visually unique. The tech races": Moon and arctic
date: often carry negative income balances by default
recommended: unable to pay for themselves without their supporting temperate race. This is a pretty glaring oversight.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: this is a good buy. Worth the money. Should keep you entertained for a long time.\n\n"

reviewText:
Many people have been saying that 2205 has been too oversimplified. I disagree, with some notes below:

Trade Routes:
-Resources and energy are now shared between your islands on a map.
-You have different biomes (potentially 3 of each biome) that can all trade with one another.
-Once you have several different biomes with lots of different population classes each I promise the trade routes are still challenging and you hve to get certain types of entire maps to focus on producing one or two goods.

Resource Balances:
-This allows you to upgrade your population class, quickly see the new requirements, and then race to provide them by working backwards.
-The neat cretive aspect is that you know eactly how many of what you need to build, and you have limited rare resources, so the puzzle game still exists, but you are less likely to overbuild.

Different Biomes:
-I like the temperate biome for the graphics. I like the Arctic/Lunar mechanics but not the aesthetics. They seem to be just places to set up resource chains.
-The objective of the game for me is to create the most sprawling temperate megacities that I possiby can. Lunar and Arctic biomes are sort of like side puzzles that I have to solve in order to create the ultimate temperate city.

Combat:
-I don't like the combat in this. But who ever buys Anno games for combat?

No Continuous game:
-Yes there is. The campaign can be largely ignored as can the combat missions.
-Part of the idea of just drag dropping everything is there so you can haphazardly advance through the story then go back and opimize later once you have advanced. This is a good thing.

Difficulty:
-Creating and balancing a huge megacity remains challenging. Producing enough energy to efficintly maintain all of the production chains in the different biomes is difficult, especially when you are first starting out on a map.
-Losing the game is difficult but it always has been. Just advance within your limits and you will be fine. I rarely lost games of Anno 2070 or 1404 either. It is just a matter of how impressive you can make your city and Anno 2205 has still made this challenging.

In the end, I wish I was as motivated to perfectly optimize all three biomes. I only really care about one of them, the other ones can just be mediocore. Still, this is a good game and I think if you like the previous Anno installments you will like this one too. Just don't get angry when you don't see the trade routes right away, those get harder to manage later on.

reviewText:
This game is awesome.  There is enough of the old flavor of Anno to make it approachable, but enough redesign to make it interesting and fresh.  To those who are saying this is 'dumbed down' or 'simplfied' that is just not true.  There is a definite stream line of the production system, but it is still every bit as in depth and interesting as it has ever been.  While you may mot see exactly how much of each resource you have at every second, there is still a count going on.  It simply cleans up the interface down to the more essential elements.  If you loved Anno, GIVE THIS GAME A SHOT.  I promise you will not be disappointed.  It's true that it does not hold strictly to the Anno formula, but it is a refined version that stands on its own.  There is still plenty of land and area management to keep everything interesting, and if you think it's simplified or too easy, then crank up the difficulty! It gets pretty intense.  This game is no joke, nor a rush job, and is 100% worth your time.  The first hour or so may feel easy, but trust me, keep chasing that rabbit down the hole and you will be rewarded with a rich and enjoyable experience.

The biggest difference from old to new is the combat system.  This is a complete redesign, switching over to a complete RTS system for the duration of the scenario.  These combat scenarios allow for the acquisition of rare materials that are required for upgrading your buildings.  This change of pace keeps the steady gameplay changed up and interesting.  Don't knock it til you try it.

The biggest con I have so far is that the combat scenarios are limited to 2 at the moment.  I'm sure they will get refreshed on a regular basis as in 2077 but I can't verify that at this time.

reviewText:
Many people have been saying that 2205 has been too oversimplified. I disagree, with some notes below:

Trade Routes:
-Resources and energy are now shared between your islands on a map.
-You have different biomes (potentially 3 of each biome) that can all trade with one another.
-Once you have several different biomes with lots of different population classes each I promise the trade routes are still challenging and you hve to get certain types of entire maps to focus on producing one or two goods.

Resource Balances:
-This allows you to upgrade your population class, quickly see the new requirements, and then race to provide them by working backwards.
-The neat cretive aspect is that you know eactly how many of what you need to build, and you have limited rare resources, so the puzzle game still exists, but you are less likely to overbuild.

Different Biomes:
-I like the temperate biome for the graphics. I like the Arctic/Lunar mechanics but not the aesthetics. They seem to be just places to set up resource chains.
-The objective of the game for me is to create the most sprawling temperate megacities that I possiby can. Lunar and Arctic biomes are sort of like side puzzles that I have to solve in order to create the ultimate temperate city.

Combat:
-I don't like the combat in this. But who ever buys Anno games for combat?

No Continuous game:
-Yes there is. The campaign can be largely ignored as can the combat missions.
-Part of the idea of just drag dropping everything is there so you can haphazardly advance through the story then go back and opimize later once you have advanced. This is a good thing.

Difficulty:
-Creating and balancing a huge megacity remains challenging. Producing enough energy to efficintly maintain all of the production chains in the different biomes is difficult, especially when you are first starting out on a map.
-Losing the game is difficult but it always has been. Just advance within your limits and you will be fine. I rarely lost games of Anno 2070 or 1404 either. It is just a matter of how impressive you can make your city and Anno 2205 has still made this challenging.

In the end, I wish I was as motivated to perfectly optimize all three biomes. I only really care about one of them, the other ones can just be mediocore. Still, this is a good game and I think if you like the previous Anno installments you will like this one too. Just don't get angry when you don't see the trade routes right away, those get harder to manage later on.

reviewText: Much like Civilization V, this piece of the series was a dissappointment. The heavy quest-line limits your every move until you find yourself just giving in to their whims. What this game lacks in strategy is simply emphasized by what it lacks within simulation. Anno 2205 comes off as a beautiful game to watch, and definitely something you can sink a few (many?) hours into, but at it's core, it is too easy and too predictable. I would rate it 3/5. If you are a strategy- and sim-freak like myself, this game offers very little that the previous titles didn't offer (while the previous ones did it better.) It is simply Anno in the future, dumbed down.\n\nThen again, the mindless repeatition was somewhat relaxing, and the graphics were beautiful. If you are short on cash, other games might be for you, but I will still reccomend giving this game a try. Hardcore sim/strategy? No. Decent game? Definitely. Worth the money? Perhaps.

If you like multiplayer, deep-end game content, or random maps... you won't find that here. If you like a city builder with the ability to tinker with production chains and gradually build a sparwling city over multiple zones, this game might be fun for you. I'm recommending this game because it isn't BAD, though I find it inferior to Anno 2070. If you aren't bored with Anno 2070, though, stick with that.

reviewText:
So this game is getting a lot of negative reviews so Im writing this. Im going to set this up as follows, description of what the game is, pros, cons, summary.

This game is basically is a production chain, corprate city builder. What that means is you need recourse x and recourse y to get recourse z (x+y=z, as well having to build a city to house your employees. This is standard for anno games. There is a combat element as well. This game is very similar in essance to Tropico games if you are looking for a comparison.

Pros
- Multiple Environments (i.e. Temperate, Artic, and Lunar)
- Easy access for new to anno players
- Streamlined menus
- Great graphics
- Ease of jumping from location to location (environments)
- Simplified trade systems
- New economic emphasis
- Very well polished and complete

Cons
- Very shallow combat
- Lack of weight to A.I. Competitors
- No true" continuous mode
- Trade to A.I. basically non existant
- No real weight to fleet managment
- Lack of weight to Corporation value (i.e. stock price)

Summary

What this game does right in my opinion out ways what it does wrong. Lets start with what it does wrong. Combat is terribly shallow requiring no real thought or prep. You are just given ships to command and you go and click on what you want them to shoot. Now I dont think they are to far off the mark with the shell of combat in this game. A few tweaks could make combat worth while. If they bring back the ability to build your own ships as well as upgrade them properly with experience to each vessel it could be fun to send them out and have them return to port and you be able to view them there but as of now that doesnt exist. A.I. is basically just present corporations they seem to do anything other than exist as benchmarks for your progress. This ties in with corporate value and trade
date: if they would make the A.I. corporations dynamic as in directly competing for trade routes and stock sales as secondary income as well as bringing back hostil take overs from Anno 2070 it could be very interesting. One of the biggest complaints I have seen is no "true" continuous mode. Now the game itself is a continuous game framed around a basic campaign. It would be nice how ever to have the options to turn off all the talk and just to let you run the city without interuption.\n\nNow the good. First off this game is very well polished. It looks great and runs well. For players new to the Anno series this is probably the best place to start as the menus and systems are streamlined and easy to figure out. The new environments create diversity among the maps. The way you jump from location to location is done well as you dont feel as if you are being pulled out of the game to load. The new much more economic and city building emphasis works well. I prefer the new streamlined menues to the old Anno games just because they are quick and easy to look at
recommended: no more clicking warehouses to see what I need to buy and sell. The trade is also quicker
hoursPlayed: as you just set up the locations and go. A bit more depth would be nice but it works well. There is little more to say here other than I find this game to be very enjoyable. I think with the right tweaks this game like Anno 2070 will be fantastic. Anno 2070 started a little on the weaker side but was tweaked well.\n\nTo conclude if you are new to Anno I do not think you will go wrong here. Its enjoyable and has depth with out being overwhleming. If however you are an Anno veteran
voteText: it may be worth while to wait and let the expansions tweak the game to a more desirable level
helpfulPercent: particularly the combat and
votesHelpful: stock systems. Again those are in depth features that veterans will know and wont really affect the quality of play for new players."

reviewText:
This game sees alot of hate from veterans of the series, and with some good reasons, but there is no denying this a fun game.  Fundamentaly different previous instalments, this game offers the very bare bones concept of the Anno series.  Its more an econmey managment game more than a city builder but not by alot and in its root is a city builder.  For those of you who don't know the Anno series, and Anno 2205, is a city-building/eco managment game where we build a city a supply your citizens needs at increasing difficulty.  While Anno 2205 is the same principle and fun at that, it feels to watered down to appeal to newcomers, I have no problem with that its that the execution is not great.

First off the game is just in general just way too casual.  Farm buildings are now just one building(unless you count the building modifications) compared to previous games that had fields to place down and made you think about the best solution.  You can build houses anywhere which is an ok thing.  The new way of goods distrubition is ok and didn't need to change at all.

I really just hate the artic region and really prevents me from wanting to go back and make a new session becuase it is just so slow and stupid.  You can only build housed near heat sources which are always production centers.  So you are constantly building industry which you can't support.  I understand the challenge of the artic, but its too much and too far from any interesting gameplay becuase it feels like a burden, just like the boring combat which is neccesary to move on with the game.

Now one big change that just removes my ability to consider this Anno game to be one the caliber of others is that the lack/reinvetion of trade and goods movement.  Taxing trade routes would have a really neat idea if the game had NPCs that interacted with you at all or had interregional trade.  The new trade system removes ship routes from island to island and replaces it to super simple trade.  Trading with the only NPC in the game, Mr. Spaceport man, is almost, scratch that, is actually completely pointless.  Becuase of the tax on trade goods combined with the amount you need to produce and the cost of producing said goods is so expensive that the trade goods negate any income or profit, the only goods worth it are high tier goods which are even more expensive to make so there is literaly no point and if they didn't allow to sell your goods it would make no difference in gameplay.

All in all, that fact that the game fails to capture many big and small details and gameplay elements it just waters down the game and make it feel sub par.  For newcomers and veterans alike, the game is fun and worth it, though lacking features and replayability compared to the others.  It is fun and worth buying, but serioulsy Blue Byte/Related Designs, if the Anno series dosen't return to its roots in the next game that consider me and many customers gone from the series.

reviewText: I've enjoyed previous game ANNO2070 and this is a great continuation of the style, story and challenges. I love the idea of Moon bases, when I first heard of it, but playing the game it really is just another base that has slightly more challenging environment than Arctic. The graphics in this game are 10/10. I love every detail. Very futuristic and educational on how resources, which kind and how much are used. Sound design is also 10/10, plus the music. Very well done. The part that didn't amaze me was the battles and wars you have to fight. They all seem to be the same, with just different level of challenge. I though that game could have had better storytelling to that point. Winning the game also doesn't give you any indication, I've played very long and pretty much at the point of winning all skills and challenges, but the game just continues. With maybe, more enjoyable missions, shorter battles and more storytelling to the war/resistance, this game will be 10/10. At this point it's more like 7/10 for me. Still highly enjoyable.

reviewText:
Yeah I saw the negativ reviews and I can't say they are completly wrong, but in my oppinion some of the critics are dumb. You can turn of the point with collecting stuff. If you play on the highest rank it's harder to be in the plus and the main key of Anno is still there. To build a civilisation without going to the bad balance.
Millitäry is a bit off map in a single mission. For me who wants to build without disturbing it's nice. I didn't really liked the fight for your island and hope your enemy isnt better than you So i normally turned off the enemies. :)
And you still need traidingrouts, but they are a bit different from the first Anno's. You dont make a route and put a ship on it. You make it on a world map and say how much the need to transport.
But its true that the longterm motivation isnt really given. But thats for me at all Anno's.

A littel overview (personal thinking):
Pros:
- a long campain
- many sidequests to get rare resources
- free mobile app to farm rare resources and send them to the game
- 3 different sectors (normal, artic and moon) with different states
- every map with a unic sector project
- finally (if you dont have turn it off due difficulty level) can move buildings instat of destroying and new building
- crisis sectors (military missions) in different maps so no impact on your civilisation
- finally (I jumped of happieness) you can see if you produce enough supplies or need more
You can see if your stock is rising, dont having change or sinking and in which ammount

Cons:
- only 9 maps (3 per sectors)
- only 1 ship per map
- no custom/random maps
- only campain no mp with others (you could compare your companies)
- no longterm motivation except achives
- it's not like the old ones

At least I can say that if you want to build your civilisation and want to have a few problems with getting higher you can play this game good on Expert. If you want something like the first few Anno's you should keep your hands off this game :)

Well,


I finally got my population past 1 Million people in under 30 hrs of gameplay and I thought i would give you a balanced review from the rough start and errors, to mastering the new anno.

Anno is a very unique game and it wasnt untill I play this version it rekindled my hopes for the future of the genre. The last anno series was great 2070, I played well over 100 hrs if not more and being a huge fan of city builder games and I will say this game now stands on its own. You have a much larger area to work with and the debateable switch to auto ship deployment instead of direct control was a little different. If you keep a good pace I found you will probally be releaved not having to manage that, as well cultivate your economy and manage the supply levels to your citizens.  I find it is a balance between trading between your artic regions temperate and the lunar colony, my perosnal favourite, the energy transfer trading. I have over 120000 power bring produced by the moon and is essentially my power supply for every sector(this takes time).

The side missions are interesting and a nice break to building, this still kind of reminds you there is something else to do if you dont want to build.

There could be a possible replayability issue in the long term.

Performance issues and not that smooth after being built up.    (  iam running gtx970 ssc  i54960k @3.5)


A few issues I noticed mainly where, Ships running through objects in the water. Snow mobiles look like there 3ft off the ground. A few more but i guess that is what a big report is for.

The game crashes if you ALT + TAB -  during certain points. Not all the time but 80%



You can turn on auto upgrades building in the bottom right.   TO mass build apartments and house hold down and drag!


Have fun managing your expansion, citizenary needs, and ATTACK for those petrochemicals!

If you have any questions feels Free... Be welll    AND ENJOY THE GAME>

reviewText:
I like the game. The steamlining makes it more enjoyable. Some people might just cram as many houses into a corner as possible, but with the system you are allowed to build somthing you are proud of. You can make districts and allow your imagination to run.  I like not being confined to the best grid layout or being a slave to guides.

Combat is separated from your main city and in its own zone. This put me off at first but I found I liked having optional combat and not being blockaded or sidelined by diplomacy.

I recommend this game for its city building and rewarding trade system.

reviewText:
So I put in a bit of time in this game now, and therefore feel better equiped to offer a more comprehensive reveiw, having experienced some of its depth now. I'm offering this as a fan of the series for its last three titles or so.

At first, like most people in the first hour or two of the game I probably would have given a bad review as well. In doing so, i think i forgot how easy anno 2070 was for the first couple of hours too. As i soon found out, Anno 2250 does indeed become challenging. At a glance, the simplification of trade routes and the lack of units by which to manage them seemed a big disappointment to me too. By the time I was maxing out my arctic colony and ranking up my lunar population it became apparent why. The amount of resources you will be ferrying between sectors can get dizzying, and I had more of them then i needed to accomplish everything than i did  in Anno 2070. By the time I really got things cooking in the late stages, It was clear that the simplification of trade routes was actually something I was glad for. If I had to micromanage the transports to much too, it would be overwhealming. However the one drawback I did not like or understand was why a transport of any kind that has additional space, cant ferry more than one type of goods or resource. Thats a minus to me.

The other big minus of this game is apparent in every review already on here, the military component. It sucks, the missions are repetative, and get boring quick. I suppose its an okay way to kill time while your waiting for your capitol to tick up or something, but really, it just isnt fun. The lack of units, and being confined to only naval combat (no real air units) just dosent hold up, for anyone apparently. It might as well be a mini game on an iphone. Its lame, and I found myself really missing my air units and submarines from Anno 2070.

On its own this game is actually great. Its really hard for fams of the series to allow it to stand on its own, when its title demands it be compared in every way to its predacessor. But honestly, if you play it with an open mind, and put in the time. I think you will be impressed.  Its utterly gorgeous in scenery and detail particularly when you get your colonies built up. Its complexity and resource management is a micromanagers wet dream, but you still have to put in the time. It wont challenge veterans in the first few hours, but it will once you really get going.

For newcomers, you are gonna love it, if you like this genre of game.
For veterans, play it. Then judge. There's no getting away from the lame military component, but anno is still alive and kicking here, and you dont wanna miss what this one has to offer in the later stages.

reviewText: First review ever :D.. let me start off with saying that Anno 2205 is a good game, I like how they tweaked certain features (like seeing how much buildings you need to build to use a resource properly). Theres alot of things I like but alot of things where im kinda sceptical. --->  no random generated maps, and no AI where i can change and make a fun new gaming experience (almost every time).  Sadly the game doesnt have any replay value. I just hope that Anno 2205 gets better with further dlcs.. love the game series but got bored for the first time with it, which is disapointing.\nFeel like discussing this topic? just write in the comments and lets hash it out :D.

reviewText:
This is a huge side step in the Anno series.
A lot of the gameplay has been simplified and streamlined.
Micromanagement has been almost completly taken away.
Instead we got a much faster, much bigger and much newb friendlier game, until you finish your first 8 hours
and it kicks you in to the moon
After that the complexity of the game overwhelms you.

Temperate: Way too easy

Arctic: Ultra Tetris

Moon: Your credits will be buttsecksed

Easy to learn, hard to master

9/10 a bit too expensive. Get it on a sale or somethin'.

reviewText:
Admittedly I'm quite a casual gamer, and have never played the Anno series until 2070, of which I only spent less than 200 hours on; as thus, I'm only comparing this game to Anno 2070.

Tl;dr: a mild Yes. And before anything else: Uplay was not an issue.

--------CON--------
Admittedly, aspects of this game are indeed a bit too simple. There is no longer a need to control Ecobalance (of which I actually found to be the most fun) or manage your production chains as much; instead of having to check your stocks and add storage to see how much resources your growing islands need, you look at a tab integrated into the UI and do simple arithmetics to see how many more production chains do you need. Also quite a large disappointment is the fact that I can't now manage to sell stuff to NPC's by building my own boats or wage wars by building my own airplanes; micromanaging your own transportation route was so much fun, and the lack of that ability is indeed disappointing.

Overall, this means that there is less to do to manage your enterprise. You sort of just keep on plopping down stuff, check spreadsheet, make sure your balance is high and keep on plopping down stuff. Anno 2070 for me was plopping down stuff constantly as well, but aside from the plot efficiency managing, you also had to think a bit more about how to organize your transportation routes and so forth.

--------MEH--------
Crisis sectors are the only real places of combat. Although this means that at least you don't have to worry about your islands being ruined, they didn't need to have taken out normal ship-building as well...

Quests... eh, they're sort of like the previous game. You pick up stuff, you find stuff, you hand it to the quest giver and get some resources or cash. Playing on standard, this often gives you a lot of rare resources, of which sometimes you may not need, but having is better than not having I guess.

Personally, I'm ok with having no coast buildings other than the slot ones. However, I would've liked to control where I placed my own port... the slots they give often requires you to place extra long roads to connect, and with the fact that you can't build warehouses to control your transportation this forces you to tie everything into the same road network; production layouts that was closed on the outside like in 2070 now requires extra roads to connect and nothing on the interior other than expanding your building.

--------PRO--------
As much as people say gameplay over graphics, the graphics is ABSOLUTELY WUNDERBAR. Like, certainly the most beautiful city-building game out there at the moment. The temperate region is ok, but the chilly arctic and the foreign moon just completely blew me away... and I was running on low with reduced resolution, as a Macbook Pro isn't exactly designed for gaming. The visual attention to details as well as the small audio blips, like from the last game, really adds the sense of immersion in this game, to the point where when I get my desktop back I'm going to just have a monitor dedicated to only run the game in postcard mode and turn on the day-night cycle.

Although the plot is fairly weak, the game was never about plot; bits and pieces of carry-over from 2070 gives a good feeling, seeing humanity recover from the great disaster that set the stage for 2070.

--------ENDING WORDS--------
Once again, I never played previous Anno games other than 2070. Even compared to 2070, this game is a fairly simple game that, indeed, doesn't have that much depth. This certainly makes the game less challenging; however, I personally enjoy the less amount of things to think and worry about, as I want to play a game to relax and have a good time. With its clear UI, simplified mechanics and the stunning graphics, I can definitely recommend this game. Maybe not so much grabbing it right now, but when it's on sale some times later I'd say that this game is definitely worth it.

reviewText:
Updated.

Relaxing fun and beautiful game. It is different than other Anno games, and feels fresh. I like new regions and hope to see more. Game is very beautiful. It's easy at first even on hardest difficulty, but it gets pretty alright along the way. Battles are easy and relaxing, but feels like a different game, they kinda fun, but i would love to see something different, where we will build our own ships with our resources and send them into battles. Overall Anno 2205 is a great game. I'm glad it's different. Characters are interesting and awesomely voiced. Also, major sector quests are cool.

Can't wait to see orbit and tundra, i would love to have more content. I would love to see Mars.

There are some performance issues and no multiplayer, I do hope it will be fixed.

To Ubisoft i can only say, learn from CD Projekt how to make good games, make players happy, and no DRM, and players can choose any language they want. Here, Russians can choose only russian, which is well translated but still, i prefer to have a choice in a matter, especially when i paid more money than for Legendary Witcher III Wild Hunt. Overall i have issues with Ubisoft and how they ruin their games, than with Anno itself. I mean, it's a serious issue these days, big game corps like UbiSoft, EA etc should learn form CD Projekt, and think about players more than quartal incomes, because if you have happy players, you have money.

reviewText:
If you are looking for a AWESOME CITY BUILDING GAME, HERE IT IS!!!

If you are looking for an orthogonal ANNO SERIES GAME, it's probably not.

Most people wrote their review when they only played 20min. Well, I have 16.3hr in record already and here is my review.

First of all, the concept itself worth the 80$ for me already. (Yah it sounds silly but futuristic is just my type, it gives hope)
And space elevator and He-3 sort things, they are really possible to make; unlike Photon Torpedo or light saber, they look cool but doesn't sound scientifically possible at all. You can tell that developers did put effort in researching these things.

But seriously, although I do think it's a awesome game, it doesn't really worth 80$ or even 60$ at current stage for most gamers. All you can do is to repeat the same thing on different difficulty, but really the same. No multiplayer; single player itself is basically a combination of both  campaign and free built but neither systematic stories were told nor total freedom was achieved. Same nine maps all the time. For it's graphic, and name, probably 40$ at maximum. You can just find a camera and take a screenshot of your city, and all of them can be your wallpaper. But again, gaming experience doesn't solely come from graphics, the game simply lacks playability, in terms of how much money you paid to play.

Some gamers complain about micromanagement and others stuff were being removed. I think developers just wanna reduce difficulty and complexity of the game. I mean, man, managing three four islands on same map was hard enough already in 2070, now you telling me to manage ships and space ships on nine maps at same time? That's gonna make me noxious at least. So, those who are actively looking for ANNO 2070 '135 years later' expansion, this is totally a new thing, probably not for you. But for those city builder lovers who do not like to manage ships run around islands to deliver goods, this is it.

I wish expansions and updates would make this game better. Diablo3 was criticized when first released, but it did do better after several patches, so, who knows.

And ubi better fix bugs.

A detector drone or sensor drone, forgot what's the formal name, in the first mission of a sector project that extract graphene or something, won't work properly (at least in my case) it's detector is not working (not giving directions) at all, neither reloading sector map nor restarting game fixes it, and that means good bye to that project. Drones in all other missions work fine.

Overall, it's a good game, but kinda lacks contents. Likely to make a lot of layers feel tedious after their first run, especially on easy difficulty. If you wish better gaming experience, buy it later when some thing new come out. Or just wait for ANNO 2313 or something if you just like typical ANNO game, observe how it goes.

Or wait the complete edition and buy when it's just 20$. ( like 2070 now)

reviewText:
If you want an Anno game that is a simply re-skinned version of the last two games, then I recommend you mod Anno2070. If you want a new game with different features and challenges, then this is the game for you.

The game is vast and more scaled up than the previous games, letting you build bigger and faster than you ever could before. Production/consumption rates of every item in the game are displayed, removing a lot of tedium and guesswork when setting up production lines. New mechanics such as heating in the arctic and shields on the moon force you to adopt new city designs. Modular buildings give you increased flexibility when designing productions chains, allowing you customize each building to help with the challenges of supporting it. Your population is there for more than just funding, each building needs workers and requires them to be on-site.

If you're expecting Anno2070 part 2, or Anno1404 part 3... I'm sorry to say that this is a new game.
voteText: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let's be real here, folks. A lot of hate will be spewed in this direction just because it's Ubisoft. (I remember when Ubisoft was universally hailed as the good guys against the likes of evil corporations like EA. Ah, memories.)

The game, though, deserves to be reviewed on its own merits, and not the reputation of its parent company, and I, for one, must say that this game is positively gorgeous.

It's not a city-builder so much as an economy-planner, and there is a unique satisfaction in building beautiful economies, linking them together, and watching the cash flow like water, not to mention admiring the beautiful sight of all of the ingeniously-planned cities which you have constructed.

Don't let the (sometimes-deserved) anti-Ubi hype keep you from this very, very fun experience. It will hook you. If you liked any of the previous Anno games (or Dawn of Discovery, as it was pointlessly renamed in the U.S.) then you will love this, and please help send the message that we don't want horrid bloated flash Anno games (*cough* Anno Online *cough*) but rather, lovely and original titles like this one.

reviewText:
Parts of the game feel really phoned in, and the combat isn't really clicking for me.  Lack of multiplayer is kind of a killer.  singleplayer campaign structure has been improved consiterably.

That said, I still recommend it but not at current prices, wait for a deal.

It's an interesting new approach to the series, parts of it work and parts don't.  The multi-region interplay is pretty good, even the abstracted logistics became a net positive for me.  The combat has been entirely seperated from the main part of the game and sequestered into side missions.

The game is in dire need of more content in general, what's here is a good starting point, but I'd really like to see it evolve like 2070's content did, with the monthly events and all that kind of stuff.

reviewText:
There seems to be a lot of negative reviews out for this game today about half a day after release. I would like to share mine.

I’m not really a fan of Anno games, but I do like city building / resource management games. I have played Anno 2070 for 265hours, finished all the hardest missions, and filling all the islands with endgame building monuments and modules for all 3 factions.

I’ve been in Anno 2205 for about 3 hours. Much has been changed in this game. Resources are less modular and simplified, there is much less of needing to use your command ship to ship fixed amount of resource, most are done automatically. Your residence generate income, create workers supply, factories create more advance building materials to make next tier of buildings, and uses electricity and workers as maintenance. You build electricity modules to power all buildings, it simply cost income to maintain. Maintaining this 3 core resources seems to be the core of the resource management system, with much more advance building material in the late game.

In 2070, quest offered by npc are limitless. In 2205 there seems to be less quest offered, at least in early game, but they are much longer in chain, with the first quest resulting in being able to rebuild a dam offering lots of power resource. There are 3 regions to play in, each with multiple sectors, temperate, artic and lunar. Each sector has its own long line of projects to complete. The early intro quest extends to the late game from the start, guiding you in your entire game progression.


The combat in the game has been change. Instead of being in the sector where you build building, you join standalone missions and complete military missions with your fleet of warships. There are alot of variety in the different ships at your disposal. Modular upgrades that you can buy and place in your ship for extra bonus in various attributes from the previous game has been removed. Instead, each ships have multiple abilities, missile barrage, emp etc. Ships has utility abilities like repair and shield. This cost either limited uses or fuel, which is also limited. This can be replenished by fuel lying around the map or powerups that you can pick up with your ship to replenish ability use or fuel. By finishing assignments and missions, you gain military experience where you can permanently upgrade your military ships attributes or gain new ones. You also earn new rare resource iridium and graphene that can be used to upgrade your HQ or your factory with additional modules that boost productivity or becomes less taxing on worker use or power usage.

Multiplayer has been removed, this game no longer has pvp support, though I wasn’t really interested in the pvp element of the previous game.

One huge impressive element in this game is the graphics. The islands and water in the game looks beautiful. The amount of artistic work placed in the futuristic theme is huge. All ships and buildings looks extremely high tech. Factories all have their unique looks from different regions. The military missions are much more explosive with the much more Arcady style of gameplay, with improvements in the fx effects etc. Large bridges extend and connects islands in the temperate region. Beautiful glaciers and artic mountains cover the artic region. Each sector also seems to be larger than in the previous games. All Sectors in different regions, including the lunar ones are all connected via the global map, which is where you can see the progress of other npc owned areas and also set up global trading routes from one sector to another.

Overall I have enjoyed the game experience so far, and if you’re looking for a relaxing casual single player only game of city building mixed with military ship gameplay enhanced with gorgeous looks, I would recommend this game to you. (Will probably update this review as I play longer)

EDIT: Been playing this for much more longer and game definitely has much more challenge.
12 hrs in, not even close to filling up 1 sector, 1 game could possibly be 48hrs+

EDIT: 1.4m+ population, this game is awesome.

reviewText:
Parts of the game feel really phoned in, and the combat isn't really clicking for me.  Lack of multiplayer is kind of a killer.  singleplayer campaign structure has been improved consiterably.

That said, I still recommend it but not at current prices, wait for a deal.

It's an interesting new approach to the series, parts of it work and parts don't.  The multi-region interplay is pretty good, even the abstracted logistics became a net positive for me.  The combat has been entirely seperated from the main part of the game and sequestered into side missions.

The game is in dire need of more content in general, what's here is a good starting point, but I'd really like to see it evolve like 2070's content did, with the monthly events and all that kind of stuff.

reviewText:
This game does not accurately represent previous Anno titles. However gives a fresh experience, many of us have been waiting for. Most Anno games in the past have just been the same thing over and over, with graphical updates, and set in a different Era. On previous versions there where many things to like, that were not put in this Anno.

HOWEVER! That does not mean this (by any means) is a bad Anno experience. In fact, its a fantastic experience. Music is amazing, gameplay is very enjoyable, Story is much better then previous Anno games, and its overall just a great experience. A later DLC to add Skirmish is very likely, and when that fateful day arrives, the Anno fans of old, will get their fill. For now though, this game is great.

Do not alter your opinion based on if its like the other Anno games. In alot of ways it is, and in alot of ways it is not. Never the less, the game is great as a whole, without compairing to the other Anno games. Don't let other opinions fool you, with judgements based on previous Anno games.

reviewText:
While the gameplay is a little bit different than previous titles in the ANNO-Series it is still a worthy follow-up. Despite having to manage all of your islands and protecting your traderoutes it was substituted with secure, set traderoutes between sectors of a few island each.

It also substituted the island-based fertilities for plants from earlier versions with different biomes, for example, the arctic zones and having the military actions moved into specifically designed zones.

The graphics are decent; the music isn't all too noteworthy. And the campaigns' storyline is decent.

So, in short:

Posivtive
- Less Management of trading routes
- Almost the same gameplay as its predecessors
- Different biomes
- Moon

Negative
- No pirates anymore
- No customizable military anymore; always preset units with few options to upgrade and a few more units
- No more multiplayer
