reviewText:
Anno 2205 is, at its core, a decent entry into the Anno series but I would not call it the best. I have now put over thirty hours into the game, and while I have enjoyed it and will be playing more I would like to outline to potential buyers what I feel are the pros and cons of this game are.

Pros -
1) No microtransactions in game. Unlocks are earned by simply improving your corporation level or by unlocking them with uplay points which you earn by doing achievements.
2) No game-breaking bugs. Game is very much playable, minus a few freeze ups here and there. Not enough to be frustrating though.
3) Trade routes between cities are very easy to set up and keep organized and make changes to.
4) Much more accessable and easy to get into for new players than any other anno game I have played. (I've played anno 1602, 1701, and dawn of discovery)
5) With no pirates or enemies like previous Anno games had, there is no need to worry about your trade routes being attacked and production halted as a result.
6) You can customize your difficulty in different areas. So for example if you want some parts to be hard but say have mission payout high to avoid grinding missions for rare resources you can set it up like that.
7) With building cities in multiple regions you have to deal with unique, region-specific challenges which makes for fun gameplay.
8) First dlc has been announced and is promised to be free.
9) If you placed a building in the wrong spot, or a spot that is no longer effecent just pick it up and move it as you see fit.
10) Production buildings all come with possible modules to either improve production, reduce worker requirment, reduce energy requirment, or reduce number of logistic trucks required.
11) It is a more relaxed city-builder than others on the market. If you like the idea of a city builder but don't have to worry about sewage/water, or unemployment and polution this may be the city builder for you.

Cons-
1) REQUIRES UPLAY EVEN IF YOU BOUGHT ON STEAM. YOUR GAME MUST BE ACTIVATED ON UPLAY AND UPLAY IS ALSO NEEDED TO SYCRONIZE YOUR SAVE GAME FILES.
2) The isolated combat scenerios manage to be more boring than the previous anno game's combat. Sure it may require a little bit of strategy but essentially the same four combat missions repeat endlessly.
3) You cannot set end-game goals like in previous games. Gone are the days of seeing that you won when you built that amazing cathedral or mosque. Now you just play until you get bored. This may not be a problem for some, but those of you wanting end goals to work for may not find that here.
4) When you consider the game only ships with 3 temperate areas, 3 artic areas, and 3 moon areas the possiblity of replability is shot way down, especially when you consider that you can just buy the other areas in your first game. Essentially, once I get bored of the current game I see no reason to start a new game of anno 2205.
5) No random map generator.
6) You never interact with your competitors cities like you did in previous games, indeed you never even see their cities. Your oponents" are just people you do missions for
date: or vote for to get bonuses. Great if you want to be left alone
recommended: not so much if you were wanting to trade or go to war with them as in previous anno games.\n\nIn conclusion

Now, take what I say with a grain of salt, as I have only sunk in 4 1/2 hours of time into Anno 2205 at this moment in time.

In the short amount of time I have played this game, I must admit that I have been thoroughly enjoying it. There is a decent variety of buildings to create, resources to farm, and plenty of things to do. With that being said, I feel as if something is missing. I can't seem to put my foot on it, but there is certainly a lack of something. Granted, I did play the previous Annos, and there was diplomacy, ground combat, trade routes, et cetera et cetera....but, I am speaking of this game in itself, NOT comparing it to it's predecessors. This game, within itself, is lacking content. There is no denying that. However, this game is, without a doubt, a good game nonetheless. I enjoy it, and I can be rather choosy with my games. reviewText:
Sou um grande fã da série com mais de 513hs de gameplay em Anno 2070. Isso dá alguma credibilidade ao meu pequeno review de Anno 2205. Primeiramente, é bom esclarecer que o novo jogo é diferente do antecessor. Mas com um detalhe, ele continua tão divertido como antes. A cadeia de bens que deve ser montada e na sequencia levada aos benefíciários, ou seja, os habitantes, está mais racional. Anteriormente não se tinha uma noção mais precisa da quantidade de bens que deveriam ser transferidos para ilhas, o que muitas vezes fazia com que se produzisse determinado produto em quantidade maior do que a necessária, ocasionando desperdícios de toda ordem, e prejuízo de recursos valiosos.

Dessa vez o menu (UI) tem um papel fundamental na organização da produção, pois ele passou a ser exibido de forma dinâmica, permitindo ver rapidamente qual item está com a produção negativa, e qual está excessiva. Com isso fica mais fácil incrementar a quantidade de uma determinada comodidade e satisfazer assim todos os habitantes.

No lugar de criar uma vasta cadeia de transporte de uma ilha para a outra, em Anno 2205 a configuaração dos mapas foi  radicalmente alterada. Temos três ambientes distindos para explorar. Começamos num continente com clima temperado, depois passamos para uma região glacial e por último conquistamos uma parte da lua. Cada local possui sua própria infraestrura e economia, de modo que alguns itens do outro continente e do satelite da Terra são enviados de um lado para outro por meio de um ônibus espacial. No lugar dos navios, o transporte de bens é feito 99% das vezes por naves espaciais. Fantastico!

Acabou-se aquela exigência por vezes irritante de suprir a cidade com bombeiros e hospitais, mas foram mantidos a delegacia de polícia e o centro comunitário, que diferentemente de Anno 2070, agora podem ser colocados em qualquer parte da cidade, abrangendo toda a área pelo número daqueles prédios administrativos no mapa, e não exclusivamente pela sua área de alcance somente.

As batalhas foram transferidas para um cenário espefico, permitindo que o foco do player se concentre apenas na construção da cidade e na produção das comodidades e na distribuição de bens. No decorrer e no final das batalhas - que são todas navais - se recebe como prêmio itens raros que não podem ser produzidos por fábricas, o que implica num modelo de grinding para certos melhoramentos. Por falar nisso, agora se ganha XP ao fazer as missões, e dependendo do seu nível serão destravados os blueprints e ampliação da capacidade de acumular recursos.

O jogo não tem um modo continuos game"

reviewText:
After playing almost a week im still seeing this game rated 'Mixed'. Usually when I buy games I tend to read some of the user reviews and make them wheigh in my decission to buy or not to buy. The score Anno 2205 gets, makes me reevaluate my spending strategy.

I'm glad that i bought this game as a preorder because otherwise i might have waited a year to buy this game at a discount.  Let me tell you, this game is worth every buck you spend on it. Ofcourse i don't know if the extra 20 for the season pass is worth the squeeze but after playing the base game I'm already looking forward what Blue Byte might throw at us in the near future.

Anyway, from all the negative comments I've read there's only one that really counts and that's the lack of multiplayer. All the other things like no realtime NPC's to play with or the fact that you can't build ships anymore for traderoutes is really a matter of opinion. Where Blu Byte really shines in this sequel is that it streamlines old gameplay without taking the essence out of the game. All the frustrating things previous anno games had are gone.
For example, no more looking up on wikis what the ideal farm setups are or the ideal amount of buildings in a production chain which really was a gamebreaker for me in the last 2 annos. Oh and by the way there is a stock system but it's not as fleshed out as previous games.

I really must recommend this game to anyone who likes citybuilding games. If you buy this game then please give it the thumbs up if u like it, Blue Byte deserves it.

reviewText:
I'll preface this by stating that I've played every single Anno game since they started making them. I'm a long time fan of the series and haven't disliked a single game they've put out and this game is definitely not the exception to that rule.

Is this game a bit different? Yes.
Is that a bad thing? Personal opinion but I would say no.

This game certainly does quite a few things different than previous titles, so lets get into it.

Pros and ConsPros
Beautiful graphics
Well designed maps
A much tighter and more cohesive campaign experience
Persistent progression (corporation level and your built maps stay with you throughout missions)
Better stats for your settlements
Trading economy network (much improved over previous games, far easier to manage and oversee what's going where and how much it costs you)
Need to adapt building strategies depending on map type
Cons
No multi-player
No random maps
Not many locations
Some rather major performance issues when playing for long periods
Relatively short campaign (which is an issue when there isn't all that much else to do)
Some other notes
Combat Zones
Combat zones separate out warfare into their own maps, and there aren't many of them. This is both a pro and a con because while I enjoy the new maps built specifically for combat, they get repetitive really quickly and offer no real meaningful contribution to the game outside of the story-related objectives. Collection of rare resource seems to be the only thing worth caring about otherwise and it's really just busywork and that's something we need less of in games, not more.

This also brings into contention the fact that there is, outside of some map quests, NO combat on your settlement maps at all; and, by association, means there will only ever be your corporation on a map, no land rushes to compete for space and resources, no fights over said territory, nothing. This probably also explains why there's no multi-player as after you strip the very fundamentals of what made Anno's multi-player there isn't really a great deal left you can do with it, outside of leader boards for population and efficiency etc.

Production Chains
If you've played the new SimCity you've probably seen this kind of thing before, basically now you can make addons" to your buildings for numerous benefits including production increases and cost reductions. This
hoursPlayed: I enjoy the extra flexibility it gives you and adds some much needed variety to building. Some will argue that this dumbs down the game but I don't really see it
voteText: it's pretty much the same except you have to think of most buildings like they're farms with different sized "fields" to consider once you've built the main building.\n\nConclusionAll in all I've enjoyed my time with this game
helpfulPercent: it's a significant departure from its predecessors in some ways while still feeling the same in others. If you're looking for a game that will last you a long time this probably isn't the game for you
votesHelpful: check out previous titles instead
votesTotal: but if you're looking for another Anno game that mixes up the formula a bit while still being the sort of game you know and love
votesFunny: give it a try."

reviewText: This game is gorgeous, filled with lots of fun, action, and intrigue. Ultimately it is a city builder, but it also has a lot of naval combat and more from what I can tell so far. You start as a fledgling corporation of your design. Slowly you build your way up, gain connections, and explore the vast areas of the planet and the moon! No longer do you have to balance climate and factory output like in its predecessor. Instead just keep a balanced checkbook, build, explore, and destroy. There are tons of sub missions inside sub missions and a ton of achievements to unlock. Did I mention how beautiful this game is? The attention to detail is exquisite to say the least. There are no save game states like before, now it is an automated feature, kind of like in an MMORPG. You make a corp., and work within that game state. If you want to make a new game, you start a new corporation. So the missions, achievements, and different gameplays, are all a part of the same ongoing campaign. I am not sure how deep the game is at the moment, but from what I can surmise and from the previous Anno titles you can rest assured that the game will be a joy to play, over and over again. If you are a fan of Anno titles, or like building sites, exploring, and blowing stuff up, then this game is for you!

reviewText:
It is extremely different from the other 2 games; first off there are no farms and factories like in the past games, now you build what is required and then add modules to increase production.

Then they have done away with the town center and trade buildings, you can build any where on your island; some would call this similified but I believe it adds a new dynamic to the game play.

Also they have changed the tax adjustment stuff, as the lore implies the world is run by corperations, there is no tax only work and profit. This in turn means all the cities share the profit of your corperation and therefore it is so much harder to balance the books.

Other reviewers are right, it is different from other Anno games but I like it, it is the natural" progression from the previous storyline and in doing so is an intense game I am no where near the end I dout I'm close to the middle but so far I am impressed and I'm excited to discover more of this game.

I also await the DLC it is bound to have.

reviewText:
Thsi game does not feel like classic Anno games; this is not necessarily a bad thing. Many of the old mechanics are now streamlined behind a layer of abstraction. Instead of waiting for each individual crate of grapes to get from one facility to another, many of fiddly things are made island-wide (logistics, the replacement for land-based warehouses) or even sector-wide (power, for example).

Many other reviewers complain about the loss of these 'features', and that this makes it not feel like an Anno game. They're right, to an extent - this game does not feel like the previous Anno games, which paced your construction with long periods of waiting for the goods to start flowing. You had a lot of time to reflect and plan what you were going to do next. In 2205, however, as soon as the relevant facilities are constructed, you automatically see the benefits, and can even start exporting them immediately as well. You still have to build efficiently, but you can move directly from one challenge to the next.

I definitely can recommend this game. If you really liked the fiddly micromanagement that bogged down the previous games, 2070 is a great entry with that classic feel. If you want to try something a little bit simpler and a lot more streamlined, Anno 2205 is great.

reviewText:
I thought for a while about buying this game and have read a number of reviews and comments on various different forums.  As I did buy it I thought I would my two cents into the mix after playing for 5 hours and have just got to the 4th (and final) tier of population needs.

DRM
Yes it’s a bit of a pain that you have to have a uplay account and have to install it onto your computer but apart from the initial verification process I can’t say that I have noticed it.  For me the DRM is not an issue.

Game Play
Overall I’m really enjoying the game.  I have seen allot of talk about the game being dumb down and on the whole I would have to agree with these comments.  I don’t think it’s as hard or as complicated as Anno 2070 however as your cities get larger there is a fair amount resource management to do (and it’s that what the game is about?).  For example in my main city the need for luxury food was getting high and I was running out of space so I decided to buy a new region and source my whole farming there which meant I could bulldoze my farms in my main city and just import the food. I thought this would be a quick task but realised that to support a farming community I needed to set up a small city.  I wouldn’t say this was difficult but did take a bit of time and I certainly found it enjoyable.

Combat has been taken out of the city building sectors and has its own.  I would say this is the weakest part of the game but it’s ok and found it fun to mix it up every now and then and jump into the combat zone.

Research
There is none from what I can see, unless I’m missing something.  This was something that I really enjoyed in Anno 2070 and really added something to the endgame and also changed the way your next game was played.  Real shame its missing and don’t really understand why.  Perfect opportunity to have specific things in each sector you could research to help the others.

Story
It’s a bit crap.  Basically it’s grow your corporation as big as possible.  The side quests in the form of sector projects are a bit better but not by much.

Graphics
This game looks great however you will need a beast of a machine to run it at max.  I have an i7 6700, 16 GB DDR4 and nvdia 660gtx x2 in sli.  Problem is sli isn’t supported so my 2nd graphic card is just sat there with its feet up.  I run the game in 1440p on medium at 40ish fps.  Nvidia Pascal can’t come soon enough!  Also you will be changing between the sectors allot so a SSD will really help with the load times.

Sound
It’s ok, nice back ground music but nothing to write home about.

Overall
I’m glad I brought it and would recommend it but there are a few things such as sli support, research and improved story line which would really improve the game.

reviewText:
Please be aware this review is just after a few hours gameplay (about 6hrs)...

If you love Anno games (Like I have been, 2070 being my fav), but could do without the military aspect, then this game is almost perfect. Yes there is military action in seperate missions from the main game, but they are almost pointless and can be done quick enough to get back to city building that we love.

The game is simplified for sure, but also has the multibase system similar to the latest Sim City game, only each area has a much greater effect on the other as the income is the same, and you have to trade to produce what you need. I think with this system they had to simplify the main game mechanics or it would have been too much of a pain for half of the gamers out there. I think I may have been one of those frustrated souls!

I will re-review if once I am done I feel the game actually sucked overall, but so far so good. Cannot believe I waited this long to buy it. I guess I listened to all of the negative reviews without noticing that most were about the combat, which I didn't really care for in the other games anyway!

reviewText:
I recommend the game on the basis of it being an ANNO game.  Here are some of the pros and cons I could think of.

Pros:  Graphics are amazing but will melt your computer if you dont have a beefy GPU or CPU.
Pros:  Artwork is very nicely rendered, all in all, its a very pretty game and full of eye candy.
Pros:  Its a bit easier to understand demands of your citizens, gives statistics on how much each industry produces instead of running to a WIKI like in Anno 2070 to figure out what you need to build and how much of it.

Cons: Maps are prefab, beautiful, but prefab, no random element like in 2070.
Cons: I feel as if the game has been EXTREMELY dumbed down.  Instead of supply chains (seeing transports on the streets) ferrying goods to and from it just instantly does it and shows the animation of stuff being moved about.
Cons: No multiplayer and I have to honestly say, after playing it I highly doubt there ever will be multiplayer in a game like this, it has changed that much between 2070 and 2205.
Cons: Maps feel extremely small but is a new engine, you can definately tell they skimped in a lot of areas probably due to engine stability and perfomance issues.

Edit:

I decided to add some additional details in regards to my opinion of dumbing down of the game.  What I mean by this is we were originally accustomed to the previous Anno games where you have to setup up trade routes etc to get the supplies to the manufactor and the end product to the citizens.  In 2205 this is not the case but rather deciding on how you are going to build the city, theres alot more city planning in this game than the previous Anno game.

In 2070:  Buildings and building layouts were static, no upgrades other than enhancements you loaded into your warehouse, global effects, or ARK upgrades.

In 2205:  Theres still a global effect through voting at your ARK *Space Station*.  However, as far as buildings go, most of your production buildings do instantly provide the product, however they are far from static in layout.

Building Upgrades:  Each building that produces a product (electricity, water etc) has so many upgrade slots to enchance production, running costs, workforce costs etc.  So cramming abunch of veggie farms in one location, not wise.  Not only does it cost more in power, maitenence and workforce to run x2 said farms its better to bulldoze one, upgrade the other to exceed the production of the lost farm for a cheaper, more efficient cost.

Building upgrades require rare resources which you cant really obtain from the map, you must buy them from the exchange or do combat missions to get them.  Scour the combat map, theres plenty of extra stuff you can get besides the end mission results.

reviewText:
A bold new direction for the Anno Series, but it's going to be a hard pill to swallow...
Anno has been an iconic series for a lot of reasons, Anno 1404 remains to this day one of the finest resource and city management games of it's time, it's less about city development and more about resource chain management, which makes it about optimisation and logistical planning. It married this with some genuinely timeless graphics, which even now remain entirely gorgeous, and a design that will almost certainly remain playable ten years in the future. It's that kind of a game, a true classic. Since then Blue Byte have been working on the formula and have been trying to recapture the lightning in the bottle.

Anno 2070 was a regression, not least because Uplay was locked into a state where it would force you to remain online and would kill your game if you disconnected, but also because the game lost it's way a little, it just lacked the sheer charm and glory that Anno 1404 had. There were some great ideas in 2070, but overall it just crumbled under the weight of what had, by then become the sheer age and baggage of the old ways". It was still a good enough game for fans of the Anno series like myself

reviewText:
This game paints a dark picture for the future of mankind in which a multitude of crises have forced mankind to consider a second wave of moon-colonisation. As I play this game I am constantly reminded of the dire-straights faced by humans today as reflected in the fictional year 2205, as at least 4-5 times an hour I am harangued by some vulgar chap from Liverpool requesting I feed him and his family or fetch some 'supplies', and he seems all to eager to invite me into his house.

I cannot be sure if it is the scarcity of food and energy that has forced people to live on the moon, or the rapid explosion in the number of scousers. Either way this game provides us with all the chilling and all too real warning of the dangers posed by over-population and the potential threat that Moon-Scouser terrorists may pose to civilization.

The game itself plays better than Anno 2075, although the Tundra DLC doesn't seem to tie into the story or provide any real change in gameplay in any real way.

Well despite all the negative reviews I actually enjoy this game as much as Anno 2070 (1,000+ hrs) - only about 5hrs in so far and just got to the moon. This game is inherently more complex in terms of micro-management as you have to manufacture and move key resources/items between the 3 different zones - which is what I quite like about it so far. Not terribly fussed about lack of multiplayer as I has not bothered with that in previous Anno games.

The graphics are amazing and everything runs smooth at 1440p - looking to try 4k out at some point.

The only annoying/negative aspect is the story aspect and kinda being spoon fed what to do next, etc. It appears to lay off a bit once you get into the game more but its a pitty its not like the previous free-roam continious mode from 2070. Perhaps that will get added later, who knows.

reviewText:
Is Anno 2205 the classic Anno experience? No.

Is it a bad thing? No.

I have been playing Anno since ANNO 1602 and I can say that my experience with the latest release has been an enjoyment rollercoaster. Many of the old mechanics have been removed or changed and admittedly I was mad at first. But as I took the time to play the game the new or changed mechanics started to make some semblance of sense. The first thing that caught my attention was the initial lack of farms you can attach to plantations. But as you played the game you unlock rare materials that you use to build additional farm modules to the plantation, increasing its productivity past 100% and making it more cost effective than building a second plantation. It around this time I realized that Anno 2205 is focused more on space management and economy, and I enjoy it. The game might seem dumb in the temperate zone where there are no restrictions on where you can build and space is relatively plentiful, but when you go to the Tundra and the Moon, the game gets interesting.

In these locations you are limited to where you can build. Not in the traditional sense where you are limited by land, but also by heat in the Tundra and shielding on the Moon. Your factories, in the Tundra, give off heat which your residence need, otherwise they will not inhabit the building. In place of the traditional method of building your cities in huge blocks and production complexes separately, you need to figure out how to build your production and shelter together in order to maximize the amount of people you can host. And on the Moon is changes again. You need to shield all your buildings from space debris. Now you have the issue of building and powering these awkwardly shaped shield generators to protect your buildings. Not only do you have to worry about shielding your building on the Moon, you have to fund all the production on the Moon and OMFG is it expensive.

To afford building and upkeep on the moon you need to expand your taxable population in the Temperate zone, and they consume a lot of material. If they are not happy they will not pay as much. Now you have to pay for shipping from the Tundra for the population’s demands which costs money. And having a positive income can be difficult at times, let alone a high positive income. So to build on the Moon you need to wait until you have enough tangible wealth to actually build. So why not kill some time with combat missions? Set your economy to a surplus and take a half an hour clearing out a hostile zone. You gain experience to unlock new ships and get rare materials to upgrade your factories. If you want to play the military missions on a harder difficulty for more rewards you are strongly recommended to increase your fleet’s level, which costs money. I am constantly moving between locations expanding and optimizing my economy trying to get to the next phase of the game. I feel like there is a lot going on for this game and it is quite possible that if all the old mechanics were in place with the new mechanics, the game would be too slow and no one would want to grind on a single player game.

What can the game do to improve? Bring back the shipyard. It is pleasant that the ships are “free” in the game, but there should be the option to build the ships used for trade and combat. If you could build transport ships, trade would be easier. It becomes a huge expense for your economy to pay 200c for every 20 stack of product shipped between the temperate and tundra zone. It costs 3000c for every 20 stack for the transport to and from the Moon! Giving the player the option to use their own ships to move as much product as possible on a single route should be brought back into the game. As far as Military ships, this can solve several problems at once. First in makes the ships you lose more valuable since you had to pay for those ships to be built in the first place. Secondly, it makes the rare material slower to gain and more valuable since you need to pay for the ships to get the material. After a few visits to the hostile zone I have maxed out my rare materials, and I could do it because it did not cost me more than a few upgrades to win the engagements.

The Co-op and Multiplayer needs to come back. Ubisoft, this function has been a part of the game series forever and you need to stop cutting corners. Additionally, the cost is too high. If everything that was in the season pass DLC was in the game at Launch, then it would be worth $50; at launch. Recommending this game to another person, I highly suggest waiting until there is a handsome discount on the game. If you can pick up the game and season pass for $20, pounce on it. It is not a bad game contrary to community’s attacks on it. It needs some free add-ons and hot fixes, but it is visually beautiful and still a fun game to play despite the change in game mechanics.

reviewText:
Conclusion
Anno 2205 contains all of the elements from previous Anno titles, improved upon and streamlined, whilst cutting out some of the annoying micro-management pains, and problems with giving the player the right information at the right time.  You still get the piecing together of the familiar production chain to make better stuff, to make better stuff, etc. all in aid of attracting higher taxed citizens to fund your off-world colonies.  It is still as complex as Anno 2070, but the interface provides the information you care about in such a way that it feels less frustrating trying to balance and juggle all of these things.  In Anno 2070 I almost never felt on top of the balancing act, but in Anno 2205 I very much feel this way... some of the time... then it all tips again (because I've started a new colony on the Moon, or built on a new island in the Arctic), and I need to re-balance the scales again.

It is a thoroughly enjoyable and satisfying, (not to mention beautiful), city building, planning, and resource management game suitable for players new to the series as well as veterans, however it does need a few hours invested into it to unlock all of the complexities and can seem very simplified at first glance.

Those giving it a bad review after just a couple of hours have quite clearly not spent enough time with the game to find out that YES, it does include storage, and YES it does include modular production plants, farms, power, mining etc. amongst all the other familiar systems from Anno 2070, for example. They are just hidden away under a couple of hours of gameplay in order to not completely overwhelm new players to the series... and personally I think this is a really great implementation of how to do a tutorial of sorts within the game itself whilst actually playing.


Full review
City building:
There are 3 different climates within Anno 2205, Temperate, Arctic, and the Moon.  Each climate is split into 3 zones, giving 9 total zones where it's possible to build cities/colonies, (your first in each climate is free, and you can purchase the others later on for huge sums of hard cash to add end-game longevity).  On first starting the game, you get to pick one of the Temperate zones by reviewing each different map, consisting of multiple islands and one special monument option for each.  I chose the zone which could get the electric dam monuments as I know how power generation in Anno can be a real killer of your profits (and it turns out this was a very wise choice!).

You are essentially walked through your journey by the familiar mission layout on the upper-left corner of the screen.  This contains all the information you need about your main task, and sub-tasks, without shoving a tutorial in your face if you want to just get on with your own thing.  I really love this and I think it is a good and smooth experience for familiar Anno players, as well as newbies.

It turns out that the Temperate zone tends to be your profitable zone early-game, and you need it to fund Arctic and Moon zones which sap all your cash until much later in development.

The worrying moment...
Now this is the point where I believe a lot of the negative reviews are coming from... it appears after the first couple of hours that there is over simplification to this version of Anno.  There doesn't appear to be storage, there doesn't appear to multiple add-ons to farms and production facilities to boost production etc. there doesn't appear to be island trading, (all islands in the same zone partially share resources), and there doesn't appear to be any fleet or combat!  At face value within the first hour or two, it seems like these things are gone... OH HOW WRONG FIRST IMPRESSIONS CAN BE!!

As soon as you start diving into the next few hours of this game, you soon start seeing all of these complexities showing up in their vastly more streamlined implementations.  The game turns into a mixture of familiar Anno, SimCity, and Command and Conquer, but every element fits perfectly into this strange cocktail.

Supply and Demand vs. storage
Firstly, the resource counter only shows + or - numbers for production and demand.  This is a simplified view, yes, however a brief hover of the mouse over each resource shows the total in storage, and although we had to build more storage containers in Anno 2070, you soon realise how utterly pointless it is storing these goods... and all you really care about is producing just enough to meet your citizens' demands without overproducing so much that you're wasting maintenance money.  I really love this, and it takes the player's mindset away from meaninglessly hoarding tons and tons of resources to fine-management of your production chains.

Naval Combat and rare resources
Then you unlock the combat missions.  Basically you get told there is a crisis somewhere on the globe, you pick which difficulty you'd like to play the mission on, then you load into a totally new zone (map) where you sail around with your fleet blowing the living daylights out of any enemy that so much as gets in your way.  This combat feels very trivial at first, and it is.  You can lure enemies into mines, ambush them on their patrol paths, plan your route of attack to reach their weak points etc.  However, once you start doing these missions later on the harder difficulties, it actually does get quite a bit more challenging and you need to use all of these tactics to your advantage.  The other thing to note is that you soon realise clearing the entire map of enemies is a bit of a waste of time.  You end up taking all 3 sub-missions at the very start of the map, as well as turning on the elusively hidden feature to show all the resource buildings on the minimap (this should be shown by default imo).  These are your real objectives, as they are your source of the rare resources which you desperately need in the city building part of the game.

The eureka moment
These rare resources are then taken out of the combat missions when you succeed and are used to upgrade your factories and production buildings!  I had first built several farms and power plants around thinking This is way over simplified" and then upon doing this first mission and seeing how the modules worked I suddenly had a eureka moment where it all made sense suddenly! (and I immediately had to use the awesome new "move building" feature ;) haha).

Trading
Trading doesn't need to happen within the same zone/map in Anno 2205
date: (they share all resources and workforce automatically).  Trading starts to happen shortly after you colonise the Arctic in another zone and this is where your inter-dependencies come into play.  You will need to produce some goods in the Temperate zones to send to Arctic or Moon zones
recommended: and all variations therein.  This is necessary to increase the happiness of your populations to get them to upgrade to the next level (and then want even more difficult to obtain goods).\n\nThe trading happens much more fluidly than in Anno 2070 by having the player simply choose a trade good
hoursPlayed: the start and end of the route
voteText: and how much to send.  Simple but effective
helpfulPercent: and less annoying micromanagement.  Again
votesHelpful:
all the info is shown in one place easy to see and modify without deleting trade routes and worrying about boats being shot by pirates (*looks at Anno 2070*).

Overall verdict
My overall verdict is very positive on this game.  The first couple of hours felt a little lacking
votesTotal: but it soon unlocked its full potential and now I'm off fending for myself
votesFunny: trying to balance my colonies against my main settlement
commentsCount: and looking forward to unlocking new zones to build in fresh
column16: as well as work towards getting all of the monuments going.  Anno 2205 is a very cool and sleek new addition to the Anno series."

reviewText:
Anno 2205 has taken a different direction than its predecessors, and I think that decision was needed to keep the series great. However the game feels lacking in terms of randomized challenges. This is its biggest flaw in my opinion.

As a player I want to feel a sense of adventure, and that requires randomness at some level. This game doesn't provide much of that, even on the hardest difficulty. It is as challenging as previous Anno games if played on a high difficulty, which was a concern I had before launch. But it can certainly be easy for all newcomers to the series too. But what is completely lacking is the randomness of discovering an unforeseen problem and dealing with it. That is such a necessity in gaming. Natural disasters and rival corporations provided this previously, and I would be fine if they took one out, but not both. To me, this game without randomness is like food without salt. Sure, the food is fantastic, but I don't want to keep eating it. It will get old much more quickly than it should, and it won't have the replayability that I need.

Pros (in order of strength):
The graphics
Multi-session gameplay
Accessability for newcomers
Management of a city's resources
Music

Cons:
Lack of features (randomness)
Combat
Lack of compelling goals
Story (Campaign)
Linear Gameplay

The thing I love most about this game is the multi-session gameplay. It works so well and so easily -- it's something I always wanted in Anno. I can't praise this design enough. I will easily put 100 hours into my corporation, and I think I could spend 100 more on optimization, solely because of this feature. The modular buildings make the gameplay much more strategic than previous Anno games, although more could be done to make this aspect of gameplay more valuable. Furthermore, and perhaps most importantly, this is a true Anno game. It retains much of the feelings I had for the previous games. It is complex, strategic, beautiful, and addictive. It would definitely be the best Anno game in the series if the criticisms I have listed were resolved in some fashion.

Specifically combat I want to mention because this seems to be a mixed bag. Personally I love the new combat system... if it were a tech demo of the new combat system. As a finished product it feels very incomplete. It reminds me of the RTS games I love, like Sins of a Solar Empire or Age of Empires. But there's no variety -- no randomness that I spoke of above. I played it once at each difficulty setting and that's all I'd care to do for now. I love that you have abilities to use now to help your ships in combat (1404 and 2070 had this concept but it is better implemented here). I just wish there were more of a point to it beyond grinding for resources and xp.

Many reviews I have read are unfair and go beyond the scope of critising this game. I have had trouble with Uplay when I played 2070 around 2 years ago. It stopped me from playing the game completely for a long period of time. But, that experience in no way affected my decision to buy this game. Uplay has been perfect so far with 2205. Lack of multiplayer may be a criticism for the direction of the series, but it is not a valid criticism of this game. I have used multiplayer in 2070, and it was fun, but it would not work the same way in 2205 if it had it. A different concept for multiplayer would have to be established for this game, and I'm guessing that is why they chose not to include the feature. I would also argue that no feature is dumbed down in this game. They simply took out tedious micromanaging that I can't believe anyone would consider a strength of the past games.

When it comes down to price, I don't see how this game is worth $60 or $80. I payed $80 and I'm glad I did, but for a lot of people it may not seem worth it. $30-40 is the price I would value it at.

The conclusion: I would bet that most people would enjoy 2070 more, but if they added some much needed features, this game (or its sequel) will definitely be the best of the series. For now, it remains on par with 1404 and 2070.

(I will continue to update my review as I get further into the endgame. Thanks for reading my review.)

reviewText:
I know many people aren't too fond of this rendition of the Anno series - mainly long time supporters of the series from what I can see. My first Anno game was 2070. After playing that for some 300+ hours (+ many more offline and not recorded), I went back and played every single Anno game for the PC. I honestly think Anno 1404 was the best Anno of the series and still do (I have probably 400 hours or more of offline time in it), even with 2205 out. 2070 and 2205 stand a fair bit apart on terms of my overall liking of the 3 Anno games mentioned thus far.

What I like thus far:

- Graphics. Holy crap, they're excellent. Though, the game lags a bit on my setup so perhaps there could be a bit more optimisation done. I have noticed some spelling errors and grammatical mistakes in the game. I understand that at least, given that the Anno series of games generally are German-made. Thus, translations or second-language barriers are met. The night lights in cities are also quite nice!

- Music. Excellent, like all Anno games. Sound effects are good too.

- Ease-of-use. Surprisingly, I like that 2205 was easier to pick up than 2070 and 1404. A few of my friends don't understand how to play Anno, so this gives me hope that they can understand it! The UI is clean and easy to understand.

- Variety of land types. No, I'm not talking about the 3x3x3 system. I'm taking about the fact that you can inhabit the moon, the arctic and temperate regions. I heard talks of an expansion for Mars coming for this game in the future.

- 2070 references and sights. Drones, deep sea hunters, voices. The Ark. EVE.

- Balance and tune. Logistics between what buildings need and produce is easy to understand so you don't go overboard and rack up unnecessary maintenance costs.

- Modular buildings. They got this aspect right, like SimCity 2013. Having a fully upgraded building will be better than multiple unupgraded ones. I also love that the other modules can reduce your maintenance/energy/workforce use.

- Sector projects. All of them are pretty dandy to have. After completing the resource generation ones in the arctic and temperate (graphene and petrochemicals), I am now on the sector to rebuild the dam.

What I dislike or miss:

- Overall amount of islands on the map and map size overall. I loved the huge maps in 1404. 2070 was a bit meh in that regard for me too.

- Why can't I go into the menu and play a continuous game like 1404 or 2070? While I do like the concept of the company you made... if they integrated it in such a way like Anno 2070 with the ark and profile, it could be so much better.

- Duration. I feel that this game won't keep me as enthralled as 1404 or 2070. I pulled a 28 hour and a 25 hour stint in 1404 and 2070, respectively, with friends online/over LAN.

- Is workforce even necessary? It's too easy to have a lot of it, and thus, not worry about or manage it. It is a bit more worrying in the very early game, though... but that's about it. The same thing can be said for transportation of the goods. However, I do like the fact that it makes sense.

- Why are all the goods automatically shared in the sector you're playing without the need for a ship from island to island? In the temperate areas with bridges, I get it... I miss the aspect of building ships and moving goods around. It gave me more incentive to make a large island dedicated ONLY for the production of goods, thus leaving other large islands to support populations. You can do this still in 2205, mind you... but it just doesn't feel as right as 1404 or 2070.

- Crisis sectors are meh. They should be done like they were in 2070. They're too easy. I would LOVE to be able to build a settlement in those sectors and fend off the enemy faction, like 2070 as well.

- There just doesn't seem to be many problems to solve, compared to 2070 (Ecobalance, disasters, health/fire, etc...).

- The lack of online multiplayer is one thing may people griped about. Ubisoft probably gets that by now. Again, the aspect of having a company is absolutely perfect for online and competing in friendly ways. I do understand why they said they removed multiplayer in the first place. I did spend a bit of my time either critiquing cities my friend/s built (and bombing them), or waiting for them to catch up so we could defeat enemies together (Keto, Strindburg, Hector - all on hard).

While it may seem like I have more negative points than positive ones, I do have a bit of faith 2205 will get better as it goes through DLC and expansions. I do like the game overall, and on a scale of 0 - 100, it is about 75. 1404 is a 95 and 2070 is a 90 on that scale. I also have faith future installments will build on the good things 2205 did and bring back the good aspects of previous installations (with that being said, I would LOOOOOOOOOOOVE an Anno to take place between 1850 and 1920).

Would I encourage people to buy the game? For hardcore Annoholics or micromanagers, or city builder lovers, absolutely. For anyone not relagated to those groups in the extreme... I would say wait for the first sale, then get it. By then, some DLC may be out to build upon the game as well.

I will also update my review as I play more of the game.

reviewText:
I've played for over 9 hours now and while I would not consider myself a powerplayer in previous anno games, I HAVE been playing the Anno series since Anno 1503. I have seen a whole lot of < 3.0 hour playtime reviews and I felt compelled to leave my own thoughts after playing nearly nonstop since launch.

A number of things have changed since 2070 but I think that on the whole it's for the better. That's not to say that I dont think they couldn't improve some things.

-Random maps are gone which is really sad and is one of my only gripes at this time. More than anything This needs to come back or give us a map editor so that we can make more variations. 3 variations of each of the 3 climate types is really not enough.

-They've added a Move Building button which I've seen a lot of people complain about but I absolutely love. It was annoying as hell to need to tear down my carefully contructed factory complex just to move the entire thing over 1 tile. To be fair, there should be some small cost at least, but its hardly the end of the world.

-Combat mission maps are where all of the combat takes place in 2205 as opposed to having to defend your islands in 2070 and earlier games. It can be a nice change of pace from building but I cant help but feel like the combat section is not meaty enough to warrant the change from the traditional anno formula. That said, it is still useful as a place to get the ancillary resources that you'll need to build upgrades.

-All buildings are now required to be on the same road network as your docks. THANK YOU! I have always hated the 'build a warehouse in the middle of the forest' approach to the resource management. It lead to ugly settlements with no sense of order.

Graphically the game looks nice but does run a tad laggy at times on my 770. But in a singleplayer game like this, that is hardly a dealbreaker.

Yes this game uses UPlay. That should not have been a surprise to anyone. Honestly, I've never had a single issue with UPlay in all the time that I've had it. So for me, its kindof... whatever. I'd prefer to not need it but I couldnt care less.

reviewText:
Full Review - Follow-up of First Impressions Review
Hello people, I am writing this review because I am seeing a lot of negativity, which personally does not make sense to me. This game has a lot to offer, even though there are some let-downs.


First off

THIS IS NOT ANNO 2070! If you are expecting Anno 2070 with a Moon expansion and a fresh coat of graphics, you will be dissapointed. I am reviewing this game as a stand-alone, without comparing it to previous titles. Also, I have previously only played 2070, so it is up to you to judge my credibility. Here we go:

Pros & Cons:

Pros
- Great Visuals
- Long-term Gameplay
- Continuos Gameplay
- Various Difficulty Setting

Cons
- Price ($$)
- Combat
- Unengaging Campaign
- Hardware Guzzler
- No Manual Save

Corporations

You create your own Corporation. You answer to yourself and only yourself. You are guided by the World Council, but ultimately what you do is UP TO YOU.
As you progress, your Corporation levels up, and competes with the other NPC Corporations. Eventually you can surpass them and buy their land (sector) for your own use. In the mean time, represenatives from various Corporations will offer projects to help you develop different benefits, such as improved logistics.

Sandbox VS Campaign and General Gameplay

While it is true that there is no separate Sandbox" mode
date: the main game IS the sandbox. Yes
hoursPlayed: in the form of quests/tasks you have to complete in order to progress your population and advance to the next tiers. Whether you breeze through the story and start over afterwards
voteText: or spend a whole calendar year in the same game
helpfulPercent: is entirely up to you. Also as far as building your city
votesHelpful: as long as you are connected to islands (Temperate Zone) via huge New York style bridges
votesTotal: or have a Warehouse on an island (Arctic)
votesFunny: you are free to build your Residential Areas and Factories WHEREVER they can fit. The only exception to that are the mines and the water resources (Energy
commentsCount: fish etc)
column16: which are restricted to specific locations
column17:
but that is not necessarily bad. It makes management of space more simple.

As you advance your civilization you can expand to two more regions. Here is a summary of all regions you will eventually have access to (in order of progression):

Temperate Region - Main region

This is where you will spend most of your time
column18: because it is where your population is most dense and this region has the most resources. The region has a warm climate and a series of islands you can connect via the long bridges
column19:
mentioned above.

Arctic

As you progress
column20: eventually you will need resources/goods you cannot acquire from the Temerate Region and you will need to expand to the Arctic. Much like the Teperate Region
column21:
the Arctic has a seres of islands that you can expand to with the use of warehouses.

The Moon

The moon is the final frontier in Anno 2205. Much like the Arctic
column22: the moon has resources you cannot obtain anywhere else. The region has a series of craters that you gain control of through warehouses
column23:
like in the Arctic.

IMPORTANT:

Have you ever wondered why we never went back to the moon? (Humans) Well
column24: one answer could be... Because it is VERY EXPENSIVE. If you go to the Moon too early
column25: or as soon as you are able to

column28: and then it will be rough for a while

column30: Arctic
column31: and Moon

has three regions (maps). Once you get your initial region you will need to buy the rest from other Corporations if you wish to exapnd further.

Two more zones are in the works. Check the DLC section on Steam or the main game website.

One problem however
column33: is that while the campaign can teach you how to advance your civilization

column35: you are supposed to advance your civilization
column36:
but you know that from the nature of Anno. The campaign does not reinforce your motivation to play what the game is all about.

Trade

Once you control multiple regions
column37: say one in the Temperate Zone
column39: as long as you develop the space port of each
column40: you can set up a trade route for resources between the two zones. You can also set how much resource to trade. Eventually you will also gain access to the World Market (Space Station)
column41:
where you can buy and sell resources.

Combat

While the focus of this game is city building and civilization development
column42: there is some combat involved. After all

column45: as far as when you do that

Visuals

reviewText:
I've played the hell out of 2070, and I'm very much enjoying 2205.  People posting reviews about the lack of 'depth' are mostly referring to the fact that you no longer have to download an external spreadsheet or calculator program to figure out how much of what you need to satisfy a given population.  You can, for the first time, use in-game feedback to figure out whether or not you're making enough widgets for your folks.  Further, while its true that the building of fiels is gone, the building of modules provides the same tetris gameplay with dramatically increased effect.  The alt-tab savings alone are astonishing.  If you combine that with the fact that your main population centers require more different goods than ever before, and the fact that you have 3 totally seperate production areas (as opposed to 2 in 2070 and 1404), the depth has by any reasonable measure increased.

Many of the reviews have also not finished the intro/campaign portion and hit the wall that is large-scale lunar construction.  It's bloody expensive to build things on the moon, and doing so requires massive expansion of your primary settlement, which in trun requires expansion of your production base and so on. You will be constantly expanding your population and production in a very fun version of the red queen's race, just as it should be.  U-play is also a non-issue for me, worked perfetly first time and continues to do so.

TL:DR Buy this game.  Unless your favorite parts of Anno games past is the parts you spent alt-tabbing

reviewText:
Edit: My feeling of the game remains unchanged as time goes on. I understand why die-hard fans of Anno may be disappointed, but the game is still very fun in its own way.

I've found Anno 2205 to be extremely enjoyable. I've sunk about 5 hours in it today and I loved every minute of it.

Compared to Anno 2070, I feel that the gameplay experience is a lot smoother. It's always extremely clear what kind of material you need. The buildings' area of operation are much less restrictive. While a house can be out of range, now the community buildings are considered a resource in themselves. This enables the player to be more creative with his cities without being punished too harshly because of building placement. In my humble opinion, this is a huge positive change.

To the people that say that trading has been removed from the game... It's still there, but now you don't micro-manage the most inconsequential trade routes with boats. Now you just have to keep an eye on how resources flows between your colonies and make sure your production can handle the demand. It's an important change considering you are not trading between islands but between different maps completely.

Talking about the colonies... Having three biomes with completely different play-styles is really fun. Switching between each one adds variety to the game. And they are pretty.

The campaign integration is, in my opinion, very well done so far. Maybe it won't work for everyone, but I think it's a good way of making the world feel real. Honestly, I could hardly bother doing the Anno 2070 campaign because I found it tedious. Here, it feels like a suggestion. Hey
recommended: I know you're busy but could you help us not dying pretty please kthx? Or just keep doing your thing
hoursPlayed: whatever." While the Lunar terrorists are a bit unbelievable
voteText: at least they are menacing villains with a really cool leader.\n\nIt's too early for me to give a verdict or talk about the re-playability. However
helpfulPercent: based on my experience so far
votesHelpful: I am very pleased with my purchase.\n\nTLDR; I really liked Anno 2070
votesTotal: but I feel that Anno 2205 is a better game so far."

reviewText: This is the first time since the release of the very first game Anno has changed. 1602, 1507, 1701 and 1404 share not only the same game mechanics but even icons. Icons, Coral. Even the previous futuristic sky-fyish instalment Anno 2070 was pretty much the same Dawn of Discovery (which I still like the most, mostly because of the Pirat, that guy was super cool). So Anno has changed. Some wil like it, some will not. The biggest change is that now you need to control not the amount of your resources but their flow through the three available regions. Now about the problems in a productivity chain you'll be noticed imidiately by some smart AI, and not with the blazes of a rebellion because of missing books (seriously guys). Overall the game may seem simplified compared to the previous ones for some, but its a point for long discussions for nerdy fans. There is no mutiplayer, by the way (who cares?!).\n\nOh, and I've found out we'll get tundra and orbit as new regions in the upcoming DLCs. Orbit!

reviewText:
First off, anyone who has played less than 5 - 6 hours has no business writing a review. I too thought for the 1st 2 hours that it was too simply but I was wrong. Once you get in to the multiple sectors it's becomes VERY challenging. Once you let go of the old Anno UI and realize that everything from the previous Anno is here, just presented in a different way you begin to apprciate the complexity. No more 3rd party calculators about how much production you need based on population. Anno now tells you what we all used to calculate out of game (+1 over production, -2 under production, etc).

Second, if you're a previous Anno player select the Expert level at the beginning. That will provide you the challenge you need. Also, right now, LET GO of your experience from prevoius Anno games. That's not a bad thing, but if you just keep comparing this to Anno 2070 you'll never be able to appreciate or enjoy the complexity and the complexity is very deep and real.

Thrid, not one negative review has even made it to the Moon and they want to talk about how it's a dissappointment? Wait until you're managing 3+ sectors and then write your review.

This is a must buy IMHO.

reviewText:
So this is the first review I have ever written.

This game is absolutely beautiful. Every aspect of this game is just amazing to look at, especially the Lunar and Arctic maps.

The game play is very nice. With the hours i have on Anno 2070 I am very happy with 2205. The devs. took a fresh take on a fun game and made it very cool. They took the micromanagement of the storage system and moved it into more of a macro management style. I have to send resources to my Arctic and Lunar maps to allow them to grow. Any surplus resources can be sold to the global market for extra cash. (Beware when you get to the lunar map. Buildings get VERY Expensive.)  The ability to choose the boosts is unlocked after you progress a ways into the game. You can help decide which boost you get by voting on it. I have yet to see any disasters occur yet(Fires, Disease outbreak ect.)

I do feel that the combat systems need some work. When upgrading ships I would like to know what it is that I am upgrading. Just adding a chevron next to the ship does feel lazy. The combat system does feel like a bit of a mini-game. Which is understandable considering this is not a true RTS game but I feel it could be executed better.

Overall I would absolutely recommend this game, however do not buy it if your expecting a regurgitation of Anno 2070.

Pros:
Beautiful graphics.
Enjoyable, progression
Community marketplace
Creative mechanics for new regions
Resource management between maps feels intuitive.

Cons:
Combat feels quite boring.
Building Hab modules in arctic feels clunky(too far away from heat source when the building is >50% inside a heat source)
Cant choose which ships i get to take into combat.

reviewText:
I'd like to consider the negative reviews and their general crticisms of this entry in the Anno series.  First of all, I would disregard any negative review with less than an hour or two players, because these are people who had their minds made up to begin with.


So, the common complaints:


uPlay:
I don't see this as anything more than a launch platform these days.  Anno does not have Ubisoft's always on" DRM and does not require a perpetual internet connection.  I don't blame people for disliking the bloat that is uPlay
date: but I think it is unfair to give a negative review to a game as a whole just because of the way you open it on your computer.  Not to mention
hoursPlayed: I click Play on Steam
voteText: and uPlay opens and launches the game without any further clicks.  It also then syncs my save and minimizes uPlay when I am finished
helpfulPercent:
so I don't even notice it on this title.


No multiplayer:
I suppose that this is a legitimate gripe for those for whom multiplayer is an important feature.  I can't relate to that and I think the vast majority of Anno players did not play multiplayer.  I am guessing that the developers knew this and focused their budget on making the best single player experience that they could.


"Dumbing Down" of Supply Chains:  I think this is a narrow minded complaint that fails to account for the new features and changes that mitigate the simplification of supply chains.

This is definitely still an incredibly complex game if you are looking for efficiency.

In Anno 2070
votesHelpful: you would make a change to a chain
votesTotal: and then you would have to wait 30 seconds or a minute or two to be able to see if that change had the effect you intended.  You can now see this instantly.  This gives more time to actually play the game and less time staring at a number to see if it goes up
votesFunny: down
commentsCount: or stays the same.  Those 30 seconds add up over time.  Not having to check out a wiki for the most efficient layouts is also a blessing
column16: as efficiency is going to be based more on how your personal city is set up than in how well you can copy a layout from the internet.  The "logistics" resource does a fantastic job of replacing the old way of making sure to have a supply depot nearby.\n\nIf you were a player like me who really liked fiddling with the fields
column17: but always felt you were being less efficient if you didn't look online to see what other people had come up with
column18:
you may really enjoy the module feature they came up with for this game.  You get the "Tetris" style building placement gameplay while having more flexibility overall.

Not to mention one of the best changes:  You can click and drag any building to move it around for FREE.

________________________________________________________________

All in all
column19: I completely disagree with the negative reviews and feel this is more than just a satisfactory entry in the Anno series.  I expect to play this for an unreasonable amount of time and recommend it to anyone who likes city building games."

reviewText:
I've played all the Anno games to date - each one building and getting better. I was pretty skeptical of this one from the onset but thought I'd give it a try since the others in the franchise did not fail to deliever.

The game is obviously beautiful, with lots of different biomes to build in and different supply routes. Mixed in with some military optional quest the game seems to be fairly robust, something that I think will only grow over time.

The soundtrack, not something I care about often, is actually quite good.

Overall I think the game is pretty solid - if you dismiss the usual Ubisoft hatred and gnashing of teeth (some of it is warranted) and look at the game with an honest and open mind, I think you will find a beautiful fleshed out game, that will provide hours of fun for any city-building fan.

reviewText:
This is a great game, just not at the moment...
The negativity surrounding Anno 2205 is not unfounded, from the change of heart to allow Beta access for pre-order customers, to releasing a Season Pass with no content. The most sour taste has been left with the feeling of an unfinished game, to be completed, in part, by the gradual release of DLC's.

Anno 2205 at the moment is the foundation of a great game, the UI's been simplified and the interactions are somewhat easier compared to the previous Anno's. I find at times that it's been dumbed down a bit, perhaps to make it more accessible to a wider audience. I do fear that this will put off some of the more die hard fans out there.
It's a visually beautiful game, with excellent graphics and attention to detail, even down to zooming into buildings (I encourage you to take a look at some of the Lunar ornamental buildings).

I get annoyed at the repetitiveness of, well pretty much all of the missions, summed up by find x of this" and "destroy that". The military missions aren't much better! I do like the separation of the military missions to the main game. I miss the ability to take over other territories

reviewText:
After nearly 60 hours of play time my impression is definitely positive.

I started playing Anno 2205 on the middle difficulty setting and it felt somewhat challenging at first but by the time I finished the tutorial storyline I was confident in my building techinques and easily maintained multiple profitable export routes.

The hardest difficulty setting is tough because money comes much less easily.  Instead of being able to rely on keeping your employees content and have them passively generate all the money you will ever need , profitable export to the world markets becomes much more important.  And since producs fluctuate (sometimes quite wildly) in value in accordance with the vagaries of supply and demand, yesterday's most golden egg can quickly become tommorrow's dead weight.

Anno 2205 is more streamlined than the previous version, eliminating some of the micromanagement of that game.  No longer must every island have to balance its own population of workers; in 2205 they have learned how to commute where needed.

There is also no need to micromange trade routes: goods flow automatically within the same sector and trade between sectors does not require ship building. In fact ships have been removed as buildable units for both trade and war.  Instead combat occurs in its own, optional sector as a somewhat separate minigame where the ships you own are automatically available at the start of the map.  Larger and larger trade ships become available at higher corporation levels, at progessively increasing mainteance costs.  Both of these are welcome changes.

So what exactly are sectors? It's how Anno 2205 makes a global corporation actually feel like a world player.  Each sector has a theme, and there are three of them: temperate sector, arctic sector and lunar sector.  The temperate sector plays most similarly to Anno 2070 with islands, employee residences, public buildings, factories and natural resources waiting to be exploited for fun and profit.

The arctic sector is where the scientists live and it's a bit different. Heat is generated by factories in a radius around the building.  Residences must be built within that radius.  This gives the layout of your arctic city a distinct feeling and gives rise to an interesting variation on optimal layouts compared to the temperate sector.  Maintenance costs are a bit higher than the temperate sector so a little more care has to be given to choosing when and what to build.

The final sector, the moon, is different again.  The moon is a harsh environment and buildings must be protected by forcefields due to the  constant danger of meteor strikes. It is also the most expnsive sector from high construction costs, to steep mainteance expenses, to the mostly costly transfer routes back down to Earth or the world market.  This means that unlike your temperate sector where life is easy you will need to carefully manage exactly what buildings you need and exactly how much population you are willing to support. Simply expanding your base willy nilly to every corner of your chosen crater is a recipe for swift bankruptcy.

I am really enjoying Anno 2205. I have over 400 hours played on its predecessor.  The new types of sectors are interesting and challenging in their own rights.  While negatives effects like pollution and bad weather have been removed I am not too sorry to see them go.  I look forward to seeing if the newest version will hold my interest for just as long.

reviewText:
This game is awesome... It can be even greater. How did i get to that conclusion. Well

First all the stuff i expected to be there but was not. I played Anno2070 for many hours.

- No logistics management. Now its just numbers. No trucks; No flying Drones picking up goods from production.
- Military is now minigames (Thats great for me. I just wanted to build cities and productionlines.)
- No Mountain destroying mining operations. (I thought the mines would slowly eat the mountains like a destructable environment like thing.
- No transport ships taking flying from the earth to the moon thing. No more transport routes like with the ships in earlier versions. I wanted rockets like those ships flying between planets. I wanted to build on spheres (like in planetary annihilation) not flat maps. With a cool 3-stage futuristic rockets blasting off from the earth to the moon and back everytime goods are delivered.
- I wanted to build a spacestation (But thats coming i guess, in the season pass).

Now for the good stuff.
+ Something new. Its not a clone of the earlier games with new skins on the units.
+ I build a moonbase that supplies energy to every sector I have on earth.
+ I got environments that is so beautefull I can look at it again and again and think wow.
+ I got factories with the most awesome animations.
+ I got productionlines and meaningfull storylines to fill up the wait time to generate money.

I got a game that is not the end but potentially could be the colonization of the solar system and I can fantasize about it.
I want to colonize and terraform Mars.
I want to build cities in the skies of Venus.
Build large solar plants on mercury and cities on vertical walls in canyons to protect them from the sun and radiation.
I want inhabit the moons of jupiter; Io, Europa (Under the ice cities and production), Callisto and Ganymede.
I want to go to Titan and live among the rings of Saturn
Build a spacestation in the gravity equilibrium of Pluto and its moon Charon. And colonies on the surface of them both.
I want to be able to stand on one planet and see the actual buildings I build on the planet, and rocket ships coming back and forth between them. (No shortcuts).

I am recommending the game. PLease don't let us down. Make this game as awesome as it can be.

reviewText:
After nearly 60 hours of play time my impression is definitely positive.

I started playing Anno 2205 on the middle difficulty setting and it felt somewhat challenging at first but by the time I finished the tutorial storyline I was confident in my building techinques and easily maintained multiple profitable export routes.

The hardest difficulty setting is tough because money comes much less easily.  Instead of being able to rely on keeping your employees content and have them passively generate all the money you will ever need , profitable export to the world markets becomes much more important.  And since producs fluctuate (sometimes quite wildly) in value in accordance with the vagaries of supply and demand, yesterday's most golden egg can quickly become tommorrow's dead weight.

Anno 2205 is more streamlined than the previous version, eliminating some of the micromanagement of that game.  No longer must every island have to balance its own population of workers; in 2205 they have learned how to commute where needed.

There is also no need to micromange trade routes: goods flow automatically within the same sector and trade between sectors does not require ship building. In fact ships have been removed as buildable units for both trade and war.  Instead combat occurs in its own, optional sector as a somewhat separate minigame where the ships you own are automatically available at the start of the map.  Larger and larger trade ships become available at higher corporation levels, at progessively increasing mainteance costs.  Both of these are welcome changes.

So what exactly are sectors? It's how Anno 2205 makes a global corporation actually feel like a world player.  Each sector has a theme, and there are three of them: temperate sector, arctic sector and lunar sector.  The temperate sector plays most similarly to Anno 2070 with islands, employee residences, public buildings, factories and natural resources waiting to be exploited for fun and profit.

The arctic sector is where the scientists live and it's a bit different. Heat is generated by factories in a radius around the building.  Residences must be built within that radius.  This gives the layout of your arctic city a distinct feeling and gives rise to an interesting variation on optimal layouts compared to the temperate sector.  Maintenance costs are a bit higher than the temperate sector so a little more care has to be given to choosing when and what to build.

The final sector, the moon, is different again.  The moon is a harsh environment and buildings must be protected by forcefields due to the  constant danger of meteor strikes. It is also the most expnsive sector from high construction costs, to steep mainteance expenses, to the mostly costly transfer routes back down to Earth or the world market.  This means that unlike your temperate sector where life is easy you will need to carefully manage exactly what buildings you need and exactly how much population you are willing to support. Simply expanding your base willy nilly to every corner of your chosen crater is a recipe for swift bankruptcy.

I am really enjoying Anno 2205. I have over 400 hours played on its predecessor.  The new types of sectors are interesting and challenging in their own rights.  While negatives effects like pollution and bad weather have been removed I am not too sorry to see them go.  I look forward to seeing if the newest version will hold my interest for just as long.

reviewText:
A very entertaining game despite the changes they did to the gameplay compared to the previous Anno games, such as:
Trade routes can no longer be operated between islands by boat
The battles are not developed in the same place where your city is placed only in specific places or areas
You cannot longer build ships, so there is no load limit on them, plus they cannot carry anything nor improvements.
Stores no longer exist as they had been in Anno 2070 but rather through logistics buildings and obviously more factories.
There is no longer an option diplomacy
And other features that I will discover  Despite the various changes that made the gameplay is still very fun, entertaining and with incredible graphics.

reviewText: Anno 2205 is a good game.  Not perfect and not everything it could be, but quite good.  It is also an expensive game, and for the amount of money there is only one thing wrong with it that turns it from a great game into merely a good one.  Yes, there are other issues, but one can always complain about something or wish for more in any great game.\n\nWhat really kills the quality of this game is the load times between different terrains.  You will need to switch back and forth between temperate, arctic, and lunar terrains in order to get the production balances correct and grow each sector.  The 15-20 second load times are simply unacceptable and make the city building experience much slower than it would otherwise have to be, particularly when you are playing on higher difficulty settings.  On a lower difficulty setting you might be able to overproduce in one sector in order to anticipate demand that will eventually come in another sector.  However, on higher difficulties the credits are scarcer and it's harder to keep the balance ticking upwards.  Thus, what harder" means is that you have to switch back and forth between sectors frequently

reviewText:
10 Hours in so far. Like it.

It is a change from Anno 2070, for sure, but I am overall liking this game. The naval combat mission are a nice change of apce from base maximizing.

There is still storage like before, but this time the obvious number is the amount that that particular material is increasing or decreasing, not the amount in storage.

There are resources that your building consume to maintain population or to create other resources, but there are also building materials that you use to build other buildings. There are a few resources that only cannot be created by a building. They are given quite freely from the naval missions and even once through Uplay Rewards.

There is no multiplayer. There is no sandbox mode. Just campaign. The maps are huge and you can have multiple maps.

The building and management aspect of the game is still my favorite aspect, even if it has seen an overall simplification. In my opinion, that simplification was much needed polish to game mechanics that took too long to gleam valuable info from or to perform, such as resource balancing and moving buildings.

I love the new modular building upgrade system. One of the best additions so far.

I am also digging the regions and the trade between them.

So far I have not seen any real threat the AI factions pose. I just see them as a type of leaderboard.

Not a single bug, although the game got a little bit laggy after 10 hours non-stop.

I waited for this game for months, and even bit the bullet when the Beta was stolen out from under us. Yeah, Uplay is a sad reality, but I didnt have any problems with it (the download was kinda slow though even on 100Mbps).

Overall, I am not dissapointed, although 60 bucks is a big pill to swallow for nearly any game. If you are undecisive, I would hope to see this on a winter sale or maybe cross your fingers for a free update or two. If all else fails, you can bet on DLC in the future to flesh out this game more.
