reviewText:
Only played a few hours so far but so far I am loving this game. The only part I don’t like (as a long time Anno player) is that you are limited to the campaign and nothing else. I like in the old games that you could change every aspect of the game so every time you played it was like a new game. now its just the campaign. don’t get me wrong the campaign offers options as well but not nearly as many as what I’m used to.

I love how stream lined the game is. Its easy to just pick it up and start playing. efficiency has changed a lot to. In the old game building placement meant everything you had to have an optimum layout for every item or you would be crushed in no time by an AI that was optimized. In this one placement isn’t as vital, there are ways to optimize and increase efficiency but in a different way from the old games.

There are a lot more changes to this title but I’ll leave it to you to find them out. Enjoy your trip to the moon.

reviewText:
People need to stop thinking this game was supposed to be Anno 2070. It's not. It was never supposed to be. It is it's own beast, and after playing almost all the way through, I've decided I like it.

Yes, I miss some aspects of the older games, but what it lost in detail, it gained in playability. By removing the burden of managing inventories, the game now lets you focus exclusively on balancing efficiency which, in my opinion, is what Anno is really all about. My decisions have almost immediate effects which, again, allow me to focus on building and advancing, rather than having to micro-manage the storage slots on a dozen different trading routes.

While I do miss being able to produce ships of my own and build defenses and all that, I again come back to the fact that this is just simply a different game and as it stands right now, doesn't suffer from the separation of building and combat.

If you're new to the Anno series, you'll love this game. If you're coming from 2070, leave your preconceptions at the door and I'm sure you'll love it as well.

reviewText:
I am prepared to give this game a recommendation, however one glaringly bad issue has sprung up that prevents me from recommending it at full price. However I'll get to that afterwards.

Let's get one thing straight, I do enjoy Anno 2205. The big complaints from people seem to be that it departs too far from the typical Anno formula, however I'm perfectly fine with that! I'd rather we get big changes than see the exact same game with a new coat of paint every few years *cough*2070*cough*. The game does lack the same freeform gameplay of the previous Anno's, this time focusing on 9 pre-determined sectors that you can switch to at any time (assuming you've unlocked them). So no more settling islands and exploring the world. Is it a little disappointing? Sure. But being able to get right into the game without too much hassle does help.

I don't want to spend too long talking about how I feel about the game as whole. Many of my thoughts are shared with other people, excluding the fact that I enjoy the more efficiency based gameplay over resource management. The big thing I've noticed however is game saving.

This game does use UPlay. And thankfully it doesn't seem to rely on it too heavily. Or so I thought.

Anno 2205 does NOT have manual save functionality. It is entirely reliant on UPlay Cloud Saving. I was however unaware of the save failing after my Internet went down as I was closing the game. I started up the game today to find over 4 hours of work had vanished.

So the question is, do I recommend this game? Yes, but ONLY if you have a stable internet connection AND you have enough room on your hard-drive for the game saves. Otherwise you will lose progress seemingly without warning.

SCORE: 7/10

TL;DR: This game is in my opinion a worthy successor to Anno 2070, however its issues with saving and very linear gameplay prevent it from getting a higher score. Wait until it goes on sale.

reviewText:
I've played anno 1404, 2070, and this one (of course)
Anno 1404 and 2070 were almost identical, apart from being in different eras. Highly enjoyed both.
Anno 2205 has some ups and downs, but overall I do enjoy the game.
It's far less reliant on tedious micro management of resources, supply lines, and trade routes between islands, which is nice.  You're not counting farms and calculating production based off eco rating to determine how many sushi joints you can build without running out of rice.
You build a farm, it makes 5 moon rocks, you expand it, it makes 10. End of story. Simple.
Which allows you to play across multiple maps, (which probably sucks for loading time on lower end systems) which is really cool.
Expansion into space was a neat feature, as well as the costly trade routes to get out there.
Not too many complaints; the questing is more like an annoying side-track quest, I'd like to see a return of underwater construction, and the game feels very linear. I'd like to see scenarios and open build again.
And then there's the combat; although the new system is interesting, it's also fairly.....disconnected. You fight on one map, build on another, the two never touch. There are no military threats in your own seas, which is odd. But your ships don't get better via tech, but rather by the number of battles you fight and money.
Not as many interesting ships, either. Like; there's no submarine that fires nukes at people.
Personal preference rules on the combat system, I like both, but kind of prefer the anno 2070 system.
Oh and also, no major world event vote for crap every 15 seconds bullcrap. Anno 2070 was clearly meant to be play at least once every 2 days, I do like not having my notification bar filled to the bring every time I log in lol

In the end, still like the game, still looking forward to DLC and how patches change the gameplay.

reviewText:
UDATE 15 hours in. http://i.imgur.com/wxQoK1r.jpg

Thank you Ubisoft for making my dream game to actual game. For years I imagined game where you run your own corporation in space and mine resources, what I did not imagine was little bit simcity elements mixed in but guess what it makes it even better.  This is just perfect game for me. Liked everything I have seen so far and I made it to the moon and my corporation is just starting. I see hundreds of hours gameplay in this. I liked Anno 2070 but I love Anno 2205! I love to concentrate on optimizing supply chains and manage my cities and bases to look gorgeous.

For hater reviews... There are still management and trading just different kind. You just need to play the freaking game, there are lot of depth in this game. Kinda overwhelming  actually towards endgame. There is ofcourse not actual end to this you can keep upgrading your corporation as long as you please. Game is pretty darn streamlined at beginning but gets to the point I believe even hardcore Anno fans should be satisfied but at same time makes for new comers easy to step in. Did you expect mechanics to be clone from Anno 2070 when there are now multiple planetary bodies involved? And isn't it good there will be loads of more Anno fans because start isn't complicated?

Temperate, Arctic and Moon give game lot of variablity to game. Totaly different settings on all of three places and different tactics. I bet new DLC's will make this variety even more versatile.

BTW runs well on high settings 1920x1200: Intel G3258 @4.5Ghz, 8GB DDR3, HD 7950 3GB.
No lag at all! After filling one region and being kinda on end game with easy mode still no lag to be seen. So if your PC is equal or better than mine you are good to on high settings!

Price is salty but game is sugary. Personally I can recommend Gold pack because it will add two whole new regions to play in game. I am truly awaiting orbit dlc to come because I wan't to already expand my corporation to space station/s. If its done such good quality as rest of the game it will be totally worth it. Keep in mind I am scifi fan who truly likes idea of colonization and space stations.

+ Awesome graphics. This game makes me calm just by looking at it and there are good amount of detail in every building and almost everything is moving. No dull just standing buildings.
+ Sounds are equally amazing. Awesome music and pretty good effects.
+ Multiple region gameplay is very well done unlike some other city builder game.
+ There are tons of stuff to do. I can say from my experience loads more on one gameplay than Anno 2070.
+ So much Scifi awesomeness!

- Carbage battlemechanics but makes good minigame when waiting resources to add up.
- Loading times between regions. Nothing too bad but very noticable (~5-15 seconds in my case)
- No multiplayer but there is resource trade system implemented and . (Personally I don't care about multiplayer missing never used it anyway when I am creative I am creative alone.)

reviewText:
BACKGROUND: Frequent player of the ANNO franchise, having logged just shy of 150 hrs in Anno 2070 and countless more in earlier installments.

VERDICT: Buy it.

REASONING: Those bashing ANNO 2205 for lack of complexity simply haven't played the game long enough.  While there are a few UI choices that hide the complexity in a not-as-great way, the game quickly ramps up into a multi-sector balancing act worthy of the franchise name.

Much like every previous entry, the story isn't exactly anything to write home about and side missions are meh, but that's not why you play an Anno game.  This has solid city-building despite the beginner-friendly start, and you get massive, pretty skylines for your trouble, with unique challenges per biome and sector.

It's not perfect, it's not 100% optimized, but the core is there and the game is still enjoyable 15 hours in.

reviewText:
Anno 2205 is a really good game. While it may be rather different from it's predecessors in the franchise, what it adds is more than enough to counter what it takes away in my opinion. Whilst I don't think it's worth spending the £54.99 on the gold edition (price at 20th January 2016), it's certainly worth picking up and giving a go if you were a fan or the previous games or city builders in general.

Combat was moved to specific locations in Anno 2205, and so they have specifically designed maps which sort of have a story built into them. It's not a very good story, but it's something. At times, having to defend against attackers in the building regions would be fun and prove rather challenging, but sometimes I find I just want to focus on building without having to worry about being attacked.

Managing multiple different building regions in different climates (Temperate, Arctic & The Moon), and having to transfer goods between them constantly creates an interesting challenge as you'll find that in order to advance in one region, you need to supply it with goods that can only be made in one of the other regions. Expanding to moon bases is an even bigger challenge than just the regions on the planet, as it needs a lot of materials from the other regions to operate and is massively expensive to the point where it could completely ruin you in-game economy if you aren't prepared for it or don't act quickly.

The main story is sort of average, with no huge twists or suprises. However it is a city builder / strategy game and so it was never going to have an amazing story like an adventure or an RPG game would have. It does the job good enough and introduces you to each new region type effectively.

The side-missions (or quests) that you get in each region can be rather repetitive, they're usually go find these things (and bring them back to us)" or "Use this drone we've given you to destroy some things." Also
date: the game kind of forces you to do them if you want to build modules (upgrades) for you buildings or even some certain buildings themselves. You can buy the resources thaat you need to do this
recommended: but it sometimes proves to be not enough.\n\nEach sector has it's own string of major side-missions that usually consist of 3 parts
hoursPlayed: with each part having 5 missions to complete. Some of these are like the other side-missions
voteText: like "go find these things" but can be a tad more complex
helpfulPercent: like having to drag around a kind of drone that tells you the direction you need to be heading in. However
votesHelpful: there can also be tasks like towing things to a certain point
votesTotal: or the miore challenging "maintain a certian population" or "maintain a certain surplus of goods or power" or "have this number of service buildings".\n\nThe optimal inputs and outputs are now listed in the description of each building
votesFunny: which I think is better than the guessing game that it used to be. The optimal inputs & outputs did exist in previous games
commentsCount: but you weren't told what they were."

reviewText:
I’ve played Dawn of Discovery and Anno 2070, I like the games. The only things I don’t like about this game is that you don’t get to play with others and you don’t get a lot of land or a big enough map. Honestly, I would rather have all the maps combined into one super map than play in slices the way it is now.

Now, to the things I really like.

Building upgrades. You build something, then you can spend more to add upgrades to it so really, it’s like building several buildings yet it hardly takes any space! I mean, eventually you’ll have to build others, but you build fewer than what you had to do in the other games.

Moving buildings. Holy potato this saves time! I mean, I don’t have to destroy whole swathes of buildings just to switch stuff around!

I like how they added bridges and things. All the visuals are fantastic, a feast for the eyes.

What I wish…

Honestly I would love for them to make a game that goes from primitive to futuristic. A game that combines all their games into one. Something that allows you to truly grow a world and the people in it. Dawn of Discovery is still my favorite out of all the games. I do recommend Anno 2205, because it’s still a great game, I just don’t consider it in the same league as DoD and 2070.

They could do a whole lot MORE with this game. It’s like they took the idea of the future and took it too far, leaving behind everything that made their other games so good. If you’ve not played any of their other games, you’ll like this game. If you have played their other games, you’ll find yourself returning to those and only playing this one sometimes.

I’m not satisfied, but for what it is, I like it. I just won’t play this one much till they give me more than boring single player in bite sized maps. I yawn at the whole corporate buying and politics, I liked how things were done in dawn of discovery. Maybe they are building up to something like, but I doubt it. Maybe their next game will go back to the things I loved best about the series.

reviewText:
After reading all the hate on Anno2205, i wasn't going to buy it. I've always liked the Anno series, so when it came up in the sale i thought screw it, how bad can it be? The answer is... It isn't. It's a great game!
I don't play Multiplayer so this isn't a problem for me.
The combat system is fine for a single player game. Reminds me of C&C. I can see why it's done this way, It's a bu8ilding game at heart.
The maps are vast, the cities are vast. I'm having to manage 3 zones at once. Thank god im not having to micromanage trade fleets like previous games. Which i suppose is right, I'm the CEO of a company why would i care about logistics?, I tell some pleb where i want certain goods to go, and they get on with it. I can focus on building, meeting demand and not going bankrupt.
I really like the relocate building feature, I'm not stuck with a building i've positioned only to find after modding it a little, I've run out of room and have to delete it like previous games.
Graphics are really nice, gets a bit laggy if you play for a few hours, there seems to be some issue with it holding onto irrelevent data and hogging system resources, Just means after a few hours I'll have to quit and reload to keep it smooth.

If your playing it on easy and blasting your way through it in 10 hours thats your problem. If you take your time to meet demand, mod your buildings to make them more efficient, do side quests, do up your ships and make your cities and industrial areas look nice, the main campaign is easily as long as the other games. I'm guessing there will be future DLC with new senarios and expanded gameplay, but as a base game I'm really happy with it. I'll look forward to seeing where they go with it.

reviewText:
Pros
-	It looks great! A lot of effort has been put into the design of the buildings and sector landscapes.
-	Many hours of gameplay.
-	The module system, which allows you to upgrade your production facilities.
-	Three sectors in each of the three game regions providing plenty of room to build.
-	No longer have to manage eco balance.
-	User interface is clean and simple to use.
-	Trade routes are simplified, but still remain a key gameplay element.  Eventually, you can transfer energy.

Cons
-	No multiplayer.
-       No manual save (cannot revert to earlier save game).
-       Simplified trade routes (compared to Anno 2070).
-	Load times can be a little slow, but generally there is no issue here. Note: I do have the game installed on an SSD (see below for further detail).
-	Game crashed on me twice in first 27 hours of play.
-	If purchased via Steam, Uplay is still required. Although my experience of Uplay has been positive.
-	Conflict zone gameplay becomes repetitive.

Summary

This is not Anno 2070. Yes, this is a good thing.  It is, however, at its core, still Anno.

This time around, you are in control of your own corporation with the aim of reaching the Moon.  Once there, you can mine Helium-3 and produce vast amounts of energy that you can transmit to your cities back on Earth.

As was the case in Anno 2070, you build production facilities to supply the needs of your inhabitants.  Once certain needs are met, you can upgrade residential buildings, which introduces the need for further goods and services, such as intelliwear and androids, security and transportation.  You carefully balance the supply and demand of these goods and services and watch your metropolis flourish.  The sectors look amazing, and as your corporation level increases you receive additional rare resources with which you can purchase modules for your facilities.  Trade is conducted between sectors, once your spaceports have been upgraded.

I have thoroughly enjoyed my first 20+ hours with Anno 2205, and I look forward to many more! (8 / 10)

Additional Comments

I do not understand all of the negative comments that are being made in other reviews. As another reviewer has suggested, perhaps those with more positive feedback are too busy playing and enjoying the game.

I played the game on the Advanced difficulty level, and I had bought all sectors, reached 150k investors and built my corporation HQ after approximately 27 hours of play.  I have not fully developed my cities/settlements in the other sectors.  I look forward to many more hours of gameplay.

I have spent over 80 hours with Anno 2070, and I can honestly say that Anno 2205 does become just as complex as you progress further into the game.

Others may disagree, but I believe the game is far from over once you build your HQ.  You can really begin to optimise and expand your cities.  You can even add modules to your corporation HQ.

I have also tried the Asteroid Miner companion app.  This is not simply a Bejeweled clone as others have suggested – it is similar, yes.  Transfer of rare resources requires that you sign in to your Uplay account with your registered email and password or Facebook credentials.  It is worth noting that after just 15 minutes of play the back of my handset did feel quite warm to the touch – I can only assume this is due to heavy use of the phone’s resources.

Please Note: Although I have completed the main objectives, reaching a population of 150k investors and building my corporation HQ, I still continue to play.  This may result in updates to the content of this review.

Played on the following hardware/software:
AMD FX8350 CPU
Crucial M550 SSD
Crucial 32GB RAM
GTX 660 2GB GPU
Windows 10 Pro OS

reviewText:
A solid economy/management game. I do like the interrelated biomes that send and recieve goods to create a complete production web. The gameplay is a bit different from previous Anno titles, but I actually prefer this approach. You still have your different factions to keep happy, but they're split out across the three biomes, so you only have to worry about one at a time, which I like. They're not the same factions (eco/industrial/scientist -> temperate/polar/lunar, plus maybe tundra/orbital in future DLC).

Of course, as you can see from the screen shots and videos, the game looks fantastic. It's graphically very detailed and polished. The UI is also very solid. The tech is there.

The combat missions are... off-putting. I wasn't able to figure out how to create command groups, which is frustrating. In general, the combat left me feeling a bit 'meh'. Fortunately, you don't have to do them apart from two or three mandatory missions (maybe fewer - most of the story battles can be skipped just by gaining a corp level, which is pretty easy).

The tutorial NPCs are very naggy. Like, seriously obnoxious. If I have to listen to 'Time to upgrade your factories' one more time... Anyway, there's an option to turn those off. I am trying to hold off until I finish the story quests to do that, just in case I miss something, but it's getting harder every time the npcs remind me about an unfinished combat mission or to upgrade.

There's also mini quests? I guess that's what you'd call 'em. Basically, you have a little boat or buggy that's your avatar in the colony that you can run around and do errands for people to get the 'special resources' that you cannot acquire on your own. You can minimize the need to do this if you select the sectors that have rare resources as their perk. I did that on all three biomes, as I didn't find the mini quests enjoyable.

Overall, I'm really enjoying the game. It feels like an Anno game, but different enough to be interesting to me (and apparently to anger some Anno fans ;oP There's some real vitreol in the reviews here). For my money, I found it worth it enough to by the Season Pass. Thumbs up!

reviewText: I'm about 7 hours in and loving it. I played the heck out of Anno 2070, and this new version holds up. It's certainly different - the scale is much larger - but I actually really appreciate that they down play the fidgety clicking for fetch quests and make information about your economy and city much easier to access and understand. It's also interesting how they're replaced the automatic placement of farm components with a more intentional customizable system. Combat is more interesting, for certain, but no where near on-par with a real strategy game like StarCraft or Command and Conquer. I'm still learning a lot about how to lay out my cities and keep everything balanced. My only concern at this stage is wondering if I'll be able to advance the game to a point of being able to sandbox with more custom world settings. Not sure if that's after you beat it or something they'll make available through DLC. So, overall I give it an A- and am looking forward to discovering more!

reviewText:
I figured I'd help those that are thinking about this purchase and have no idea what to choose based on mixed reviews.

The game is gorgeous for one and its hard to pass up a game even if not great when it looks better than every city builder in existence.

I have not played a lot at all but started out and could immediately tell how different this was.

Whether or not you would enjoy this game determines what previous Anno camp youre from or if you've never played an Anno game before.

New comers would probably love the game because there is nothing to compare this to except Simcity or Skylines in most cases.  I've played previous Anno's and have both city games and this is what Sim City should have looked like graphically.

Now, as for my previous Anno experience: I came from the camp that never played Anno all the way through because I get tired of managing EVERYTHING.  It becomes really tedious and a very difficult balancing act to enjoy.  I also didn't like that resources ran out, meaning at some point the game was going to end even on continuous to make people happy....Or I'm missing something that would allow iron, coal etc to exist forever.  On top of that, other islands eventually become unhappy if one side is prospering in new food/technology etc.
I learned that while a great game, that level of micro managing makes playing like a full time job and things can go really south if you lose track.


I know some people love that about Anno and that is mostly why they dislike this game.  Its much easier to get started, not as complex planning is needed right off the bat, it is much more forgiving and changes have been made to remove a large portion of micro managing.  When I say a large portion, consider any previous Anno series game is entirely micromanaging comparatively....so I welcome the break.

So ultimately it comes down to what you liked about the previous Anno's or if this is the first time you've run into an Anno game.

If you like micromanaging everything to the T and enjoy tedious planning, then the previous Anno's are for you.

If you like a slightly more casual gameplay that escalates in a controllable manner without feeling like a second job and like to spend the time watching things grow instead of checking your inventories regularly, boat schedules/transfer rates, trial and error etc, and are looking for something a little more involved than Sim City or Skylines, this is probably going to be a Good - Great game for you.

I hope this helps to clarify some of the mystery.  I haven't played long enough to go into full details but it is really hard to get a reading for this game from some of the reviews...especially ones that say this game is crap
recommended: the others were so much better" without the discussion of what the difference really is or which camp they're coming from.\n\nAlso for hardware specs sake
hoursPlayed: I am running an i5 Devils Canyon at 4GHZ and a 980 TI at 2560 x 1080

helpfulPercent: 512GB SSD on Ultra - 8x AA max everything. Some studdering in the cut scenes which may be normal

reviewText:
The Anno series has been around since 1998 as an intricate business simulation and city building game.  It is similar to the Settlers series and the old Sierra City Building games in that on top of the city building elements, you have to develop a balanced economy to ensure that goods and services are available for its citizens.  If you compare this series to a game like SimCity, Cities XL, and City Life, the focus is less on the individuality of the buildings.  Instead, it is solely on the ecoomics of the town.  While the city feels more alive, the one downside of these games is that unless you can develop a sound strategy for trading, your city will always be stunted and never grow.

Specifically on Anno 2205, the most recent in the series, it is very much a refined experience.  Compared to the freemium game, the game has no microtransactions and you do not have to wait for buildings to be built.  Compared to the previous game in the series, Anno 2070, this game is definitely more accessible.  Rare resources are not has impossible to find as you can win them in simple combat missions or fetch quests.  The basic economy, which has less granular information and no tutorials, is at least easier to understand.  With trading between cities (one of the biggest strengths IMO), your cities feel important.  I constantly find myself going between the different maps in the game to build up my economy so that I have more money for other cities.  Oh yea, your balanced check book is based on the combined value of all of your cities.

Overall, I recommend this game for anyone who like city simulation games like Settlers, Caesar series, SimCity, City Life, and Cities: Skyline.


Pros:
-Graphics
-Music
-Performance
-Quest System
-Combat Minigame
-Generally Fun Experience
-City Networks that actually make sense

Cons:
-Less Granular Information
-Season Pass

reviewText:
Firstly, I will say I have been with the Anno franchise since 1602 and have played every single Anno since. Anyone who is a fan of the franchise should know that each game has changed considerably with each iteration whether it be the use of community centres, what resources you will need and where, what sort of factions you will build... 2205 is just the same. Whilst I agree mildly with some reviews which says certain features have been removed for no reason like having a warehouse with goods in that you can trade for profit and not knowing how many of each production building you will need for optimum output, once you put some time into the game you realise that it's very much an Anno game at the core.

I am at the point in the game where you first start to colonise the moon which was 5 hours of casual play. When I first started the game I was a bit worried. It didn't seem like it had the same production managment that you did previous. I loved optimising farm space and working in little tight production trees which use as little space as possible and once you start on the later goods you realise that it's still there in the module system. I'm loving modules and figuring out how much space I need to optimise the production factory to maximum. It's just done in a different way.

As for rare materials, I remember that 1701 did a similar thing with resources like Jade? And lets not forget licences from 2070. You get them from completing quests, you don't have to do the combat minigame.

As for the combat minigame, I agree there needs to be more maps. But I feel that maps will be added to the game as it moves along and I don't think that's a bad thing. It's keeps interest. I like the combat as it gets rid of a bit of monotony, though the people do start bugging you about completing and then suddenly another will be available.

When reading reviews bear in mind the amount of time the person has played they game as like any Anno game it's a nice relaxing start that suddenly becomes too much to bear. And whilst I believe I'm a player that will figure these problems out quite easy (Watching youtubers play this game is rage inducing.) I'm still not worried about longevity.

If you must. Give it time, wait for people to get over the rage of how easy 1 hour of gameplay is and then come back and see if opinions change.

As an Anno Veteran. I am very pleased.

reviewText:
First Review uptade:

Short Version: Management games don't have to be about isolation. Isolated maps, isolated game modes or missions. Anno 2205 is about continuous gameplay, development, integration and blending of systems. Elegant game design is the core here. Its like previous games of the series where cake ingredients and this edition finally mixed and taken then together to the oven.

Long Version:

Anno 2205 mix in a very interesting way the concept of endless mode and campaing of most city builders. The improvements and streamlining of user interface and gameplay are notable and really make the game more enjoyable to play than previous titles in the series.

The use of more than one biome" really put more emphasis on interconnecting the economies of different regions and the little changes in gameplay between this biomes are a nice little change of mood.

Battles still feel like a inadequade guest in Anno games
date: but at least this time they are more well constrained to a side mission structure
recommended: making them easier to ignore if you like or more like a small lite action romp to briefly easy your mind.\n\nA big notable change to gameplay is the fact that now you can change the position of previously placed structures. At first this seem like a way to make placemant mistakes less of a nuisance
hoursPlayed: but on long term has few interesting repercussions on gameplay. For once
voteText: previously planning placement of everything on the map is much less important
helpfulPercent: but at same time you have much more room for constante tinkering and optimization city of layouts. A feel that
votesHelpful: for the proposed structure of continuous gameplay and multiple cities
votesTotal: this is a welcome change.\n\nA nice first impression from this strategy/builder. It is familiar but not afraid to change core aspects of the genre design and I think mostly well succeded in doing so. If any impression changes in the long term gameplay I'll update the review again."

reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic.

Don't listen to the nay sayers. The only thing that's changed in this game from previous games is the fact that the goods are now a production vs consumption ticker, versus a stockpile. The stockpile is still available, but it's for emergency use, when you run low on production. The reason for this is because you are playing multiple zones. When you are away in a different zone, the time in other zones still progresses. If they were to have a stockpile type of model, you would have exubirant ammount of resources stock piled in other zones when you eventually return there, and it would make the game pointless and without a challenge.

The supply chains in this game are complex and involved. If you loved managing production, supply, transportation, etc.. from the previous titles, you will absolutely love it here. It's even more involved.

A lot of care went into the world. As production grows, on screen traffic of supply and cargo ships expands. The traffic is very dynamic and you will see your city and zones change over time as you put work into building your world. It's amazing how much care went into this game.

reviewText:
(Skip to the Pros/Cons if you don't want to read a lot.)

I love this game and am very happy with it, and I think it deserves a higher rating. I think a lot of these reviews came from people expecting something different from this game, so make sure you know what you're buying before you spend your money.

I have not played the previous Anno games, so I don't know how this game compares. I have loved the Sim City games for a long time, though, and was very disappointed by their most recent game (Sim City). This game feels a lot like what I would have liked to see instead. It's smooth, it's not filled with pointless micro-managing, it's pretty, and it's fun. If you want a game that makes you constantly play catch-up and worry about your citizens dying, then I wouldn't recommend this game (get something like Banished, which is also an awesome game, instead). If you want to build cities and watch them grow while building towards a goal, then definitely buy this game (if you've got a bit of extra money).
A lot of people have said that this game is oversimplified. Although it's true that more depth and freedom would be nice, they've also made the game significantly less annoying than many city-builder games. Also, the longer you play the game and the more you branch out, the more complicated and involved the game becomes. It's really up to you how simple things are.

Pros:
- Pretty
- Relaxing (potentially, if you're not pushing your company forward quickly)
- Loyal to the city-builder genre
- Fun combat
- Storyline
- Starts simple, becomes complex

Cons:
- Not very challenging at first (again, it's possible to challenge yourself with this game more and more as it goes on)
- Might be a bit too structured for some people
- Not a huge amount of content (yet?)
- Expensive
- Repetitive combat

reviewText:
I’ve played Dawn of Discovery and Anno 2070, I like the games. The only things I don’t like about this game is that you don’t get to play with others and you don’t get a lot of land or a big enough map. Honestly, I would rather have all the maps combined into one super map than play in slices the way it is now.

Now, to the things I really like.

Building upgrades. You build something, then you can spend more to add upgrades to it so really, it’s like building several buildings yet it hardly takes any space! I mean, eventually you’ll have to build others, but you build fewer than what you had to do in the other games.

Moving buildings. Holy potato this saves time! I mean, I don’t have to destroy whole swathes of buildings just to switch stuff around!

I like how they added bridges and things. All the visuals are fantastic, a feast for the eyes.

What I wish…

Honestly I would love for them to make a game that goes from primitive to futuristic. A game that combines all their games into one. Something that allows you to truly grow a world and the people in it. Dawn of Discovery is still my favorite out of all the games. I do recommend Anno 2205, because it’s still a great game, I just don’t consider it in the same league as DoD and 2070.

They could do a whole lot MORE with this game. It’s like they took the idea of the future and took it too far, leaving behind everything that made their other games so good. If you’ve not played any of their other games, you’ll like this game. If you have played their other games, you’ll find yourself returning to those and only playing this one sometimes.

I’m not satisfied, but for what it is, I like it. I just won’t play this one much till they give me more than boring single player in bite sized maps. I yawn at the whole corporate buying and politics, I liked how things were done in dawn of discovery. Maybe they are building up to something like, but I doubt it. Maybe their next game will go back to the things I loved best about the series.

reviewText:
Don't worry about all the negative reviews. It almost scared me away from buying it, but oh my! Once you're a few hours in the game really shines. Most of the negative reviews are from people that have not played the game long enough to really get into the meat of the game it seems. Don't be fooled by my gametime, I played it elsewhere and instantly bought it afterwards for myself.

There is also an iOS / Android game (match-3 type game) that allows you to transfer extra resources to your game. I'm not a candy-crush fan, but I really enjoy the idea and it allows me to make some progress on the way home from work.

All in all, I'm thoroughly enjoying the game. It's decidedly different from the Anno games before it, but I do enjoy the improvements. If I want to experience the previous gameplay I just fire up 2070 or 1404! So it's a worthy addition to hte series. Don't fear change.

reviewText:
There's been a lot of criticism over this game, so after completing the mian storyline and racking over 40 hours I have come to my conclusion and I have to say that despite the price tag I felt it was money well spent. But whether or not it is still an Anno game depends on your definition. If you want a game about city building, supply chains, logistics and economy management then yes this is still Anno. Some of the complexity of these fundamentals may have been lost but sometimes that can be a good thing.

The scope of thsgameworld feels much bigger than any Anno game before it, Blue Byte Mainz (not Ubisoft, they were the PUBLISHER, not the developer) has created a game where I truly feel like I am creating a transnational logistics network with goods being shipped from around the globe to supply a colossal metropolis. Cities feel huge and vuibrant, especially in the temperate zones, the whole scope of the game feels like a dial had been turned up considerably. You may be running island chains a fraction of the scale of the previous games but in all honestly save for some really massive islands in Anno 1503, most of the games made it seem like the entire world decided to settle the East Indes. So I'm glad that even though there's only one city map that's joined to a continent. It feels more varied overall. I am still going to miss the random island system though.

The world itself feels distinct compared to previous ones which is always a plus with a new instalment of a franchise and there are a ton of visual and backstory cues to 2070 and if you're an Annoholic like me you may get a smile if you spot them. Even when cities get enormous they feel busy: In 1404 and 2070 whenever your city got to a certain size the crowd sizes would drastically drop; emptying entire districts of walkers. So far I have yet to see this kind of depopulation in 2205 as far as car traffic is concerned so that's a big plus.

COmbat has been overhauled to be confined to Crisis Zones that are all about combat. They're a very different feel to the rest of the game and feel much more involved than combat in previosu games. Though the tactic of lump all ships together and plow through your enemies" is still somehat effective
date: a good commander will use all tactical advantages at his disposal like a missile strike
recommended: calling submarines or activating shields. It does beat the feeling of sicking your ships on a hostile mob and waiting for them to all die from Swiss Cheese Hull.\n\nI won't lie
hoursPlayed: the game does feel a little lacking in places. Random events like fire
voteText: illness and crime are gone
helpfulPercent: your competitors are mostly background features and the Crisis Zones
votesHelpful: while offering a nice break from city building
votesTotal: can feel repetetive. Not helped by the providers nagging you saying "please get this job done" every 10 minutes when the only reason to do them is to get rare resources or kill time for your money supply to build up. One of the crisis zones involves lifting a blockade
votesFunny: but does it affect your supply chains in any way? None whatsoever and that feels like a missed mechanical opportunity. The supply balance mechanic as a UI element goes either way for me; its nice to know where I'm encountering shortages and quickly fix them but when it came to oversupply I enjoyed the feeling of loading up cargo ships and selling any overflow I had to my neighbours. Unless there's a feature I'm missing
commentsCount: the local trading posts from each sector only sell you things and don't buy anything.\n\nThis game has potential with expansion. The story ends with ambitious implications and Ubisoft has already announced two upcoming zone types which by the looks of things will be just as distinct as the three zones we already have. And there might be more coming down the pipeline as for 2070 Ubi we had host of small new things within the first 12 months of a release
column16: with a fully-blown expansion when the period approached a close. We might see the same for 2205 but the inclusion of a season pass implies we have more to come beyond two new maps.\n\nI still consider it a positive experience though. It's a solid and relatively bug-free game that feels like a smooth continuation of the series and when it comes to issues Ubisoft's technical support have been very active and helpful on the Steam forums. So I will probably be playing it for a while."

reviewText: Although, the game is still fairly new I would have to say that I have found Anno 2205 to be challenging. I say that because of the space management involved and not just micro managing multiple different resources. I found that the longer I played that more complex the game became and it increased the difficulty, at least in my own opinion it felt that way. Making sure your other colonies had sufficient power, materials, and consumables were a constant that had to be monitored often, Otherwise, your credits would start plummeting because your population had grown too big or you weren't producing the optimum amount of resources for your citizens. One thing I would like to have changed is the time control. I would rather the keybinding for increasing/decreasing time speed could be toggled and not held down only.

reviewText:
As a player who loved Anno 2070 I believe that this is a welcome change to the Anno series.  Sure there are some changes that have been made that require less micromanaging:

-storage has changed to a + / - system where you have to keep a surplus of items instead of having your olf storage cap out.
-Less aquatic micromanaging of constantly forgetting to move ships from on island to the next.

I love the multiple scenario idea from the  temperate areas to the arctic and the moon.  I really appreciated this aspect of Anno 2070 and having the ability to construct underwater platforms.

They've added some to the game to make things a bit more enjoyable for the causual city builder player like myself and I can see where the hardcore micromanagers think this game falls short.

tl:dr - If you don't like constant micromanaging then this game is phenominal, definitely reccomend

reviewText:
Coming in from a long time player of the Anno series, the game is perfectly fine. The graphics are decent, the gameplay is pretty similar to what the old time players are expecting, some stuff is streamlined as some people are upset over but honestly it's not ruining anything. I'm not going to give some hefty review as it's not really needed when you have throngs of 30 paragraph posts; the game itself is fun if you enjoyed the last few games to come out and if you're already using Steam or Origin in the first place you probably don't care about Ubisoft's little system.

The gimmick for this Anno is the multiple colony system. You build up not just island to island but to other sections of the full map itself, after that you can tap into the moon for all sorts of odd resources and what not. Ocean combat got brought back in from Anno 2070 for some reason but it's about as smooth as it should be.

Pros:
Exact same game everyone expected it to be.
UPlay doesn't do anything but sit there quietly and let you sneak in little perks as you level up.
It's a pretty game, nothing Earth shattering but it looks good.
They didn't change much other than some of the lesser systems.
Yep, still the same build 20 buildings that feed into 20 buildings that feed into 5 buildings game we've loved for 10ish years.
Lots of banter making fun of the Tycoon faction from 2070, pretty sure nobody actually played them because they were bad...

Cons:
Voice acting kinda sucks for the character that introduces you to combat. Pretty sure they actually brought in a boatsman.
$60 is a bit much unless Anno is one of your favorite series. Money well spent for me but maybe not for everyone.


Tl;dr: Moderate bashing for no reason from others, but the game is rather great and pretty darn fun at the moment. Only bugs was some of my buildings randomly turning blue and some weird shimmering while zoomed out; minor stuff.

reviewText:
I've been playing the anno series since the very beginning.  This is my favorite installment so far.

Things I like:

I like that they tell you how much each item will produce and whether or not your low or not.  I always hated guessing how many of plant x I needed to support a plant y.
The graphics and cut screens are first rate.
I haven't hit any bugs so far.

Things I don't like:
Switching between areas takes too long--I don't like the loading wait.

No island exploration anymore.

Overall, I'm very impressed and very happy with the game.

reviewText:
So after reading through some of the reviews and also adding my own experience of at least the first few hours of gameplay i can with an honest heart claim that its different but the same.

I love the rework of structural balancing in terms of placement and customization; yes you can read up on some of these reviews" that have negative impact on that you cannot use the same sort of custom harbor manipulation as you could in the previous version i myself thought it was cool and all that BUT had some major drawbacks on the ai pathing and combat capacity so im glad they did away with it instead of using a half ♥♥♥♥♥ variation as i cannot see a reason for them in this iteration.

So far not sure what the complaints on lag is all about i would assume it boils down to drivers and compatibility because i have had nothing but a smooth fast experience ( including streaming to some friends ) lack of multiplayer yes of course i really really want to beat friends at base building etc BUT considering how the game is made up im not really sure how they would practicly solve a lot of the mechanics without resulting in massive out of sync issues.

The campaign though ( and i miss those in a lot of games ) are really good
date:
a bit cheesy at times with some of the side missions but you can overcome them due to the rest of the game being really polished and epic looking.

recommended: combat is not really that impressive do you need to focus on maintaining a good balance between production
hoursPlayed:

reviewText: Don't believe the haters that the game is a buggy dumbed down mess. It runs fine on my mediocre PC (R9 280X/i5 4690k @4Ghz) without any issues. No crashes, audio is not missing. On the dumbed down part, sure it starts out simple, but in a few hours you'll unlock production factory upgrades (eg: fields in previous Anno games), and arctic region. The game is not overly easy on medium, you actually have to watch your resources otherwise you are going to run into problems. There is one big issue though: the crisis sectors. They are horribly implemented, boring and long if you do the sidequests for the extra necessary resources. Also they are part of the story, I had to complete two up until now. Let's hope that one of the DLC sectors will provide an alternative in acquiring the rare materials.\n\nVerdict: the game is good, looks nice, plays nice. The price and the crisis sectors are big negatives though. If you just want to play an Anno game, buy 2070, it's cheaper and more fleshed out. If you ran out of Anno games to play and have enough disposable income (or not interested in) to buy Fallout 4 then this game is a good choice.

reviewText: I am giving this game a new review due to my last review being negitive. I simply didn't give this game a good play through. I have 200 HRS of Anno 2070 game play, and 120 HRS were spent dealing with the logistics of shipping what product where and what ship to put it on, and end game is maddness when something breaks in this shipping mayhem. So when I read reviews upset that the logistics is not the same I can't relate at all! I find it as the best remake and difference in the game and something that needed to be changed, and I am not a newby. I find the game submersive with the sound track and amazing...I mean amazing graphics and that is on high settings. I have a Geforce 980 and on ultra settings my frame rate drops in the 20's and teens in some places. I have always enjoyed Anno for the things they add into the appearance of the game and didn't have to..it just speaks excellence to me when someone pays attention to the perfection in the details. Every model in this game will make your jaw drop. It is so well done you could kid your eye into thinking you are looking at work being done on the Moon. I applaud the people at Anno for there dedication to the series...well worth my time and money!

reviewText: hmmm,,,, tbh i do not now what to think =/. Looks cool, yes, this is obvious. BUT, the last anno that i played quite alot was 1404, and was really amazing, everything. But with this i feel that everything is easier, not really challenging and quite guided every thing. So the game ends up being boring =/. Its super sad for me to say this, but its exactly what i feel. And also that the planning and building feels that it goes super fast, like clikc click, done. I payed 70 bucks for the gold edition, and in my opinion is not worth that money. To sum up, i'm disapointed with the new Anno, because the lack of challenge or motivation when playing it. (hope to be the only one feeling this)
